Texas Radiation - Newsbits

 April 27, 2001

By Mary Manning

 LAS VEGAS SUN

 If nuclear power use expands, a proposed
repository at Yucca Mountain could end up with five to 10 times the
amount of radioactive waste that has been set by law, an
Energy Department official said.

 But it would take an act of Congress to increase
the amount, Russ Dyer, DOE Yucca Mountain project manager,
said this week during a tour of the mountain 90 miles northwest
of Las Vegas.

 "That suggestion is the reason that nuclear waste
must never come to Yucca Mountain," said Rep. Shelley
Berkley, D-Nev., who was on the tour and asked Dyer about expansion.

 Yucca Mountain, the lone site chosen to contain
commercial reactor and defense wastes, is under study to
determine whether it can contain up to 77,000 tons of high-level
nuclear waste.

 Congress set the amount of waste in the 1980s,
when it singled out Yucca Mountain from three sites that were
being examined.

 About 7,000 tons would come from weapons-related
activities, including Navy submarine reactors. The other
70,000 tons would be spent nuclear fuel from 103 commercial reactors.
 
 However, nuclear regulators are extending the
operating life of the nation's nuclear reactors, Dyer said.

 Five operating reactors have received 20-year
license extensions from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. License
renewals for another five reactors are pending.

 Another 32 reactors are expected to apply for
license renewal by 2005.

 If all of those extensions are granted, about
120,000 tons of waste would have to be buried over the next 40
years just from existing reactors, and Yucca Mountain is the only
repository expected to be open, Dyer said.

 "There's no appetite in Congress to find a second
repository," Dyer said.

 If more reactors are built to meet growing energy
demands, the waste volume could increase to between 500,000
tons and 700,000 tons, he said.

 A repository at Yucca Mountain would have space
to expand, he said. It would require a vote of Congress.

 That might not be so easy, one congressional
watcher said. "I wouldn't say it would be an automatic win in
Congress these days," said Lisa Gue of Public Citizen, an
environmental watchdog group founded by Ralph Nader.

 Spokesmen for the nuclear industry and former
Sen. Bennett Johnston, D-La., author of the bill that singled
out Yucca Mountain, said they had not heard that the
repository might need to expand.
 
 "I have not heard that, since the amount of
nuclear waste is set by law," said Johnston, now a Washington lobbyist
representing international concerns including energy companies.
The former senator authored an amendment in 1987 known as the
"Screw Nevada" bill, which eliminated any other option for
managing nuclear waste except burying it in a proposed repository
at Yucca Mountain.

 The nuclear industry has never projected such
high numbers for its wastes or expanding a Yucca Mountain
repository, Steve Kerekes, spokesman for the Nuclear Energy
Institute in Washington, said.

 "I have never heard that," Kerekes said. "Right
now it's an open question."

 However, nuclear utilities are hoping that if the
energy crisis spreads from California across the country this
summer, it will revive a demand for nuclear power, he said.

 "While we're very confident there will be some
nuclear reactors built in the coming years, I have not heard of any
numbers of that kind," Kerekes said of the waste amounts
suggested by Dyer.

 Berkley has supported research funds for
alternatives to Yucca Mountain. Scientists are developing new techniques
to reduce the amount of nuclear waste using advanced
accelerators in Los Alamos National Laboratory. UNLV received $3 million of
the $34 million secured for accelerator research this year.

 A million dollars a day is being spent on
research on Yucca Mountain's suitability, and getting more to study
alternatives has been a hard sell in Congress, Steve Frishman,
technology coordinator for the state's Agency for Nuclear
Projects, said.

 DOE officials oppose spending a lot of money on
alternatives such as advanced accelerators, saying that they
would take too long and be cost prohibitive.

 But, Berkley said, more must be done.

 "I am opposed to any attempt to expand nuclear
energy in this country until we figure out what to do with the
nuclear wastes," Berkley said.

===============================================================

      Source: Wall Street Journal
      Published: 28Sep99 Author: Micah Morrison, WSJ Editorial Writer

AUSTIN, Texas--In April, the office of Gov. George W. Bush released a
statement summarizing his 1998 taxable income. Mr. Bush had earned over $18
million, the "vast majority"
from the sale of the Texas Rangers baseball team. The governor's share of
the Rangers sale was $14.9 million, his biggest payday ever.

Mr. Bush played a significant role in putting together the investment group
that purchased the Rangers in 1989; he later was named a general partner of
the franchise. Prior to his career
in baseball, he had struggled for more than a decade in the oil business.
How Mr. Bush parlayed a lackluster tenure in the oil patch into a $15
million home run and a seat in the
governor's mansion is a subtle morality tale about the highways and byways
to contemporary political power. Like Vice President Albert Gore Jr., who
will be the subject of an article on
this page tomorrow, Mr. Bush is the son of an influential politician. Like
Mr. Gore, Mr. Bush has crossed paths with some of the seamier characters
who gravitate toward political power.
And both men--while not without pluck and political skills of their
own--have profited from family connections.

This two-part series is not a tale of smoking guns and indictable offenses.
Yet voters should know the financial connections of candidates, though they
probably will make their decisions
on other grounds. And while the candidates will not appreciate questions
being raised about the murky areas of their finances, the lessons of the
Clinton era suggest that it is better to put
matters on the table early, lest they rise Whitewater-like to haunt a new
administration.

Mr. Bush's career with the Rangers baseball team, for example, is likely to
come under intense scrutiny in the next 12 months. In 1989, when Mr. Bush
brought together his investment
group to buy the Rangers, the seller was Eddie Chiles, a longtime friend
and supporter of President Bush. Mr. Chiles let the president's son and his
group go to the head of the line. But
in a pattern repeated through his business career, Mr. Bush's play did not
quite make the grade. Baseball Commissioner Peter Ueberroth stepped in,
brokering a deal that brought Fort
Worth financier Richard Rainwater together with the Bush group. Mr.
Ueberroth's pitch to Mr. Rainwater was that he join the deal partly "out of
respect" for President Bush, a source
close to the negotiations told the New York Times.

Mr. Bush ponied up $500,000 as his personal grubstake in the $86 million
purchase. He later invested another $106,000, bringing his share to 1.8% of
the team. For his organizing
efforts, his new partners rewarded him with an additional 10% interest.
They also named him a managing general partner, a move that assured Mr.
Bush a series of benign cameos in the
limelight as he ramped up a run for Texas governor. Mr. Bush kept a low
profile as his new baseball partners aggressively and successfully lobbied
for a special referendum in which the
voters of Arlington, Texas, approved a sales-tax increase to cover the $135
million cost of a new stadium. Texas conservatives denounced the measure as
"corporate welfare."

Mr. Bush borrowed the $500,000 for his stake in the Rangers from United
Bank of Midland, Texas, where he had served as a director from 1984 to
1986. Karen Hughes, a
spokeswoman for Gov. Bush, declined to detail the terms of the loan. But
she said it was a "fully collateralized, traditional loan, and fully paid
off."

In fact, the loan was paid off through the sale of stock Mr. Bush had been
awarded in his only successful venture in the oil business, as a director
of Texas-based Harken Energy Corp.
Barely afloat in the tough oil market in the early 1980s, Mr. Bush joined
Harken as a director in 1986. He was given 212,000 shares of Harken stock,
worth about $500,000, or $2.50 a
share, at the end of the year--although he had no daily management
responsibilities. He later acquired an additional 133,000 shares through
special offerings to company directors, and he
was paid between $42,000 and $120,000 a year for the next five years as a
consultant.

Prior to joining Harken, Mr. Bush's business record was not good. He
started his first firm, Arbusto Energy, in 1977, the headiest days of the
oil patch, and was buffeted along with all
the others by the high interest rates and collapsing oil prices of the next
few years. Hoping to boost its fortunes, he changed Arbusto's name to Bush
Exploration, then merged it with
Spectrum 7 Energy Corp. in an effort to stay afloat. As the hard times
continued, Spectrum merged with Harken Energy.

Harken viewed Mr. Bush's famous name as an important asset, oil industry
executives close to the deal have said. Harken officials will not comment
about Mr. Bush, but records show
that the company's stock began to climb right after the Spectrum merger was
announced, hitting $6 a share within a year before falling back. Mr. Bush
was philosophical about losing his
management role in the oil business but retaining profit. "I try to talk up
Harken whenever I can," he told Forbes magazine in June 1987, "and I'd feel
a lot worse if the stock hadn't
tripled."

In 1989, Harken's stock was trading at between $4 and $5 a share. That's
when Mr. Bush put up his shares as collateral for the Rangers loan. In
January 1990, with shares trading
around $4.50, Harken announced that it had signed a potentially lucrative
oil-exploration deal with the government of Bahrain. On June 20, 1990, Mr.
Bush sold the bulk of his Harken
stock for $848,000, at $4 a share, and paid off the Rangers loan. Eight
days later, Harken finished the second quarter with losses of $23 million,
and the stock went into a nosedive,
losing nearly 75% of its value, finishing the year at a little over $1 a share.

Critics of Mr. Bush cried foul, charging that as a Harken director he was
in a position to trade illegally on insider information before the stock's
decline. Mr. Bush ultimately was cleared
by the Securities and Exchange Commission. But suspicions of Mr. Bush's
lucky timing had heightened at first, when the SEC, discovering that he had
not filed the proper disclosure
form, opened an investigation into the president's son. Mr. Bush claimed
that he did file the correct form, but that it had been lost. He also said
that he had cleared the stock sale with
Harken's general counsel.

"At the time of the sale," explained Ms. Hughes, the Bush spokeswoman, "he
did not know about the losses that would later be posted." Mr. Bush was not
selling ahead of bad news,
Ms. Hughes said, but into the good news that the Bass brothers, Texas
billionaires with deep pockets and overseas drilling experience, were
inking a joint-exploration pact with Harken in
Bahrain. In October 1993, the SEC sent Mr. Bush's attorney a letter stating
that "the investigation has been terminated into the conduct of Mr. Bush,
and that, at this time, no enforcement
action is contemplated with respect to him."

Harken's Bahrain deal was also a piece of exceptional luck. It raised
oil-industry eyebrows when the government of that Persian Gulf state
announced it had chosen tiny Harken to
explore an offshore site for gas and oil. Harken appeared to have little to
offer the Bahrainis. It had no overseas experience and no experience with
offshore drilling. Bahrain officials
have since said they had no idea President Bush's son was associated with
Harken, a claim oil-industry sources ridicule. Former Harken exploration
chief Monte Swetnam told the New
York Times earlier this year that there "was never a question" that
Bahraini officials knew about Mr. Bush and that they "were clearly aware
that he was the President's son."

The Bahrain deal was brokered in part by Arkansas investment banker David
Edwards, one of Bill Clinton's closest friends. Formerly an employee of
Arkansas investment powerhouse
Stephens Inc., Mr. Edwards now runs his own firm in Little Rock and has
wide connections in the Middle East. At the start of President Clinton's
first term, he brokered a $23 million
Saudi contribution for a Middle East studies center at the University of
Arkansas at Fayetteville.

While Mr. Edwards was at Stephens, one of his clients was Saudi financier
Abdullah Taha Bakhsh. In 1987, soon after Mr. Bush joined Harken, Mr.
Edwards brought Mr. Bakhsh
together with the Texas firm. Harken was struggling with debt and in need
of cash. Mr. Bakhsh bought a 17% stake in the company. His American
representative, Chicago businessman
Talat Othman, was given a seat on Harken's board. By August 1990, Mr.
Othman was attending White House meetings with President Bush to discuss
Middle East policy. Mr. Bakhsh
and Mr. Othman did not respond to an interview request. But in 1995 an
attorney representing both men told the Journal that Mr. Othman's visits to
the White House were solely based
on his "longstanding involvement in Arab-American affairs."

Mr. Bakhsh also was a co-investor in Saudi Arabia with Ghaith Pharaon, a
front man for the corrupt Bank of Credit and Commerce International, which
was shut down in 1991 with
some $10 billion in losses following a global looting spree. Mr. Bakhsh's
banker in Saudi Arabia was Khalid bin Mahfouz, head of the country's
largest bank, National Commercial, and
one of the key players in the BCCI scandal. Stephens Inc. also crossed
paths with BCCI, handling an early, unsuccessful effort by figures later
identified as BCCI front men to acquire
Financial General Bankshares, a Washington, D.C., bank holding company.
Stephens withdrew from the deal, but within a few years the same group of
front men won Federal Reserve
approval to buy Financial General.

In 1992, Mr. bin Mahfouz was charged by Manhattan District Attorney Robert
Morgenthau and the Federal Reserve Board in separate actions with scheming
to conceal BCCI's role in
U.S. banking. He reached a settlement in which he paid $225 million in
fines and restitution, with the understanding that he would not again seek
a major role in U.S. banking. Mr.
Pharaon has been permanently banned from the U.S. banking industry and
fined $37 million for his role in the BCCI scandal. Mr. Bakhsh was never
charged with any wrongdoing and
his attorney told the Journal that the Saudi financier "was not involved in
any way in any of the matters or transactions that constituted the BCCI
scandal."

It wasn't long after introducing Mr. Bakhsh and his money to Harken Energy
that Mr. Edwards again surfaced with another lucrative deal. In 1988, the
government of Bahrain had
retained Houston oil consultant Michael Ameen, a former head of
governmental relations for Aramco and an old friend of Mr. Bakhsh, to
handle the search for a company to explore a
possible new oil and gas field offshore. Mr. Edwards, who by then had left
Stephens, learned of the Bahrain contract from Mr. Ameen and soon was
representing Harken with the
Bahrainis. Harken quickly beat out the big boys for the oil-exploration
franchise; Bahraini officials have explained that they were looking for a
small company that would devote full
attention to them. Mr. Edwards did not respond to an interview request.

A wide-ranging 1991 team report by Wall Street Journal reporters Thomas
Petzinger Jr., Peter Truell and Jill Abramson revealed many of the BCCI
links to Mr. Bush and Harken, but
found no evidence of improbity by anyone connected to the company. "The
mosaic of BCCI connections surrounding Harken Energy may prove nothing more
than how ubiquitous the
rogue bank's ties were," the article noted. "But the number of
BCCI-connected people who had dealings with Harken--all since George W.
Bush came on board--likewise raises the
question of whether they mask an effort to cozy up to a presidential son."

Mr. Bush told the Journal in 1994 that he had been "against the Bahrain
deal" and he had "no idea that BCCI figured into" Harken's financial
dealings. Harken officials refuse to release
any documents, such as board minutes, that might support Mr. Bush, though
two company executives have publicly stated he opposed the Bahrain
operation. The Bahrain oil project
resulted in two dry holes and Harken Energy abandoned the project. Mr. Bush
had pretty much cashed out by then, and in November 1993 he resigned from
Harken's board. He was
replaced by the well-connected Mr. Ameen.

The international oil business has produced a rich set of ties between
Saudi Arabia and Texas. To this day, Mr. bin Mafouz of National Commercial
Bank and BCCI maintains a palatial
home in Houston. He has also had a long and varied business association
with James Bath, an aircraft broker and friend of George W. Bush from their
days together in the Texas Air
National Guard. Mr. Bath invested $50,000 in Mr. Bush's first company,
Arbusto Energy. In 1978, Mr. Bath became a director of Houston's Main Bank.
Among his fellow investors
was Mr. bin Mahfouz, the Saudi banker and BCCI principal; Mr. Pharaon, the
BCCI front man; and former Treasury Secretary and Texas Gov. John Connally.
Main Bank was
absorbed into larger banks in a series of industry mergers in the 1980s.

Mr. Bath's interesting connections to Saudi Arabia go back to at least
1976. It was then, according to a report in the Houston Chronicle, that
Salem bin Laden, heir to one of the largest
building companies in the Middle East, signed a trust agreement appointing
Mr. Bath his Houston representative. (Salem bin Laden's half-brother, Osama
bin Laden, has in recent years
gained world-wide notoriety as a funder of fundamentalist terrorism, though
he has reportedly broken with his family in Saudi Arabia). Court documents
show that Mr. Bath purchased
an airfield in south Texas, Houston Gulf Airport, in 1978 on behalf of
Salem bin Laden.

Mr. bin Laden died in a plane crash near San Antonio in 1988, and his
interest in the airfield passed to Mr. bin Mahfouz, according to the
Chronicle. Mr. Bath also founded Southwest
Airport Services to manage Houston Gulf Airport and to provide fueling
service at another Houston-area airport, Ellington Field, where the company
fueled military aircraft.

Mr. Bath was as well the president of Skyway Aircraft Leasing Ltd., a
Cayman Islands-registered company that acted as a supplier of large
passenger and cargo jets. According to a court
document cited by the Houston Chronicle, and to someone familiar with
Skyway's operation who spoke recently to the Journal, the true owner was
Mr. bin Mahfouz. Mr. Bath did not
respond to requests for an interview.

Questioned by the Houston Post in 1990, Mr. Bush said he had "never done
any business" with Mr. Bath, but that Mr. Bath was "a lot of fun." Last
month, Ms. Hughes, the Bush
spokeswoman, said that other than the Arbusto investment, "Gov. Bush did
not have any other financial dealings with Mr. Bath." She said Gov. Bush
has seen Mr. Bath once or twice at
social events over the past six years.

A review of the Bush record as governor finds few traces of the past
financial connections reviewed above. The one exception might be the
January appointment of Kem Thompson
Frost, a lawyer who has represented Mr. Bath, to the Texas 14th Court of
Appeals. Ms. Frost's law firm, Winstead, Sechrest & Minick, has contributed
to Mr. Bush's gubernatorial and
presidential campaigns an amount that "exceeds $50,000," according to
Texans for Public Justice, a campaign-finance monitor. In a brief telephone
interview, Judge Frost said her work
for Mr. Bath "ended in the early 1990s." She added that she had "never met
Gov. Bush, never discussed Mr. Bath with any of his representatives, and
filled out a standard judicial
application."

If he wins the presidency, Mr. Bush would have great direct and indirect
influence over issues of more moment to his past associates--such as
relations with Saudi Arabia. Issues of law
enforcement also are particularly sensitive, as we've seen in the Clinton
administration. Mr. bin Mahfouz has never been explicitly banned from U.S.
banking, for example, and has
vigorously tried to rehabilitate his reputation--at one point enlisting the
aid of Harvard Law Prof. Laurence Tribe to write a 38-page report
denouncing BCCI prosecutors for
"scapegoating" the Saudi banker. More recently, Mr. bin Mahfouz was ousted
as head of National Commercial Bank in a murky power play reportedly
engineered by the Saudi Arabian
Monetary Agency. A family representative says Mr. bin Mahfouz then confined
himself to a military hospital for treatment of drug abuse; his wife and
sons still maintain a substantial
stake in the bank.

Any president has to balance his public duties with his inevitable private
associations. Mr. Bush has collected a rather rich assortment of
connections in his career as the son of a man
who was president, vice president and director of the Central Intelligence
Agency. His personal financial position seems secure, thanks in no small
way to friends of his father. This is of
course no disqualification from serving as president. Indeed, a charitable
voter might consider it a plus, on the assumption that the experience has
taught him some lessons and he has
learned something aboutwhen to keep a healthy distance.
[end wsj]

A brief revisiting of  bin Laudin in the Afganistan counterevolution,

>Time to use the nuclear option
>
>Thomas Woodrow
>
> The time has come for the United States to make good on its past pledges
>that it will use all military capabilities at its disposal to defend U.S.
>soil by delivering nuclear strikes against the instigators and perpetrators
>of the attacks against the nation's political capital and the nation's

>financial capital.
> At a bare minimum, tactical nuclear capabilites should be used against
>the bin Laden camps in the desert of Afghanistan. To do less would be rightly
>seen by the poisoned minds that orchestrated these attacks as cowardice on
>the part of the United States and the current administration.
> To consider use of the nation's nuclear forces, in the present
>circumstances, cannot be brushed aside as an overly emotional response to the
>unknown face of terrorism. To begin with, we know who that face belongs to,
>and we know where a goodly portion of his logistical and training
>capabilities are located. A series of low-level, tactical nuclear strikes in
>the Afghanistan desert would pose no risk to large population centers and
>would carry little risk of fallout spreading to populated areas.
> Also, our nuclear capabilities were designed to include just such a
>mission, and they are capable of fulfilling such a mission.
> Lastly, the use of nuclear weapons against the bin Laden groups and his
>supporters will rightly shock the world, but it will also shock those nations
>that have been disposed for a variety of reasons to back the terrorist groups
>with economic and political support. The United States will, in effect, have
>raised the bar against future such acts from occurring. If we, as a nation,
>show the willingness to use the ultimate weapon in the current situation,
>there can be no doubt anywhere in the globe that the United States will make
>good on its past pledges to defend its sovereign territory with such weapons.
> The attacks that occurred this week have been classified both as acts
>of war and as a second Pearl Harbor, but these designations ennoble the acts
>in Washington and New York. An act of war is constituted when one
>nation-state uses military force against another. Pearl Harbor was used by
>Japan to attack U.S. military targets to begin such an act of war. The bin
>Laden groups are not nations or states, and they have primarily targeted
>civilian populations. In fact, the use of so-called Islamic fundamentalist
>terrorism on a global scale is a new phenomena, a product of the modern age.
>In centuries past, civilized nations would conduct "punitive" expeditions
>against pirate regimes, but those actions were strictly local in scope and
>the protagonists could not approach the sophistication shown by the bin Laden
>groups. As we have seen from such "punitive" actions by the previous
>administration, those actions achieved next to nothing.
> The fight against the bin Laden groups will be a fight to the death,
>and this is another valid reason to make use of our nation's nuclear forces.
>Unlike the more limited goals of wars between nations -- territory, formal
>surrender, etc. -- bin Laden's goals are the elimination of the United States
>as the global leader for progressive political, economic and cultural change.
>Should, God forbid, the United States withdraw from the Middle East and
>Persian Gulf, the terrorists will raise their sights to eliminate our

>influence elswhere in the world. For a vision of what these groups see as
>their ultimate objective, we need look no further than the Taliban regime in
>Afghanistan, where women are beaten in the street for walking in public,
>owners of television sets are sent to prison or shot and ancient Buddhist
>monuments to universal peace and understanding are reduced to rubble.
> No, the bin Laden groups must be exterminated completely before they
>become more powerful in their efforts to exterminate us. We should use our
>nuclear capabilities to help achieve this. We must, as a nation, take the
>firmest action possible against this growing evil in the world, before its
>poison spreads even further. If not the United States, who? If not now, under
>these circumstances, when?
>
>
>Thomas Woodrow, a 22-year veteran intelligence officer, resigned from the
>Defense Intelligence Agency in May.

Houston Biz Journal
From the September 6, 1996 print edition 

Waste Control Specialists Inc.

Headquarters: Pasadena, Texas.

Joint Owners: Kenneth N. Bigham and Dallas-based Valhi Inc.

Business: Radioactive and hazardous waste processing, storage and disposal at
landfill facility under construction in West Texas.

Initial permitting, development and startup costs: $50 million.

Location: Andrews County, about 100 miles southwest of Lubbock on the New Mexico
state line.

Landfill size: A 1,338-acre site, surrounded by 15,000 acres owned by the company.

Waste capacity:

* Hazardous and toxic material -- Landfill, 11.3 million cubic yards 
(4,000 feet by 1,100 feet, and up to 70 feet deep); 
Storage, 5,000 drums and 150 bins.

* Radioactive waste: Not determined.

Permits:

* Hazardous and toxic waste processing and disposal permits, granted in 1994.

* Low-level radioactive and mixed waste processing and storage license, 
pending at Texas Department of Health.

* Radioactive waste disposal, no permit yet.

==================

Houston Biz Journal From the September 6, 1996 print edition 
Small firm sees bonanza in DOE waste 
Stakes are high in government deal to develop radioactive landfill 
Ann De Rouffignac

Waste Control Specialists Inc. of Pasadena is working on a megamillion-dollar deal
that would allow the small company to handle and dispose of federal low-level
radioactive waste at its landfill in far West Texas.

WCS has entered discussions with the U.S. Department of Energy to both process and
dispose of low-level radioactive waste from DOE's 90 sites across the country. If
the DOE agrees to send its waste to the WCS facility in Andrews County, the company
would get rich quick. WCS would have profits in the hundreds of millions of dollars
over the life of the landfill, leapfrogging to the top of a handful of U.S.
radioactive waste processing and disposal companies.

The deal would also place Texas in the league of Nevada, Utah and a few other states
with the largest nuclear waste facilities in the nation.

By focusing exclusively on the federal market, WCS would be able to bypass most
state and federal environmental agencies and capitalize on the eagerness of Andrews
County business leaders to welcome the facility to their area.

For handling and storage of nuclear waste -- even from federal sources -- the
company must be licensed by the Texas Department of Health. The WCS application is
now pending at that agency.

But it is still unclear what agency, if any, has jurisdiction over the disposal of
federal radioactive waste in Texas. The staff of the Texas Natural Resource
Conservation Commission is currently researching that question at the request of the
agency's executive director.

The stakes are huge because the DOE has an estimated cleanup bill of about $5
billion for low-level radioactive waste and twice that amount for mixed waste
(radioactive waste mixed with hazardous waste), according to a June 1996 report by
the Environmental Business Journal.

The DOE is still trying to decide whether to "centralize, regionalize or localize"
the disposal process for the low-level radioactive waste and mixed waste waiting for
a permanent home at DOE's 90 sites, says department spokeswoman Jane Brady. She
insists that the DOE "is far from making a decision yet."

The DOE declines to estimate its quantities of low-level and mixed radioactive waste
or costs associated with its disposal. But Kenneth N. Bigham, chief executive
officer and founder of WCS, is willing to estimate.

"You can talk about billions of dollars here. The federal government would go broke
disposing of all of it," he says.

As for WCS, the company's only activity is its hazardous waste storage and disposal
facility currently under construction in Andrews County. Bigham has already invested
$15 million in its development, he says.

The site has the advantage of being isolated, in the desert and on top of a thick
layer of clay that will theoretically prevent any contamination of the Ogallala
Aquifer that runs beneath it.

Although the landfill facility was originally intended for hazardous waste disposal,
that market has grown fiercely competitive as generators have successfully reduced
waste volumes. So after receiving the hazardous waste permit in 1994, Bigham
switched strategies and pursued the more lucrative and robust radioactive waste
market.

WCS then received a new capital infusion from Valhi Inc., a Dallas-based
billion-dollar conglomerate that poured in another $25 million and became a joint
owner of the facility.

Harold Simmons, a Dallas billionaire who is chief executive officer of Valhi, is
also a campaign supporter of Gov. George W. Bush. Both Simmons and Bigham have said
the governor is "aware" of the plans for federal radioactive waste in Andrews
County.

"They (Valhi) will provide whatever money we need. It's an open-ended sort of deal,"
Bigham says.

Bigham is no stranger to the waste business. In 1988, he formed Technical
Environmental Systems Inc. in the Houston area as a hazardous waste services
company. That company transported, stored and arranged for disposal of hazardous
wastes for small generators. But the company did not have a disposal permit of its
own.

Laidlaw Environmental Services bought the firm in 1991, giving Bigham what is
reported to be a handsome profit. Having failed to develop a hazardous waste
landfill in the Houston area, Bigham turned his attentions to West Texas and
radioactive waste.

NO OVERSIGHT?

Radioactive waste disposal in Texas is a sticky question. State law says that only a
state-owned public entity can dispose of nuclear waste in Texas. Texas has already
created a state agency, the Low-Level Radioactive Waste Disposal Authority, that is
the only entity allowed to dispose of radioactive waste.

The authority is currently developing a site in Hudspeth County -- also in West
Texas, about 150 miles south of the WCS site -- to receive waste from Texas
commercial generators and possibly from Maine and Vermont. But at that site, the
required TNRCC disposal permit is pending the outcome of public hearings and faces
stiff opposition from local residents.

WCS tried to change state law in the 1995 legislative session so it could also
accept commercial radioactive waste for disposal. That effort was soundly defeated
in the House.

"When we failed to change the state law, Ken Bigham got smarter and looked at
federal waste exempt from state law," says Bigham.

By seeking federal waste only, WCS claims that no state environmental agency
disposal permit is required.

"The DOE could issue an order and I could go in business tomorrow," says Bigham.

Still, he says he will only dispose of low-level radioactive waste with the state's
blessing.

WCS and "others" asked the TNRCC to look into what involvement, if any, that agency
would have in the disposal of DOE waste exclusively, says Terry Hadley, spokesman
for the TNRCC. The agency legal staff is preparing a report that is due by
mid-September.

However, state Rep. Robert Talton of Pasadena, a vocal opponent of the Andrews
County dump, insists that any reading of state law says WCS cannot dump radioactive
waste, no matter where it comes from. That law would have to be changed by the
Legislature, he says.

"They're back. I shake my head at this. It's not good as far as I'm concerned; it's
the games they play," Talton says.

By seeking only DOE nuclear waste for disposal, the WCS facility would also escape
regulation by the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission or the Environmental
Protection Agency. The DOE is self-regulated.

When the NRC became aware of WCS plans to dispose of federal low-level radioactive
waste, the agency asked its general counsel to look into the issue. The NRC
regulates high-level waste disposal and the nation's nuclear power plants.

"The WCS proposal raises some novel legal issues. The appropriate regulatory
authority for oversight of WCS' proposed activities has not been identified," states
a recent NRC newsletter.

Only if the landfill accepts some low-level radioactive waste from commercial
sources would the EPA have any right to regulate it, under provisions of the Clean
Air Act, says David Bary, spokesman for EPA's Region 6. If the facility goes for DOE
or Department of Defense waste only, then the EPA has no authority, he adds.

Andrews County business leaders have enthusiastically welcomed the disposal site as
a shot in the arm to the county's declining ranching and oil and gas based economy.
The original permit application for hazardous waste went through without resistance
from residents of nearby Andrews, the county seat, which has a population of about
14,000.

Even when Bigham sought in July to amend the hazardous waste permit and add
radioactive waste to his handling and processing plans, the amendment was supported
by the community -- especially the Andrews Industrial Foundation, which sent letters
of support. The TNRCC approved the change.

But disposal is another matter.

HEALTH QUESTIONS

After Bigham applied in March for his license from the Texas Department of Health's
Bureau of Radiation Control, the bureau responded with a five-page letter in May
detailing why the application was "severely deficient."

The company subsequently filed additional material, and the bureau has begun the
review process, says Wesley Dunn, the bureau's deputy director of licensing. A
decision is due this fall.

The health department issues licenses to all facilities in Texas that possess or
store nuclear material, no matter where that material comes from, says Dunn. The two
exceptions are federally owned facilities that have original jurisdiction and
commercial nuclear power plants regulated by the NRC.

Currently, there are only three licenses for processing of nuclear waste in Texas.
Two companies with "Type A" licenses for very small amounts of material are
reportedly closing down, says Dunn.

That leaves NSSI of Houston, which holds a "Type B" license for processing and
storage of low-level and mixed radioactive waste at its facility in northwest
Houston. That type of license allows the company to handle specific levels of
radioactivity in limited quantities.

WCS' "Type C" application, if approved, would make its new facility the largest
nuclear processing and storage facility in Texas -- and among the top in the nation.
This type of application for processing and storing low-level waste, mixed waste and
some transuranic waste, carries with it no specific limits on the amount of material
in each category, says Dunn.

"This is a very major deal -- at least a hundred times that of NSSI. We will look at
it carefully," he says.

With the unrestricted amounts of waste material allowed under a Class C permit,
Bigham says he can't estimate how much waste the company would process or store at
the Andrews facility.

"The market will dictate how much that is," says Bigham.

The DOE has accumulated a staggering amount of mixed waste stored on its sites
throughout the nation. In some facilities that do not have original jurisdiction,
the department is under pressure from the EPA to remove the mixed waste by certain
deadlines. Each facility is different, and the DOE has negotiated separate
agreements with the different states concerning what to do with the waste, says
DOE's Brady.

Clearly, more waste is being generated as the DOE continues its decommissioning of
the old nuclear weapons fuel sites. Observers agree that the federal market for
processing and disposal of low-level and especially mixed waste is huge.

Houston Biz Journal From the October 4, 1996 print edition Utah firm joins rush to
dump radioactive waste in West Texas Ann De Rouffignac

In what appears to be a modern-day land rush to dispose of radioactive waste in West
Texas, a Utah company has purchased acreage in Andrews County virtually next door to
the radioactive dump site proposed by Pasadena-based Waste Control Specialists Inc.

Envirocare of Utah bought 880 acres of Andrews County ranchland and filed a
preliminary application last week with the Texas Natural Resource Conservation
Commission seeking permission to open a radioactive disposal facility near Waste
Control's complex.

Because Andrews County has enthusiastically welcomed Waste Control's proposal to
process, store and dispose of hazardous and radioactive waste, Envirocare also
decided to set up shop there after a "countrywide search" for an appropriate site.

"We searched around the country and found what we think is the best site -- in
Andrews County, Texas," says Charles Judd, executive vice president of Envirocare of
Utah.

"The key element is public acceptance of a facility. We think we found a place where
there is local support," he says.

Envirocare's proposed facility would be competing for the same business as Waste
Control -- federally generated low-level radioactive and mixed waste from the U.S.
Department of Energy. But some experts say that market is so huge that there's room
for both companies to operate disposal facilities in the far West Texas ranching
area.

"There's tons of market -- enough for both of us," says Judd.

Most of the waste would come from out-of--state DOE facilities -- a market estimated
by industry experts to be in the billions of ollars.

Envirocare's acreage is located 23 miles west of the town of Andrews and south of
Route 176, says Judd. Waste Control's landfill is under construction about 30 miles
west of Andrews at the New Mexico border.

But Waste Control says it is not worried about the competition and dismisses
Envirocare's application to the TNRCC.

"We consider it a publicity ploy. We don't take it seriously," says Bill Miller, a
spokesman for Waste Control. "Either way you look at it, it doesn't matter to us."

Envirocare's announcement brings to three the total planned radioactive disposal
sites for West Texas. So far, none has received all the required permits to operate.

The third facility is a state-sponsored site to be located in Hudspeth County, about
150 miles southwest of the Andrews County sites. The state's Low-Level Radioactive
Waste Disposal Authority is developing the Hudspeth site, which will be officially
authorized to dispose of commercially generated radioactive waste from within Texas
-- and also from Vermont and Maine, if Congress approves.

The Hudspeth disposal permit, however, is being vigorously contested by local
residents. It is in the hearing stage before the TNRCC.

At Clive, Utah, Envirocare operates one of the only privately owned, licensed
facilities for commercial disposal of mixed waste and Class A low-level radioactive
wastes in the country. But the perceived new market is the DOE-generated "hotter"
waste (classified Class B and C) -- the type of waste also sought by Waste Control.

Envirocare sought Utah state permits to accept waste with the higher radioactivity
at its existing facility. But Utah was not receptive to the idea, leading Envirocare
to look elsewhere to expand its business, says Judd.

The Waste Control site has received strong support from business leaders in Andrews
County, who believe it would provide an economic boost, and from at least one area
legislator. But whether local community support will be enough to allow both
Envirocare and Waste Control Specialists to dispose of federal radioactive wastes in
Texas remains to be seen.

Permanent disposal of such waste by private companies in Texas is still under a
jurisdictional cloud that will be cleared up only when state authorities decide
which agency, if any, has oversight.

"We are looking at it to see if the state has any jurisdiction," says Terry Hadley,
spokesman for the TNRCC.

Meanwhile, a legal wrangle may be brewing over whether there can be any privately
owned radioactive dumps in Texas at all.

According to state Rep. Robert Talton of Pasadena, state law prohibits any entity
except the state-designated Low-Level Radioactive Waste Disposal Authority from
operating a radioactive disposal site in Texas.

Any attempt to operate a privately owned site would require state law to be changed,
he insists.

Talton worries that Texas will be opened up for radioactive waste dumping from
"everyone" if the Envirocare and Waste Control plans go through.

"We should have learned from the Superfunds that privates didn't clean up their
mess. We'll get a super mess," he says. "Who paid for it last time? Taxpayers. I
don't want taxpayers to pay again."

Talton vows he will fight any change in the law or any decision to allow dumping of
radioactive waste in Texas except by the state-designated authority.

"We'll fight this in court if necessary," he says.

Envirocare says it is seeking whatever permits may be required in an open fashion.

"Whatever they (state agencies) require, we'll do it," says Judd. "If the folks in
Texas say no, we won't insist. We'll go away."

From the November 15, 1996 print edition
HL&P opts for early replacement of STP generators
Nuclear plant repair job could cost $230 million
Ann De Rouffignac  

Houston Lighting & Power Co. has decided to replace the steam generators at
Unit 1 of its South Texas Project nuclear power plant six years ahead of
schedule.

The big repair job, estimated by industry sources to cost about $230 million,
will be done in the year 2000 during a scheduled refueling outage instead of
in 2006, utility officials confirm.

The Light Co. presented its steam generator replacement plan last month to
the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, according to NRC documents.

"The replacement is caused chiefly by economics," says John Taylor, a
spokesman for the South Texas Project plant at Bay City.

"We will have to replace them anyway. By doing it early, we avoid costly
maintenance time, additional inspections and repairs," Taylor says.

The South Texas Project's reactors are outfitted with Westinghouse steam
generators intended to last 40 years. Unit 1 went on line in 1988.

The heat transfer tubes in these particular steam generators have been
plagued with a tendency to corrode earlier than expected, leading to cracks
or even ruptures. This problem, which has been a source of costly outages and
repairs to utilities across the country, has led to 13 different lawsuits
against Westinghouse over the past several years.

HL&P filed and settled a similar lawsuit against Westinghouse in 1990, but
the terms of the settlement are sealed.

HL&P officials last week declined to say how much the steam generator
replacement will cost or to comment on whether Houston ratepayers and the
other owners of the project -- Central Power & Light Co. of Corpus Christi,
City Public Service of San Antonio and the City of Austin -- will have to pay
for this major surgery to keep the plant alive.

"The cost of the steam generator replacement can't be separated out from the
settlement agreement," says Taylor.

The company's suit against Westinghouse was settled out of court last
December, but at the request of Westinghouse its terms were sealed by court
order. Westinghouse claimed trade secrets could be violated, and the parties
to the HL&P suit agreed to the closed-door settlement.

Steam generators contain thousands of U-shaped tubes that circulate extremely
hot water heated from the core of the reactor. The heat from this radioactive
loop causes water on the non-radioactive side of the tubing to turn to steam,
providing the power to drive the turbines to generate electricity. Corrosion
of the tubes and resulting leaks require expensive downtime and repairs.

Leaks from the "hot" side of the steam generator tubes are particularly
harmful, because radioactive coolant escapes and contaminates the
non-radioactive "cool" side of the power plant. And worse than a leak is a
tube rupture, because radioactive water can flow into the secondary system at
the rate of several hundred gallons per minute, says Jim Riccio, director of
nuclear research for Public Citizen, a consumer watchdog group.

During the last major outage of the South Texas Project in 1993, when HL&P
did a complete inspection, the utility concluded that steam generator
replacement would not be needed until 2006.

However, new data from subsequent inspections suggests that the "degradation
of the tubes" will accelerate after the year 2000 and require frequent
repairs, says Ron Baker, steam generator engineer at the South Texas Project.

"With the new data, 24 percent to 25 percent of the tubes would be plugged or
sleeved by 2006," says Baker.

The idea is to replace the generators before the problems accelerate, he
explains.

HL&P says that only 5.3 percent of the tubes are forecast to be plugged or
repaired in 2000, the year of replacement. Currently, 1.3 percent are
plugged.

"Most steam generators can still operate at full power with as many as 12
percent to 15 percent of the tubes plugged," says David Schlissel, a nuclear
plant consultant with Schlissel Technical Consulting in Massachusetts. Some
plants even operate with 25 percent plugged, but then the output of the plant
must be reduced, he says.

"If you're having problems, it makes sense to move it (replacement of the
generators) forward. Otherwise, it's an economic decision," says Schlissel.

Other sources suggest that early replacement of the steam generators at South
Texas may be more about the coming of competition to the electricity market
than about degradation of the tubes. Replacing the generators early could
make ratepayers pay for any costs not covered by the settlement, and also
lessen future downtime of the plant when competition will be hitting nuclear
plants hard.

"This is all about competition coming to Texas; they want captive ratepayers
to pay for it," charges Tom Smith, director of Texas Public Citizen in
Austin.

"We think it should have to be approved by the PUC (Public Utility
Commission) to keep them from repairing a plant that is no longer
cost-effective. Study after study indicates the operation and maintenance
costs alone of STP are greater than the cost of replacement power," Smith
says.

Nothing has been filed at the PUC concerning the replacement of the steam
generators yet. But, should HL&P want to recover any of the costs from
ratepayers, the company would have to get PUC approval to do so, says Anne
Roussos, spokeswoman for the commission.

WCS pitches west Texas site to DOE

Waste Control Specialists LLC submitted a proposal to the U.S. Department of Energy

to the U.S. Department of Energy seeking authorization to use the company's Andrews
County disposal site for much of the low-level radioactive and mixed waste from
DOE's weapons complex cleanup.

If the federal department agrees to send its waste to Waste Control's facility in

WCS among the top radioactive waste processing and disposal companies in the nation.

The WCS proposal would preserve DOE's legal authority over its radioactive waste,
but an independent oversight board led by Texas Tech University would oversee the
continuing operation of the site. ================== Houston Biz Journal

From the April 11, 1997 print edition Bill would keep radioactive waste site alive
Ann De Rouffignac

An obscure clause in a pending state bill would allow the only low-level radioactive
waste dump in Texas to remain open.

Monsanto Chemical Co. has operated the waste site on the banks of Chocolate Bayou
south of Houston for more than 30 years, the last six years with an expired permit.

In 1981, the Texas Legislature changed state law and created an agency to dispose of
all low-level radioactive waste in Texas. Every waste site closed in subsequent
years except the one operated by Monsanto. But a bill now being considered by the
current Legislature would revise that law.

House Bill 1426, an omnibus act designed to upgrade the state's environmental safety
code relating to radioactive waste, contains a clause that would allow private
parties once again to operate noncommercial waste sites (all commercial sites, those
that accept outside waste, would still be overseen by the state).

Passage of the bill would directly benefit Monsanto, which has been disposing of
waste at the Chocolate Bayou plant without a valid permit since 1991.

A plant official acknowledges that the company discussed the situation with
officials of the Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission.

"We started talking to the TNRCC to see how we can continue. They said the wording
(in the state law) had to be changed," says Don Mead, safety and environmental
officer at the Chocolate Bayou plant.

"If forced to adhere to the letter of the law, the TNRCC couldn't allow us to keep
on doing this," adds Mead.

The TNRCC, in cooperation with the Bureau of Radiation Control, drafted a bill that
would alter the Health and Safety Code and bring definitions of radioactive waste
disposal, processing and handling into conformance with federal standards. H.B. 1426
was filed by Rep. Warren Chisum, chairman of the Committee on Environmental
Regulation, in late February. Rep. Chisum did not return phone calls.

The TNRCC claims that Monsanto requested insertion of the clause into the general
definitions bill; the chemical company contends that the language was drafted by the
state commission.

An environmental attorney says the bill could potentially pave the way for a new
wave of private, noncommercial radioactive waste sites in Texas.

"House Bill 1426 could open the door to the big utilities that own nuclear power
plants to dispose of the waste on their land," says David Frederick, with the firm
of Henry, Lowerre, Johnson, Hess, Frederick in Austin. "If Comanche Peak or South
Texas Project decided to dispose of the waste on site, the TNRCC could issue
permits."

Despite these concerns, officials of Houston Lighting & Power Co., operator and part
owner of South Texas Project nuclear plant, say the local utility is in no hurry to
dispose of its waste on site.

"We have no plans to develop our own disposal facility and feel strongly that the
safest method to dispose of low level waste in Texas is at one central monitored
location," says STP spokesman Alan Mikus.

Breck Henderson of the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission points out that any new
proposed waste site would still have to comply with federal regulations even if the
state law is changed.

While Monsanto currently operates the only active low-level radioactive waste site
in Texas, three other entities shut down similar facilities.

The permits were issued by the Bureau of Radiation Control of the Department of
Health in the early 1960s and mid-'70s.

Iso-Tex of Friendswood still produces pharmaceuticals but discontinued the practice
of radioactive waste disposal several years ago, says Alice Rogers of the TNRCC.

Textin of Texas City is no longer in operation and is currently being considered by
the Environmental Protection Agency as a Superfund site, Rogers says.

Texas A&M University discontinued the practice in 1978, says Chris Meyer, radiation
safety officer at the university.

Permits for these three sites expired between 1991 and 1995, after the state law was
changed in 1989 to eliminate existing private waste sites.

Monsanto's license to dispose of radioactive waste was originally issued in 1963 and
expired in 1991.

TNRCC spokesman Patrick Shaughnessy says Monsanto is eligible for permit renewal
because the chemical company acted in a "timely manner" in seeking approval.

"They (Monsanto) can continue to operate as long as they apply for a renewal in a
timely manner," says Shaughnessy. "Since they applied in a timely manner, they are
operating. We are operating as if their license didn't expire."

Monsanto says it has no place to put the waste.

"It's a right-to-operate issue for us," says Monsanto's Mead. "There's no place in
existence that will take this specific waste."

The TNRCC's Rogers concurs.

"They have concentrations (of radioactivity) not allowed at Envirocare," she says.

Under current law, companies outside of the Pacific Northwest have only two
facilities where they can send low-level radioactive waste for disposal -- the
Envirocare site in Utah and the Chemical Nuclear Systems Inc. site in Barnwell, S.C.

Both Envirocare and Barnwell won't accept the waste generated by Monsanto at the
Chocolate Bayou plant, says Mead.

Radioactive and other hazardous waste is generated at the Chocolate Bayou plant,
which produces acrylonitrile, a primary component of acrylic fibers, plastics and
plastic piping.

The radioactive waste results from a spent uranium catalyst used in the production
process.

"It's a proprietary catalyst that has a radioactive element to it," says Monsanto's
Mead. "We're the only ones that use this one. It gives us a competitive edge."

The TNRCC has given a clean bill of health in the past to the Chocolate Bayou plant
site.

"We used to monitor the site until last year. We quit doing the monitoring because
of a budget cut. And we didn't find anything, anyway," says Rogers.

Monsanto won't disclose how much waste has been disposed of over the years, how much
is placed there annually, or the method of disposal.

"It (a discussion about the site) makes an issue out of a nonissue," Mead contends.
"We've been doing this for 30 years under auspices of the regulatory agencies. We're
not interested in getting into a media debate."

================== Houston Biz Journal

From the June 6, 1997 print edition Firm files lawsuit in dispute over radioactive
waste site Ann De Rouffignac

Waste Control Specialists Inc. has filed a $1 billion lawsuit in Andrews County
against Envirocare of Texas. The suit claims Envirocare interfered with WCS's
request to operate a low-level radioactive waste disposal site in West Texas.

The litigation comes on the heels of the U.S. Department of Energy's rejection of a
proposal from WCS for authorization of a low-level and mixed radioactive waste dump
planned for Andrews County.

Pasadena-based WCS had pinned its hopes for huge profits from the DOE's
multibillion-dollar disposal business. (See "Small firm sees bonanza in DOE waste,"
Sept. 6, 1996.)

The federal agency is in the midst of cleaning up nuclear weapons production sites
around the country, generating as much as 50 million cubic yards of mixed and
low-level waste. WCS formally submitted the dump proposal to DOE late last year.

The suit alleges that Envirocare has committed antitrust violations by taking steps
to maintain its monopoly position in the disposal of mixed waste. Envirocare has the
only mixed waste disposal site in the country, the petition asserts.

WCS alleges that Envirocare interfered with the local company's ability to get a
permit with the Department of Health in Texas to store and treat radioactive wastes.

The application requires that a disposal site be named for any waste treated and
stored. So WCS named Envirocare's site in Utah on the application. But WCS alleges
that Envirocare officials told state officials they would not allow WCS to use the
facility -- thus interfering with the firm's ability to do business as a competitor.

The Texas Department of Health, however, will issue a favorable draft decision to
grant WCS a license next week, says Ruth McBurney of the Bureau of Radiation
Control.

The suit also alleges that Envirocare publicized defamatory statements about WCS to
Texas and federal officials, other businesses and the media. The communications were
intended to "injure the reputation and standing of WCS," and prevented government
officials and business leaders from dealing with WCS, the petition states.

"Envirocare spread false and misleading information about us. We are proceeding with
the lawsuit," says Joseph Egan, attorney for WCS.

Envirocare denies all allegations and will fight the lawsuit, says Charles Judd,
president of Envirocare.

"What we have here is a company that failed to gain approval for low-level and mixed
waste disposal, and now wants to blame another company for its own failures," says
Judd.

At the center of the dispute between the two companies is Envirocare's efforts to
establish its own mixed waste and low-level radioactive treatment and disposal site
for federal wastes.

Envirocare purchased land in Andrews County last fall and submitted applications for
permits and licenses to state authorities.

But Envirocare's application for disposal to the Texas Natural Resource Conservation
Commission was not processed and returned. The TNRCC said it had no authority to
authorize or regulate a disposal site that accepted federal wastes. The state agency
also said that such a site "under any scenario or arrangement would not be in the
best interests of the state of Texas," according to a letter to Envirocare from Dan
Pearson, executive director of the TNRCC.

In response to the TNRCC decision, Envirocare dropped the disposal part of its
business plan and proceeded with its other permits required to treat and process
federal waste at its Andrews County site, Judd says.

In its petition, WCS calls the Envirocare facility in West Texas a "sham" expressly
undertaken to impose expense, delay and interference on the business activities of
WCS.

================== Houston Biz Journal

From the November 14, 1997 print edition Waste firm wins round against DOE Federal
ruling aids local company, upsets state legislators, stirs up industry Ann De
Rouffignac   Houston Business Journal

A small Houston waste company is taking on the U.S. Department of Energy in a legal
battle that could have a major impact on the disposal of low-level radioactive waste
throughout the country.

Pasadena-based Waste Control Specialists Inc. sued the DOE in August, claiming that
the company was unfairly shut out of the competitive bidding process on lucrative
government contracts.

WCS, operator of a hazardous waste site in West Texas, cleared a big legal hurdle
last month when a federal judge ruled that the DOE has the right under the Atomic
Energy Act to put low-level radioactive waste wherever the agency chooses, without a
license from the state.

In addition to aiding the company's cause, the ruling by Judge Joe Kendall of U.S.
District Court in Wichita Falls has stirred up controversy within the waste industry
and among state politicians.

While the DOE has traditionally worked with states concerning the disposal of waste,
the new ruling reinforces the federal agency's right to bypass state authorities in
setting up new low-level radioactive waste sites.

"As it stands now, states cannot license or refuse to license nuclear disposal
facilities for federal waste, and that could open up the entire country," says
Richard Ratliffe, head of the Bureau of Radiation Control for the Texas Department
of Health.

Texas state legislators are not happy about the ruling that could clear the way for
the disposal of DOE waste at the WCS site in West Texas.

"I would strongly oppose placing DOE waste there," says State Rep. Mike Jackson of
Houston, who is vice chairman of the state's legislative Committee on Environmental
Regulation.

"I think that would set a pitiful example for our federal government to do that,"
says Jackson.

Rep. Robert Talton of Pasadena, also a member of the state's environmental
committee, says the state's welfare should be placed before that of the DOE and an
individual company.

"We don't think a federal judge should be interfering or trying to force a federal
agency to do what it usually doesn't," says Talton. "We, as a state, should make
sure that people don't do things for greed and money. They should do the right thing
for Texas."

The Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission (TNRCC) is also concerned about
the ramifications of the ruling.

"This does not mean we can't have any influence. We won't just stand idly by
regardless of how it is interpreted. We disagree strongly with that. We don't expect
to be shut out of this process and will not rule out any future legal actions,"
warns TNRCC spokesman Patrick Crimmins.

Reaction from the Governor's office is more mild.

"Texas has no role in any decision that the DOE would make -- it is out of our
hands," says Debbie Head, spokeswoman for Governor George W. Bush.

While the stakes are high for Texas, they could be even higher for WCS.

The local company 50-percent owned by Valhi Inc., a publicly held conglomerate
controlled by Dallas billionaire Harold Simmons, has been attempting for years to
get a share of the multibillion-dollar waste disposal business.

In 1995, WCS attempted to push through legislation that would change state law and
allow private companies to dispose of commercial radioactive waste in Texas, which
is currently forbidden under the Health and Safety Code of Texas.

When that effort failed, WCS changed course and began seeking federal radioactive
waste.

"When we failed to change the state law, we got smarter and looked at federal waste
exempt from state law," said Kenneth Bigham, chief executive officer of WCS, in a
previous interview with Houston Business Journal (see "Small firm seeks bonanza in
DOE waste," Sept. 6, 1996).

In December of 1996, the TNRCC rejected a request by WCS to regulate the West Texas
facility for the disposal of federal waste, claiming that Texas statutes prohibit
the agency from licensing or overseeing a private company that disposes of
radioactive waste, no matter what the source.

WCS then shifted gears and went directly to the DOE by submitting an unsolicited
proposal in late December of 1996. The proposal "sought DOE authorization of its
Texas facility as a disposal site for waste from DOE's stalled weapons complex clean
up," according to a company press release.

After rejecting this proposal in May, the DOE refused to consider a bid by WCS to
dispose of low-level radioactive waste from Ohio at the company's West Texas
facility, claiming that WCS did not have a site licensed by the state to handle such
waste.

WCS responded by filing a lawsuit in federal court seeking a preliminary injunction
to prohibit the DOE from awarding any contracts. WCS argued that a state license is
not required for disposal of federal radioactive waste under the Atomic Energy Act.

Judge Kendall agreed and also questioned the federal bidding process in his report,
writing that "the fix is in." Apparently, Envirocare of Utah Inc. (also the target
of a WCS lawsuit; see chronological chart on Page 18) is the only private company
ever to receive a contract from the DOE to dispose of low-level radioactive waste.

A lawyer for WCS says the judge's decision gives the company new life.

"The ruling means that we are back in business for DOE disposal contracts; we have a
site that's well suited for radioactive waste," says attorney John Kyte with Egan &
Associates of Washington D.C. "What we want is competition for those wastes that DOE
ships off-site to commercial facilities."

The ruling has become a matter of debate in the trade media.

Nuclear Waste News ran a story concerning the case on Oct. 17, which was followed by
an article in Hazardous Waste News three days later.

Even Investors Business Daily editorialized on the subject of WCS and the DOE
radioactive waste contracts on Oct. 15. The publication noted that the issue means
big business for the waste industry because "the job of cleaning up Energy
Department facilities used to produce nuclear weapons in the Cold War has been
priced at hundreds of billions of dollars."

In a hearing on the WCS lawsuit, former DOE official Martin Malsch testified that
the total cost of federal radioactive waste disposal could reach $1 trillion over
the next 10 to 15 years.

Environmentalists in and out of Texas have been following the issue closely.

"The ruling says very clearly that the state has little to say about where these
sites are," says Tom "Smitty" Smith, director of Texas Public Citizen, a consumer
and environmental watchdog group.

Even groups in New Mexico have been paying close attention.

"Texans should be concerned about a lot of waste coming in from other parts of the
country," says Don Hancock, director of Southwest Research & Information Center, a
nonprofit environmental research organization in Albuquerque. "This is a growth
industry, and private companies will want to get in on it. Anyone who can will. And
Texas looks pretty good."

So far, the DOE has remained silent on the ruling.

The agency has not appealed or filed anything other than an answer in response to
the WCS suit. A pretrial hearing is scheduled for the end of November.

But government officials say it's now possible that the DOE may change past policy
and wield more power in the future.

"A year ago, they (DOE) would have looked at states where they could seek a path of
least resistance. But now it's possible DOE might seek as yet unknown places and use
its authority under the AEA (Atomic Energy Act) to self-regulate," says Dwayne
Weigel, assistant director of civilian and DOE waste management at the General
Accounting Office.

Whatever the eventual outcome, the small Houston company has succeeded in attracting
national attention.

"A year ago, nobody was talking about the WCS situation," says Weigel. "Now, this
same situation is causing issues to emerge concerning what is the authority of the
DOE under the Atomic Energy Act anyway?"

Warning of Excess Capacity In Nation's Nuclear Dumps. The New York
Times,
December 7,
1997, pA36.
     Some planned nuclear waste disposal sites may be unnecessary and
could
sink the
industry, according to an economist.
     The nation's three current dumps for low-level radiation will
have
excess capacity well
into the next century, said Gregory Hayden, a professor at the
University
of Nebraska.
     A new dump, such as the Ward Valley project in southeastern
California
could  mean the
end for the economically struggling disposal sites, Hayden said.
     "If it's opened, it will break the system that the rest of the
nation
depends on," said
Hayden. "They're already in trouble because of the trickle of waste."
     In a report last month at the National Conference of State
Legislatures, Hayden presented
a report that said that the annual volume of low-level waste shipped
to
disposal sites dropped
from 3.8 million cubic feet in 1980 to 422,000 cubic feet in 1996.
     Hayden attributed the excess capacity to waste reduction via
recycling
and new
compacting technologies.

================== Houston Biz Journal From the April 3, 1998 print edition Attorney
general takes action in radioactive waste dispute State challenges federal court
ruling on DOE disposal process Ann De Rouffignac   Houston Business Journal

The state Attorney General has finally intervened in a two-year-old dispute between
a Houston company and the U.S. Department of Energy over the disposal of radioactive
waste at a site in West Texas.

In a filing last week with the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals in New Orleans, the
Attorney General's office argued that the DOE should not be allowed to evade state
jurisdiction in the disposal of radioactive waste at privately owned sites.

Pasadena-based Waste Control Specialists Inc. is seeking a way to dispose of DOE
waste at the company's Andrews County site without a state license or a permit. The
DOE would not allow the company to bid on contracts without a state-licensed
radioactive disposal site.

Waste Control sued the DOE in a federal district court in Wichita Falls last fall,
saying the company was unfairly excluded from the bidding process. The district
court ruled in the company's favor. (See "Waste firm wins round against DOE" Nov.
14, 1997).

DOE appealed the ruling and the case is now pending in federal appeals court.

email news alerts email Sign up to receive free daily business updates by email
every weekday afternoon.

email Use Search Watch to watch for related topics, companies.

email Receive free Industry News via email. Choose from 46 different industries.

The stakes are huge for the small waste company. The DOE has billions of dollars of
low-level and mixed radioactive waste at facilities throughout the nation. The
agency is under the gun to clean up these sites and dispose of millions of tons of
waste.

Waste Control already has state and federal permits to dispose of industrial
hazardous waste at the company's West Texas site and has also obtained a state
health permit required to process and treat radioactive waste at its facilities in
Andrews County. The only missing link is authorization to dispose of federal
radioactive waste on a permanent basis.

The federal district court ruling put Waste Control one step closer to obtaining DOE
contracts for disposal of radioactive waste in Texas. The ruling, if upheld, would
allow the company to bypass the state permitting process and compete for federal
contracts to dispose of waste in West Texas.

Until now, state officials have remained neutral in the dispute despite the fact
that the waste would end up in Texas and could allow other private sites to operate
without state permits.

The Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission, the state agency in charge of
protecting the environment, has claimed it has no jurisdiction in granting or
denying any license involving the disposal of federal radioactive waste.

Meanwhile, the lower court ruling in Wichita Falls has attracted considerable
attention in other states.

Congressional delegations from Washington and Oregon wrote to the DOE last month,
citing the Waste Control case and the profound implications that this ruling could
have on national radioactive waste practices. These members of Congress were
unanimous in urging that the ruling be overturned.

Attorney general offices in 16 other states filed briefs in New Orleans circuit
court challenging the ruling before Texas followed suit last week.

In a 21-page document submitted to the court, Texas Attorney general Dan Morales
summed up the state's position by stating:

"Sound public policy dictates that the DOE not be allowed to evade state
jurisdiction under the guise of self-regulation while disposing of its radioactive
waste at privately owned and operated waste disposal facilities. Public policy
requires that all wastes generated by DOE be subject to independent oversight and
enforcement preferably by qualified state regulatory agencies."

================== Houston Biz Journal

From the May 22, 1998 print edition Houson firm loses legal round in federal waste
disposal fight Court reverses earlier decision, WCS will seek rehearing Ann De
Rouffignac   Houston Business Journal

Waste Control Specialists Inc. has lost a legal round in federal appeals court that
could have paved the way for the Pasadena company to dispose of low-level
radioactive waste in West Texas without state approval.

Last week, the United States Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals in New Orleans reversed
and dismissed a federal district court decision handed down in Wichita Falls last
fall that would allow WCS to bid for radioactive waste disposal contracts from the
U.S. Department of Energy without having a state-approved disposal site.

"We will seek a rehearing in the Fifth Circuit within the legal time limit," says
John Kyte, attorney for WCS. "This is not the end by any means. We are in this for
the long haul."

WCS has been battling for more than two years to get the billion-dollar business of
disposing of federal low-level radioactive waste at the company's site in Andrews
County. The existing waste site has state and federal licenses to dispose of
hazardous and non-hazardous waste. The company also received a state permit to treat
and handle huge volumes of radioactive waste at the site, but not to dispose of the
waste.

WCS sued the DOE in federal court seeking to stop the federal agency from granting
waste disposal contracts to other companies without allowing WCS to bid. The company
alleged that the DOE was unfairly denying its right to bid because it didn't have
state approval for disposing of waste in Andrews County.

WCS argued that it didn't need state approval or regulation to accept DOE waste.
Federal law allows the DOE to choose any site it deems appropriate for such disposal
without state involvement. In the past, however, the DOE has always sought state
cooperation in the disposal of low-level radioactive waste.

After the Wichita Falls judge granted the injunction, the DOE appealed the case to
the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit in New Orleans.

State attorney generals from 16 states, including Texas, filed briefs in the New
Orleans court in March challenging the Wichita Falls district court ruling.

Although these briefs were not accepted by the court, the circuit judges reversed
the injunction and and ordered the lawsuit filed by WCS against the DOE dismissed.

Houston Biz Journal From the March 5, 1999 print edition Nuclear plants contract
with WCS to store waste at West Texas site Agreement with STP, Texas Utilities
awaits approval of Legislature Ann De Rouffignac

The South Texas Project and Texas Utilities signed a contract last month with Waste
Control Specialists of Pasadena to dispose of low level radioactive waste at a site
in West Texas.

Waste Control's agreement with the STP and TU, which owns the Comanche Peak nuclear
plant, offers a huge discount to the nuclear plants, which have been sending their
waste to Barnwell in South Carolina, the only other facility that can accept it.
Waste Control will sell disposal services to the nuclear plants for an all-inclusive
price of $40 per cubic foot, says John Kyte, the company's attorney. The facility at
Barnwell now charges about $350 to $400 a cubic foot for disposal, depending on the
type of waste.

Before the contract is effective, the Texas Legislature must pass a bill clearing
the way for Waste Control's dump.

Although Kyte says WCS can make a profit at the $40 price, others say the company
must get more volume of waste from out-of-state to make a decent rate of return on
the $50 million investment in the Andrews County site.

WCS is still trying to import Department of Energy radioactive waste for processing
and disposal at the Andrews County site, and the potential profit in disposing of
that waste is enormous. Industry sources value that agency's disposal costs in the
billions of dollars.

So far, however, WCS has been unable to land any DOE contracts because the company
did not have a disposal permit for low level radioactive waste from the Texas
Natural Resource Conservation Commission. Under the State Health and Safety Code,
radioactive waste in Texas can only be disposed of in the proposed state-owned site
in Hudspeth County.

Now an effort in the Legislature would turn over the disposal of the waste to
private enterprise. Sponsored by Rep. Pete Gallego of Alpine, the bill changes the
code to allow a private company to dispose of the waste and removes Hudspeth County
as the official site.

The bill also calls for the state to take title to the waste and the site. Opponents
of the bill say that gives all the profits to a private company and leaves taxpayers
responsible for any environmental or health problems down the line.
Environmentalists also say the legislation would clear the way for Andrews County to
become a national dumping ground for radioactive waste.

Kyte says WCS is solving a problem for the nuclear plants in Texas.

"It gets the job done and solves a problem. Barnwell is exorbitantly high-priced,"
he says.
