AAS Tues 4-15-2003

Japanese Utility Shuts Down Nuclear Grid

By ERIC TALMADGE Associated Press Writer

TOKYO (AP)--Staggered by a series of scandals, Tokyo's main power company
shut down the last of its 17 nuclear reactors for safety checks Tuesday,
meaning Japan's capital may soon face its first blackouts in nearly two
decades.

Tokyo Electric Power Co. took the final reactor offline at midnight, said
company spokesman Mamoru Shirakashi. Operations at the 16 other reactors
run by the company, known as TEPCO, already have been halted.

The closures represent an unprecedented crisis in Japan's power industry.

Though a system glitch left some 3 million people in Tokyo without power in
1987, TEPCO--the world's largest electric utility _ says the city has never
faced blackouts due to a shortfall in supply.

Senior government officials were quick to voice their concern.

"Unless we can restart the facilities whose operations are halted now, we
will inevitably face power shortages," said Yasuo Fukuda, the top
spokesman for Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's Cabinet.

"The government will do all it can," he said. But he did not offer any
suggestions on what the government could do.

To break its heavy reliance on imported oil, resource-poor Japan has long
pursued an ambitious nuclear power program. The country today gets about 30
percent of all its energy from nuclear reactors.

The industry has been plagued by accidents and coverups of lax safety
practices, however.

TEPCO was ordered to suspend operations for a thorough safety review after
it admitted last year to covering up structural problems and obstructing
government inspections at its reactors a decade ago.

The admissions only deepened concerns raised in 1999 by Japan's worst-ever
nuclear accident, when an uncontrolled reaction at a fuel-reprocessing
plant north of Tokyo killed two workers--later found to have been illegally
mixing uranium in buckets--and exposed at least 600 people to radiation.

No date has been set for restarting TEPCO's nuclear reactors.

That will depend on how long it takes to complete the safety checks and
"earn the public's understanding," spokesman Shirakashi said.

In the meantime, TEPCO plans to compensate for the shutdown, which accounts
for about 40 percent of the electricity consumed by Tokyo and its
surrounding areas, by reactivating five thermal power plants and purchasing
surplus electricity from other power companies.

Even so, it forecasts a shortfall of 9.5 million kilowatts--the equivalent
of the output from 10 nuclear reactors--when air conditioner use peaks in
Japan's sweaty summer months.

April 18, 2003, 4:00PM
A unit of nuclear plant is shut down
By MICHAEL DAVIS
Houston Chronicle

Unit 1 of the South Texas Project nuclear plant near Bay City is shut down
indefinitely after some residue from reactor coolant fluid was found on
tubes near the bottom of the reactor, plant officials said Friday.

Bay City is about 50 miles southwest of Houston.

Theradioactive boric acid residue -- described by the company as about the
size of one-half of an aspirin -- was discovered a week ago when the unit
was shut down for scheduled refueling and maintenance The water flowing
through the reactor to cool it contains boric acid.

The powdery material was located on the outside of two instrument guide
tubes where they enter the bottom of the reactor vessel. These contain
instruments that measure reactor operations.

"We found two very minor indications of a slight seepage at the bottom of
the reactor vessel and are in the process of determining the root cause and
to fix it," said Ed Halpin, plant manager for STP. "Unit 1 will not be
returned to service until the problem is solved."

Halpin could not say how long the repairs will take, but added that it will
not have any effect on power consumers.

STP officials are working with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which
will review any plan for corrective action before it is put into place.

"The unit is shut down and there is no danger to the public," said Victor
Dricks, spokesman for the NRC in Fort Worth. "We have been impressed with
the aggressive response of the licensee and are closely monitoring the
situation."

While the seepage discovered was minor, gone unchecked it could have led to
very serious problems, said Jim Riccio, nuclear policy analyst with
Greenpeace in Washington, D.C.

"The real concern here is that if they had not found the leak, the crack
could have grown large enough that they could not have made up the coolant
loss," Riccio said. "You lose enough coolant, you melt the radioactive fuel
rods in the core.

Early indications are that the seepage may have come from a weld where the
tube enters the bottom of the reactor, Riccio said. He attended an NRC
conference in Washington earlier this week at which initial information on
the discovery of the seepage was disclosed.

"It stirred a few people up," Riccio said.

The NRC has been advising nuclear plants using Westinghouse reactors -- as
STP does -- about so called "thimble tube thinning," for 15 years,
according to an agency bulletin on the problem dated July 26, 1988. Thimble
tubes run inside of the incore guide tubes where the residue was found.

"Wear of the thimble tubes results in degradation of the reactor coolant
system's pressure boundary and can also create a potentially non-isolable
leak of reactor coolant," according to the bulletin.

Unit 2 at the plant just south of Bay City is running normally. Each unit
has the capacity to produce 1,250 megawatts of electricity. The reactor
vessel is housed inside the concrete and steel-lined containment building.

In the meantime, the plant has a team of engineers who have re-examined all
of the instrument guide tubes, and no additional residue was found, the
company said.

In November of last year, Unit 1 had an unscheduled outage after operators
noticed some problems with the secondary cooling system, Halpin said. The
reactor was shut down manually.

The plant was plagued with problems a decade ago. It was shut down for most
of 1993 by the NRC and a new management team was brought in by Houston
Industries, the operator at the time.

Now, the plant is managed by the STP Nuclear Operating Co. It is owned by
AEP Texas Central Co., Austin Energy, City Public Service of San Antonio
and Texas Genco.

Posted on Sat, Apr. 19, 2003   
 
S. Texas nuclear plant has water leak
By Matthew L. Wald
The New York Times

WASHINGTON -A nuclear reactor in South Texas is leaking cooling water from 
the bottom of its giant reactor vessel, a development that experts view with 
concern because they have never seen it before at any plant, the Nuclear 
Regulatory Commission said Friday.

Technicians at the South Texas Project Electric Generating Station, about 90 
miles southwest of Houston, found residues during refueling at one of two 
nuclear reactors, indicating that cooling water leaked at two places where 
instrument-carrying tubes enter the reactor core, according to the company 
that operates the plant.

No similar problems have been observed at TXU's Comanche Peak nuclear power 
plant near Glen Rose, company and NRC officials said.

Both of the nuclear power plants in Texas are pressurized water reactors and 
of similar designs.

Operators at all 103 commercial nuclear reactors in the United States have 
been giving closer attention to their reactor vessels since the discovery 
last year of extensive leaks in the vessel head at another plant, Davis-
Besse, near Toledo, Ohio.

The Texas plant, South Texas 1, shows much smaller signs of leaking than the 
Ohio plant. In both cases, technicians found deposits of boron, a chemical 
added to the water to control the nuclear reaction. The chemical remains 
after the water evaporates. At Davis-Besse, technicians cleaned out boron 
with shovels; in Texas, technicians found an amount about half the volume of 
an aspirin tablet, said Ed Halpin, the plant general manager.

No corrosion is visible, but no one is sure what is under the vessel. At 
Davis-Besse, the steel of the vessel was corroded. At that plant, which began 
operating in 1976, workers have replaced the vessel head, a part that was 
intended to last for the lifetime of the reactor. Davis-Besse has remained 
closed since the leak was discovered, 13 months ago.

The South Texas leak is unexpected and, so far, unexplained.

"This is the first time it's been seen, either here or abroad," said Victor 
Dricks, a spokesman for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

Representatives of two national nuclear industry groups are at the plant to 
study the problem, and plant managers have promised to keep the reactor shut 
down until they find the cause and repair it to the NRC's satisfaction, 
Dricks said. The plant is now shut down for refueling.

The vessel is 14.4 feet wide and 46 feet high, made of steel about 6 inches 
thick. Its bottom has 58 points where instruments can be inserted to measure 
the flow of neutrons, the subatomic particles that sustain the chain 
reaction. There are deposits at two of the insertion points, although the 
volume of the deposits was apparently small, Dricks said.

"It suggests there may be a leak," Dricks said Friday. "It's possible there 
is a crack in the weld between the bottom-mounted instrument tube and the 
reactor vessel or along the length of the tube. We don't know if there is 
damage inside the reactor vessel. We have no reason to believe there is."

TXU's plant is operating at full power, said Rand LaVonn, TXU spokesman.

"Comanche Peak officials, like others in the industry, will be watching this 
develop because safety is our highest priority," LaVonn said.

At nuclear power plants around the country, cracks of some metal parts have 
been traced to stresses created during construction. Others have been caused 
by a phenomenon called intergranular stress corrosion cracking, which occurs 
in some metals when they are under stress at high temperature. But Halpin 
said he would not speculate about the cause of the boron deposits.

Water inside the vessel is at a temperature of more than 500 degrees and a 
pressure of more than 2,000 pounds per square inch, so even a small hole 
could release large volumes of radioactive water into a containment building. 
Dricks said, however, that the pumps in the plant's cooling system could 
inject water into the reactor faster than it could leak out through a small 
hole, so that the nuclear core would stay covered, preventing a meltdown.

A problem in making repairs is that the irradiation under the reactor is 
about 500 millirem per hour, Halpin said. At that rate, a worker would absorb 
in four hours the radiation dose that most reactor operators set as a limit 
for a full year. The repair work is usually completed by large teams of 
workers, each spending only a short period exposed to the radiation.

South Texas 1 is one of the newest plants in the country. It began operation 
in August 1988. South Texas 2, which is adjacent, followed in June 1989. It 
shows no sign of leakage. The two reactors are owned jointly by the cities of 
Austin and San Antonio, a subsidiary of American Electric Power, and Texas 
Genco LP, a generating company. The plant is operated by STP Nuclear 
Operating Co.

 NYTimes (this was in the paper the 19th)
 April 18th 2003
 Texas Reactor Vessel Is Leaking Water
By MATTHEW L. WALD

WASHINGTON, April 18 -  A nuclear reactor in Texas is leaking cooling water
from the bottom of its giant reactor vessel, a development that experts
view with concern because they have never seen it before, the Nuclear
Regulatory Commission said today.

Technicians at the South Texas Nuclear Project, 90 miles southwest of
Houston near Wadsworth, have found residues that indicate that cooling
water leaked from the vessel through two penetrations where instruments are
inserted into the core, according to the plant operator.

Operators at all 103 commercial nuclear reactors have been giving closer
attention to their reactor vessels since the discovery last year of
extensive leaks in the vessel head at the Davis-Besse plant in Oak Harbor,
Ohio, near Toledo.

The Texas plant, South Texas 1, shows much smaller signs of leaking than
the Ohio plant. In both cases, technicians found deposits of boron, a
chemical added to the water to control the nuclear reaction, which remains
after the water evaporates.

At Davis-Besse, technicians cleaned out boron with shovels. In Texas,
technicians found an amount about half the volume of an aspirin tablet,
said Ed Halpin, the plant general manager.

No corrosion is visible, but no one is sure what is underneath. At
Davis-Besse, the steel of the vessel was so corroded that a metal part on
the head flopped over like a mailbox post that has been loosened from the
front lawn. Workers have replaced the vessel head, a part intended to last
for the lifetime of the reactor. Davis-Besse has remained closed since the
leak was discovered, 13 months ago.

South Texas 1 is one of the youngest plants in the country. It went on line
in August 1988. South Texas 2, which is adjacent, followed in June 1989. It
shows no sign of leakage.

The two reactors are owned by the Cities of Austin and San Antonio, a
subsidiary of American Electric Power of Columbus, Ohio, and Texas Genco, a
generating company that is a subsidiary of CenterPoint Energy of Houston.

The South Texas leak is unexpected and, so far, unexplained.

"This is the first time it's been seen, either here or abroad," said Victor
Dricks, a spokesman for the regulatory commission.

Representatives of two industry groups are at the plant to study the
problem, and managers have promised to keep the reactor, which is closed
for refueling, out of operation until they find the cause and repair it to
the satisfaction of the nuclear agency, Mr. Dricks said.

The vessel is 14.4 feet wide and 46 feet high, made of steel about six
inches thick. Its bottom has 58 penetrations, where instruments can be
inserted to measure the flow of neutrons, the subatomic particles that
sustain the chain reaction. There are leaks at two penetrations, although
the water volume was apparently small, Mr. Dricks said.

At plants around the country, cracks of some metal parts have been traced
to stresses created in construction. Others have been caused by a
phenomenon called intergranular stress corrosion cracking that occurs in
some metals under stress at high temperature. Mr. Halpin said he would not
speculate about the cause in Texas.

Water in the vessel is at a temperature higher than 500 degrees and
pressure higher than 2,000 pounds a square inch. So even a small hole could
release large volumes of radioactive water into the containment building.

Mr. Dricks said, however, that the pumps in the emergency core cooling
system could inject water faster than it could leak through a hole the size
of the penetration, so that the nuclear core would stay covered. The design
is for contamination in such cases to stay in the containment dome.

A repair problem is that the radiation field under the reactor is about 500
millirem an hour, Mr. Halpin said. At that rate, a worker would absorb in
four hours the radiation dose that most reactor operators set as a limit
for a full year. Repair work in such high fields is usually carried out by
large teams of workers, each spending just a short period at work.

AAS 
Residue keeps nuclear unit shut down
FROM STAFF AND WIRE REPORTS
Saturday, April 19, 2003

WADSWORTH -- Engineers at the nuclear plant near Bay City are examining
residue about half the size of an aspirin that was found April 12 while one
of the plant's reactors was shut down for refueling and maintenance,
representatives for the South Texas Project Electric Generating Station
said Friday.

The powdery material was found on the outside of two instrument guide tubes
where the tubes enter the bottom of the reactor, the plant representatives
said. The reactor, which is partly owned by the City of Austin, is encased
in a concrete and steel-lined containment building.

Tests indicate the residue came from reactor coolant fluid, plant officials
said.

"Finding this minute amount of residue demonstrates our inspection process
works," said Ed Halpin, the plant's general manager.

Officials with Austin Energy said the reactor problem won't affect their
delivery of electricity. But if the unit remains shut down for several
months, it could mean higher electric bills for customers.

Because the downed unit is taking 200 megawatts away from Austin Energy,
the utility will have to make up for it by burning costlier natural gas,
said Ed Clark, the utility's spokesman. Consumer bills will be noticeably
higher only if the loss continues into the hottest part of the summer. One
megawatt is enough to power 200 homes.

The plant said it is working with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to
review the needed corrective actions. The plant said a team of engineers
and chemists has reviewed all of the instrument guide tubes and found no
additional residue.

"Our priorities are to determine the cause of the problem and make sure our
corrective actions are effective," Halpin said, adding that the unit will
remain out of service until the problem is fixed.

The plant's other unit is operating at full power. The two reactors combine
to produce more than 2,500 megawatts for customers from Houston to Austin
and San Antonio to Corpus Christi.

New York Times
Extraordinary Reactor Leak Gets the Industry's Attention
By MATTHEW L. WALD

WADSWORTH, Tex., April 30 - Reactor experts around the country hope that
there is something unique about Reactor No. 1 at the South Texas Project
here. If not, the little crust of white powder that technicians found at the
bottom of the reactor vessel, a discovery that has brought operations here
to a halt for the indefinite future, could be the beginning of a broad
problem for the nuclear power industry.

The powder, which managers here repeatedly compare in volume to about half
an aspirin tablet, is boric acid, which is used in reactor cooling water to
soak up excess neutrons, and its presence under the vessel presumably means
there is a leak.

Highly corrosive when damp, boric acid has been found in the last few years
on the lids of reactor vessels around the world. A plant near Toledo, Ohio,
accumulated 900 pounds, some of which ate away a football-size chunk of
steel in the vessel lid, leaving only a thin stainless-steel liner and
bringing the plant uncomfortably close to accident.

But until the discovery here, on April 12, nobody had ever seen a leak on
the bottom. A leak in that location is far harder to repair, and would be
harder to control if a significant hole developed in the vessel, although
the chances of accident seem far smaller than they did in Ohio.

"It is something different," said Gary Parkey, vice president of the South
Texas Project Nuclear Operating Company, which runs the two reactors here.

Measuring the problem and then resolving it will take new applications of
technology, he said, adding with no evident pleasure, "We are at the cutting
edge of this issue."

Until the discovery, in an inspection during a routine shutdown for
maintenance, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission believed that it understood
the mechanism for leaks in reactor vessels. It assumed that such leaks were
caused by an occurrence called stress corrosion cracking, which, after long
periods of operation, develops in hard metals that are under strain and high
temperature.

Not long ago, the commission developed a formula combining temperature and
years of operation, and used it to tell reactor operators around the country
whether they needed to shut down promptly for inspection or could do the job
at a more convenient time.

But the South Texas Project, here amid beef cattle and wildflowers 90 miles
southwest of Houston, is only 15 years old, and its reactors operate at a
relatively low temperature. That raises the possibility that there may be a
problem even with plants that scored well in the regulatory commission's
formula, and have not been inspected.

"If this turns out to be stress corrosion cracking, and there's nothing
unique about it, then it raises questions about the validity of that
equation," said Brian W. Sheron, the commission's associate director for
project licensing and technical analysis.

That would be bad news for the nation's 102 other commercial power reactors,
which despite vast electricity deregulation have prospered in the last few
years, by achieving new levels of reliability.

The South Texas Project boasted last year that its Reactor No. 1 generated
more electricity than any other in the nation in 2001, and ranked eighth
among the 433 power reactors worldwide. A majority of the plant is owned by
two commercial companies: Reliant Energy and an American Electric Power
subsidiary, AEP Central Power and Light; an additional 44 percent is owned
by the municipal utilities of Austin and San Antonio.

The plant's operators underscore that they caught the problem early.

"There was no puddle, no buildup of boric acid on the bottom," said the
general manager, Ed Halpin.

David Lochbaum, a nuclear safety engineer at the Union of Concerned
Scientists, a group often sharply critical of nuclear operators, also
pointed out that the leak had been discovered early, but in an inspection,
he said, that was more thorough than the regulatory commission requires.

"It does show the prudence of looking periodically in places you don't
expect to have problems," he said, "rather than blindly assuming you're not
going to have problems except where you're looking."

One difficulty at the Ohio plant, Davis-Besse, was that management delayed
taking the time to remove thermal insulation around the vessel lid to check
for leaks. As a result, corrosion continued unnoticed for years. That
corrosion has been a nightmare for the Davis-Besse owners, keeping the plant
shut for 14 months so far and probably some months to come.

At both plants, the leaks occurred in places where the builders had
installed "penetrations" of the vessel. At Davis-Besse, those penetrations
allowed control rods to enter the core (to shut the reactor) and to be
withdrawn (to start it up).

Here, the penetrations are smaller, for dozens of pencil-size detectors that
are pushed up into the core to measure the flow of neutrons, the subatomic
particles that sustain the chain reaction. The leak apparently involves two
of these penetrations.

The safety implications of the problem seem manageable. Even if the reactor
were to have spit out a tube through which a neutron detector enters, the
hole would have been only 1.5 inches in diameter, well within the capacity
of emergency pumps to keep up with. And though water in the reactor was kept
at a pressure of 2,250 pounds, it is not clear that the reactor had been
anywhere near to ejecting a tube by the time the boric acid was discovered
little more than two weeks ago.

Still, while managers here do not yet know the cause of the leak, or
precisely how they will repair it, experts say the job will be complicated
and will involve significant radiation hazards.

The reason is that after months or years of sitting in the core, neutron
detectors are intensely radioactive. If the fuel of Reactor No. 1 is
removed, as operators expect for this repair, then the detectors will most
likely rest at the bottom of the vessel, since they are not designed to be
pushed into the middle of the reactor unless the fuel, and its associated
hardware, are present. Mr. Halpin, the general manager, said engineers were
working on a way to leave the probes in the middle of the vessel even with
no fuel present. But if they rest at the bottom, then a technician working
to repair the leak there could, in just a few minutes, receive from them as
large a dose of radiation as the industry allows a worker in a year.

Plant managers say they presume that the leaking parts are a pair of welds,
each connecting one tube to the stainless-steel liner inside the vessel. But
that place is too hard to reach for repairs, so they plan a weld on the
lower surface, where the tubes exit the vessel, six inches outside the
liner.

The problem is that this would permanently leave cooling water with the
corrosive boric acid in contact with the vessel wall, which is not stainless
but instead plain old carbon-steel, which can corrode. Not only would the
corrosion itself be a problem, but particles from the resulting rust could
do damage as they floated around the reactor.

The managers, however, argue that the volume of exposed carbon-steel would
be very small, and that the temperature during operations is too high to
allow corrosion anyway, a point on which they will have to satisfy the
Nuclear Regulatory Commission before they can proceed. Members of the
commission's staff will discuss the problem with the managers at a public
meeting in Washington on Thursday.

In the meantime, representatives from two associations of reactor operators,
and from five nuclear plants, have visited here and are watching carefully.

April 22, 2003, 7:48PM 
House: preliminary approval to low-level radioactive waste dump 
By APRIL CASTRO Associated Press Writer 
© 2003 The Associated Press

West Texas could become the site of the nation's largest low-level nuclear
waste dump under legislation preliminarily adopted Tuesday in the Texas
House.

The measure, adopted 107-34, would clear the way for the Texas Department
of Health to issue a license to a private company to administer the
low-level nuclear waste site.

The bill, by Rep. George "Buddy" West, R-Odessa, would allow for two
facilities to be set up. One would handle the waste under a federal compact
that requires the state to dispose of wastes from Texas, Maine and Vermont.
The compact is part of a nationwide plan to store low-level radioactive
waste regionally.

A separate but adjacent facility would take Department of Energy waste, a
provision that has caused lawmakers some concern in the past. Last session,
the bill died in the House.

Representatives engaged in hours of debate over the bill.

"We're clearly disappointed," said Erin Rogers, a spokeswoman for the
Sierra Club. "(The bill poses) massive financial liability to the state,
massive potential environmental damage and massive risk to the public
health and safety."

Andrews County, in West Texas, has been touted as an ideal location for one
of the sites and residents there have been supportive of the facility.

Low-level radioactive waste is a byproduct of medical, research and
industrial activities. Low-level radioactive waste also is produced by
nuclear power plants.

Environmentalists balked at the proposal, arguing that bringing a waste
dump to Texas would endanger residents' health and open the door to
terrorist attacks. Low-level radioactive wastes could be used to make
"dirty bombs," they said.

Rep. Lon Burnam, D-Fort Worth, argued that the state should be the license
holder, because private entities risk bankruptcy and abandonment of the
facility.

Proponents disagreed, saying the state has spent millions of dollars over
the past 20 years to study the idea.

"It is time for us to allow the private sector to help us secure a site to
dispose of low level radioactive wastes in this state," said Rep. Warren
Chisum, R-Pampa.

After the bill is finally passed, likely Wednesday, it will then go to the
Senate for debate.

___

The House and Senate low-level radioactive waste dump bills are HB 1567 and
SB 824.

============================

April 22, 2003, 10:36PM
House OKs radioactive dump after lengthy debate
By DINA CAPPIELLO
Copyright 2003 Houston Chronicle Environment Writer

A bill that would set up a private dump for truckloads of low-level
radioactive waste won tentative approval in the House on Tuesday, despite
opponents' efforts to restrict the amount, type and origin of the refuse,
and its shipping routes.

In a five-hour floor debate, more than two dozen amendments were proposed
to H.B. 1567, which would permit the Texas Department of Health to license
a private company to construct a radioactive waste dump. The legislation
finally passed Tuesday evening with a 107 to 34 vote.

Environmentalists and opponents of the bill said their focus would be
redirected to the Senate, which has similar legislation pending in
committee.

"This is not over," said Erin Rogers of the Lone Star Chapter of the Sierra
Club. "The real fight will take place in the Senate." The bill has died
there in previous sessions.

Rogers said as many as eight senators are ready to block the legislation.

During the next 35 years, the dump would accept more than two million cubic
feet of low-level radioactive waste from hospitals, schools and nuclear
power plants in Texas and Vermont.

Currently, radioactive materials are stored at the state's two nuclear
power plants and at 61 other temporary storage sites, most in Harris
County. The bill's supporters argue these sites are targets for terrorists
looking for radioactive waste to construct dirty bombs.

"Since Sept. 11, we are under increased threat for a dirty bomb," said Rep.
Warren Chisum, R-Pampa, as he argued to table an amendment that would have
barred the dump from accepting federal waste produced during atomic weapons
manufacturing. Chisum sponsored the bill along with Rep. George "Buddy"
West, R-Odessa, and Rep. Wayne Smith, R-Baytown.

The legislation satisfies a 1993 compact in which Texas agreed to take
Maine and Vermont's waste for $25 million each. But after years of studies
and $60 million in expenses in unsuccessful attempts to find a site for a
landfill, Maine pulled out of the compact.

The legislation this year differs from previous attempts to site a
low-level radioactive waste dump because it would allow the state to take
radioactive refuse from federal sites, an amount that could total nearly
300 million cubic feet over the 35-year period.

Much of the debate centered on who would regulate and control the site, how
much money the company would have to put up for a possible future cleanup,
and the risk of leaving waste in metropolitan areas versus moving it to a
centralized location.

But only a handful of amendments were accepted. One would bar the licensed
company from accepting radioactive waste if it violated an environmental
law. Another would make it mandatory for the waste company to take out an
insurance policy.

The leading contender for the landfill is Pasadena-based Waste Control
Specialists, which operates a hazardous waste landfill along the New Mexico
border in Andrews County. The company has spent hundreds of thousands of
dollars in lobbyist fees and contributions to Republican lawmakers.

Posted on Tue, Apr. 22, 2003 story:PUB_DESC
West Texas radioactive waste dump clears hurdle
By Karen Brooks
Star-Telegram Staff Writer
AUSTIN _ As environmentalists across the nation marked Earth Day 2003 on
Tuesday, the Texas House gave early approval to a plan that would allow
other states and the federal government to dispose of more than 400 million
cubic feet of low-level radioactive waste in a West Texas dump site.

The last time the Legislature took up the issue, protesters were arrested
in the Senate gallery, an opposing House member nearly passed out in the
chamber from stress, and the bill died before it hit the House floor.

This time, the bill got an easier ride. After the handy defeat of several
attempts by House environmentalists to change or kill the bill, it won
preliminary approval 107-34. It awaits likely final approval in the House
before going to the Senate.

The bill's sponsor called it a "workable solution to a growing health and
security problem in our state."

"It's been a long day," said state Rep. George "Buddy" West, R-Odessa. "Of
course, we've come this far before. We just hope this time we can carry it
on to fruition and make it become law in the state of Texas."

Environmental groups lamented the bill's passage, saying that it would turn
Texas into a national nuclear dumping ground and was written for the sole
benefit of a single company that wants to make money.

"We're extremely disappointed," said Erin Rogers, outreach coordinator for
the Sierra Club's state chapter. "This is the biggest long-term boondoggle
the Legislature has passed this session. Massive financial liability to the
state, massive potential environmental damage, and massive risk to the
public's health and safety."

House Bill 1567 would allow the state health department to license a
private company to maintain a disposal site for waste that would remain
radioactive anywhere from a few days to more than 20,000 years.

The bill would consolidate waste from up to 60 storage sites statewide at
one site in West Texas. The private company would also oversee the disposal
of waste from Vermont, which already has a partnership with Texas. It
allows the company to also contract with the U.S. Department of Energy to
dispose of waste from more than 70 other sites nationwide.
Environmentalists say that deal would increase the amount of radioactive
waste stored in Texas by 200 percent.

Opponents say there is no incentive to minimize the amount of waste coming
into Texas, and the state could be left with an ugly clean-up tab if the
company goes bankrupt or abandons the site.

Supporters say consolidating the waste is easier to control and guard when
it's in one spot. The federal waste contracts are necessary to make the
project profitable enough for a private company to operate it, backers say.

Although no specific site or company is named in the bill, the frontrunner
is Waste Control Specialists, which operates a hazardous waste dump in
western Andrews County northwest of Midland. Bill backers say that location
is among the few in Texas that are ideal because there are no flooding or
groundwater issues.

The bill is sponsored by a contingent of West Texas legislators whose
districts include western Andrews County.

Texas has spent two decades and $50 million trying to set up a low-level
radioactive waste disposal site to be run by a state agency. Four years
ago, the state tried to establish a disposal site in Sierra Blanca, south
of El Paso, but failed after residents objected. In 2001, lawmakers
abolished the state's Low-Level Radioactive Waste Disposal Authority.

The Energy Department has estimated up to 289 million cubic feet of
low-level radioactive waste could be stored in Texas under a contract
allowed by the bill.

Low-level radioactive waste encompasses a wide range of material, from
hospital waste that is radioactive for only a few weeks or months to parts
of decommissioned nuclear power plants that can be radioactive for hundreds
of thousands of years.

Bill opponents, led by state Rep. Lon Burnam, D-Fort Worth, tried Tuesday
to limit the amount of waste coming in, how the waste can be transported
through Texas and what types of waste would be allowed by the bill. They
failed.

"We're setting ourselves up to be the nation's largest nuclear waste dump,
and people are not grasping that," Burnam said.

Karen Brooks, (512) 476-4294
kbrooks@star-telegram.com

Houston Chronicle - the day of our demo

April 23, 2003, 10:28PM
Briefs

Radioactive waste dump may be coming to state

The House approved a bill Wednesday that would make Texas home to one of
the nation's largest low-level radioactive waste dumps, but with an
amendment requiring better security for the most heavily contaminated
material.

HB 1567, by Rep. George "Buddy" West, authorizes the Department of Health
to grant a license to a private company to operate such a landfill. In the
next 35 years, the dump would receive millions of tons of waste from
hospitals, laboratories and nuclear power plants in Texas and Vermont.

Low-level waste from the U.S. Department of Energy also could be discarded
there.

Rep. Vicki Truitt, R-Southlake, offered an amendment requiring that 10 to
20 percent of the waste be stored in aboveground vaults that would be
regularly monitored and easily isolated from the environment.

"It's a good amendment," said Erin Rogers of the Lone Star Chapter of the
Sierra Club. "We just wish it was all of the waste."

So far, the only company that has applied for the license is Waste Control
Specialists, which wants to open a facility in Andrews County in West
Texas. A similar bill is pending in a Senate committee.

=============================================

Nuclear-waste bill advances
House tentatively OKs allowing materials from weapons sites, 2 states
04/23/2003
By GEORGE KUEMPEL / The Dallas Morning News

AUSTIN - A bill to allow millions of cubic feet of low-level radioactive
waste from the nation's nuclear weapons facilities and two other states to
be disposed of in Texas was tentatively approved by the state House on
Tuesday.

"Texas can't afford this bill and should not become the nation's
nuclear-waste dumping ground in order to enrich one private company at our
expense," said Rep. Dora Olivo, D-Rosenberg.

Rep. Warren Chisum, R-Pampa, and other sponsors said, however, that the
measure will isolate at one spot radioactive materials stored at hundreds
of sites across the state and put them out of terrorists' reach.

"We need to get the waste at one site and not have something that would
allow ... [someone] to create a dirty bomb," he said.

The bill was tentatively approved, 107-34, and after a final vote - perhaps
as early as Wednesday - will be sent to the Senate.

The state has spent 20 years and more than $50 million in utility customer
surcharges trying to find a suitable site for disposing of its low-level
radioactive material. It signed an agreement 10 years ago to take waste
from Maine and Vermont.

But supporters say the fees to be paid by the two states won't pay for a
disposal facility and agreed to allow the private operator to also take up
to 300 million cubic feet of low-level waste mostly from the nation's
nuclear weapons facilities.

Tuesday, sponsors beat back amendments that would have banned or reduced
the amount of federal waste allowed, restricted the type of materials
coming in and denied access to states other than Maine and Vermont.

An amendment by Rep. Jesse Jones, D-Dallas, that would have allowed county
commissioners to designate routes for radioactive materials being
transported through their counties also was struck down.

Mr. Jones said he was concerned that the trucks or trains carrying the
material could be involved in an accident or be held up or taken over by
terrorists.

Rep. George "Buddy" West, R-Odessa, one of the co-sponsors, said the
amendment would make the bill "unworkable." He noted that the federal
transportation agency already has designated routes for hazardous
materials.

Also rejected were other amendments by Mr. Jones that would have prohibited
the transport of radioactive materials within one mile of churches, schools
and playgrounds and required transporters to carry enough insurance to
cover the cost of any accidents.

Critics charged, in effect, that the bill was written to benefit
billionaire Dallas investor Harold Simmons, who they said stands to make
hundreds of millions of dollars from the proposal.

A company controlled by Mr. Simmons that operates a hazardous waste dump in
Andrews County in West Texas, Waste Control Specialists, is almost sure to
get the license to operate the dump, they said.

Mr. Simmons has spent millions in lobbying and other expenses over the
years in Austin and in Washington to get the lucrative business of
disposing of the U.S. Department of Energy's radioactive waste.

Envirocare Inc., a company that owns a low-level radioactive-waste facility
in Utah, also is interested in the Texas license. But it doesn't have a
site in Texas and might be reluctant to post the nonrefundable
license-application fee of $500,000 in light of Mr. Simmons' political
connections.

Mr. West denied that the bill was designed to give the business to Mr.
Simmons' company, but he acknowledged that Andrews County is an ideal site
for the dump.

"It meets all the criteria," he said.

A delegation of Andrews County business and government officials who want
the dump and the jobs it will bring watched the debate from the gallery.

Rep. Lon Burnam, D-Fort Worth, the most vocal critic, said the bill is the
handiwork of special interests. He did not name any particular company.

"The bill was driven, written and pushed by people who are excessively
greedy," he said.

US back in nuclear bomb-making business

April 24 2003

The United States says it has regained the capability to make nuclear
weapons for the first time in 14 years and has resumed production of
plutonium parts for bombs.

The Energy Department's announcement on Tuesday marks a symbolic and
operational milestone in rebuilding America's nuclear weapons complex,
which began a long retrenchment in the late 1980s as the Cold War ended and
the toll of environmental damage from bomb production became known.

Under a Bush Administration plan, the Energy Department will begin limited
production of plutonium parts for the country's stockpile of nuclear
weapons and begin laying plans for a new factory that could produce parts
for hundreds of weapons a year.

The Energy Department's previous Rocky Flats site in Colorado was shut down
after serious violations of environmental laws and the FBI raided the
plant.

Posted on Thu, Apr. 24, 2003 FW Star Telegram
More potent 'bunker buster' on way
By Dan Stober
Knight Ridder News Service

SAN JOSE, Calif. -Demonstrating a significant shift in America's nuclear
strategy, the Bush administration intends to produce -- not just research
-- a thermonuclear bunker-busting bomb to destroy hardened, deeply buried
targets, the Pentagon has acknowledged for the first time.

The weapon, known as the Robust Nuclear Earth Penetrator, would be a
full-power hydrogen bomb that would throw up enormous clouds of radioactive
dust while wreaking large-scale damage and death if used in an urban area.
It would be thousands of times more powerful than the conventional "bunker
busters" that were dropped on Baghdad in an attempt to kill former Iraqi
leader Saddam Hussein.

Federal officials signed documents in Washington, D.C., this week to launch
a preliminary design contest between Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory
in California and Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico. Because of
the time needed for congressional funding, officials at the National
Nuclear Security Administration say, they might seek more money for
development even before the preliminary work is completed in 2005 or 2006.

Arms-control advocates are disturbed by such weapons, saying that they are
not needed and only encourage other countries to build nuclear weapons as
fast as possible. They say such weapons are unnecessary because buried
bunkers can be destroyed with conventional bombs or by sending in troops to
attack entrances, air shafts and communications cables.

Fred Celec, the deputy assistant to the secretary of defense for nuclear
matters, made clear that the White House wants the weapon and is moving
forward.

If a hydrogen bomb can be designed to survive a crash through hard rock or
concrete and explode, "it will ultimately get fielded," Celec said in an
interview with the San Jose Mercury News. The United States has worked on
nuclear earth penetrators for decades, and scientists involved in the
project say they expect to succeed.

The project is integral to the administration's push to move away from Cold
War "city scrapping" ballistic missile warheads to battlefield "tactical"
weapons.

"This administration is very serious about rethinking the entire thing,"
said a physicist at a U.S. nuclear weapons lab. "I think everyone around
here is really encouraged to look at what the actual role is for nuclear
weapons."

Reuters
Small Commemorations Mark Chernobyl Disaster
Sat April 26, 2003 02:06 PM ET
By Andrei Makhovsky

MINSK (Reuters) - Small gatherings in three ex-Soviet states marked the
17th anniversary of the Chernobyl disaster on Saturday, the world's worst
civil nuclear accident blamed for thousands of deaths and contamination
across Europe.

About 2,000 people met in central Minsk, capital of Belarus, to mourn
victims and denounce President Alexander Lukashenko, accused in the West of
stifling opposition.

Events in Ukraine, site of the nuclear plant closed in 2000, and Russia,
drew fewer people. Low attendance may have been linked to preparations for
Orthodox Easter celebrations in all three countries.

In Belarus, where about one-fifth of land was contaminated downwind from
the explosion and fire across the border, demonstrators carried the
red-and-white national flag banned by Lukashenko after he took office in
1994.

They accused authorities of minimizing the effects of the disaster and
denounced Lukashenko's decision in the mid-1990s to allow impoverished
residents to return to contaminated regions.

"Chernobyl and Lukashenko -- our two tragedies," read on poster.

In Ukraine, hundreds of mourners pressed into a church in Slavutych, the
town built to rehouse the station's staff, at precisely 1.24 a.m., when the
explosion blew the roof off Chernobyl's fourth reactor on April 26, 1986.
Small groups attended memorials in Kiev, 140 km (90 miles) to the south.

Demonstrators in Crimea denounced government moves to limit compensation to
thousands who claim "liquidator" status -- those who helped put out the
blaze and erect in the weeks that followed a concrete "tomb" around the
stricken reactor.

In Moscow, about 30 ecologists paraded outside the Atomic Energy Ministry
with signs bearing the names of Russian villages contaminated in the
disaster and denounced pollution linked to nuclear facilities in other
regions.

Although only about 30 people died in efforts to put out the blaze, about
5,000 deaths are now blamed on the accident, the result of an unauthorized
experiment that ran out of control.

RADIATION, DISEASE

About five million people suffered the effects of radiation and researchers
are still charting long-term incidence of thyroid cancer and other
diseases.

In the run-up to this year's anniversary, fresh accusations emerged that
the tomb, or sarcophagus, encasing the reactor could collapse and unleash a
new ecological disaster.

Russian Atomic Energy Minister Alexander Rumyantsev, interviewed by
Izvestia newspaper, renewed earlier accusations, saying conditions inside
were becoming increasingly uncertain.

"The sarcophagus was meant to be built for five years, it has stood for 17.
No one is investigating in detail the reactions occurring inside," he told
the daily.

"This is not a question of money. Chernobyl has become a site mixed up with
political interests."

Ukraine closed the plant's last functioning reactor in 2000 under
international pressure. But proposals to build a new tomb have made no
progress and Ukraine is still seeking Western assistance to complete two
unfinished reactors elsewhere.

Ukrainian Foreign Minister Anatoly Zlenko this week dismissed suggestions
of safety concerns.

Secret KGB archives released earlier showed the Soviet secret police knew
the plant was dangerous long before the disaster.

KLAS-TV Home
George Knapp, I-Team Reporter
Testing a New Generation of Weapons

(April 28) -- Could the testing of nuclear weapons one
day resume at the Nevada Test Site? The Bush
administration has asked Congress to approve a big
step in that direction.

The ban on nuclear testing, enacted in the early 90's,
is considered vital to worldwide efforts to limit the
spread of atomic weapons. So what reasons could there
be for even thinking about firing up the test program
once again?

Issues don't get any bigger than nuclear weapons and
nuclear testing, and Nevada will be in the thick of it
no matter what is decided. Last month, the Bush
administration asked Congress to repeal the ban on
research into low yield nuclear weapons.

The administration had already released a study saying
we need to be better prepared for resumed testing. So
what's really afoot here? And what could it mean to
our state? It's been 31 years since above ground
nuclear tests were banned. No place in the world saw
more of these fiery blasts than Nevada.

Concerns about radioactive fallout sent nuclear tests
under ground but underground tests were halted in
1992. The U.S. and Russia hoped that stopping the
tests would limit the proliferation of atomic weapons.

"I don't think it's worked," said Troy Wade, nuclear
weapons scientist. Nuclear scientist Troy Wade was
project manager, meaning, the guy who pushed the
button, on 30 nuclear tests in Nevada.

He's been involved in development and testing of nukes
since 1958 and thinks the U.S. is risking everything
by not being able to test its atomic stockpile. Most
of America's weapons, he says, are well past their
prime.

"Many of those nuclear weapons have exceeded their
design lifetime by many years. The stockpile is very
old, and that's a concern," said Wade. He adds that
more than half of the stockpile is beyond its shelf
life.

America's nuclear stockpile unquestionably helped to
prevent catastrophe during the Cold War years, but as
these complicated weapons grow older and less
reliable, Wade and others wonder if they will still
serve as a deterrent.

Deep under the surface of the Nevada test site, in a
secretive honeycomb carved into the dirt, scientists
try to simulate nuclear tests in experiments that, by
law, must be subcritical, that is, something that
stops short of an atomic reaction. Information is then
fed into computers to evaluate what kind of shape our
stockpile is in -- good but not as good as in the
past.

"The confidence level has gone down. It's not 99% like
it was. We have evidence there's been a degradation of
parts," said Wade. He argues that subcritical tests
and other measures are valuable, but that they are no
substitute for an actual test in evaluating the
reliability of our weapons. However, even if the U.S.
wanted to conduct a test, it couldn't.

Recent studies show it might take three years to
prepare for the real thing. Not only have the
facilities been dismantled, but experienced personnel
are simply gone. "We're not in very good shape,
frankly. Look at the color of my hair and beard,
people who grew up in this program are retiring or
dying, said Wade.

The Bush administration has asked that the prep time
for a test be reduced from 36 months down to 18. Such
a policy might mean millions of new dollars -- and
renewed life -- for the test site. Nuclear opponents
are appalled by the move and worry it might spark a
new arms race.

Even test site supporters like Senator Harry Reid urge
caution. "I'm not going to advocate a resumption of
nuclear testing simply because it's economically good
for the state. Can't do that," said Senator Harry
Reid, (D) Nevada.

If we do anything like a resumption of testing, it
must be with the support of the world. It can't be
unilateral. It's the rest of the world that has Troy
Wade and military labs worried. The test ban didn't
stop rogue nations like North Korea or Iraq from
pursuing their own nukes. India and Pakistan continued
testing.

The U.S. suspects Russia and France have done secret
tests, while U.S. weaponry continues to age. "The only
people who stopped for sure were the U.S. and the
United Kingdom," said Wade. Senator Reid says that
while he supports the idea of getting the test site
more prepared to do testing, he doesn't support the
resumption of testing itself and says the stockpile is
reliable.

Opponents say any testing, even subcritical, will only
encourage other nations to get their own nukes.

May 7, 2003, 11:10PM
RADIOACTIVE WASTE
Senate adopts plan for twin dumps
Associated Press

AUSTIN -- A low-level radioactive waste site that would take Department of
Energy waste would be set up under legislation approved in the Senate on
Wednesday after a long debate about how much material the site should be
allowed to handle.

House Bill 1567, approved on a 23-6 vote, authorizes the Texas Commission on
Environmental Quality to issue a license to a private company to administer
the site.

Two facilities would be set up. One would handle waste under a compact that
requires the state to dispose of waste from Texas, Vermont and Maine,
although Maine is in the midst of withdrawing from the agreement. The
compact is part of a nationwide plan to store low-level radioactive waste
regionally.

A separate but adjacent facility would take Department of Energy waste.

Although the bill does not say where the site could be set up, bill sponsor
Teel Bivins, R-Amarillo, has said Andrews County residents support setting
up a facility in their West Texas county. A Pasadena-based company, Waste
Control Specialists, already operates a hazardous waste storage facility
there and has pushed for the legislation.

"The reality is there is low-level radioactive waste stored on building tops
all over Dallas and Houston and Austin and we would like to create a stable,
suitable site for this waste to be disposed of so that people in the urban
areas are not put at risk," Bivins said.

Low-level radioactive waste is a byproduct of medical, research and
industrial activities. It also is produced by nuclear power plants. Bivins
has said a majority of the Energy Department waste is dirt.

Most of the debate came on the issue of how much federal waste Texas should
accept.

Bivins' bill allowed for up to 10 million cubic yards of federal waste to be
stored at the site, but Sen. Robert Duncan, R-Lubbock, offered an amendment
that would have limited that amount to 1.3 million cubic yards.

"I know this is in Senator Bivins' district, but it's also in my
neighborhood," Duncan told the lawmakers, who approved the amendment.

The senators finally agreed to allow the site to hold up to 6 million cubic
yards of federal waste.

Bivins said he believed companies would be interested in competing for a
permit with that cap in place. Duncan argued against the change, saying it
would make Texas the dumping ground of the United States.

The House has approved a similar bill. If the House does not concur with the
Senate changes, a committee of House and Senate members will be assigned to
work out the differences.

LOW LEVEL NUCLEAR WASTE PASSES SENATE
Compromise reached over cap on amount

The Senate today took up CSHB 1567, a bill dealing with the storage of 
low-level nuclear waste. A contentious issue for several sessions, the 
legislation passed the Senate last session but was killed in the House 
Calendars Committee.

Sen. Robert Duncan (R-Lubbock) said the debate appeared more cordial this
time around. However, that did not stop some spirited debate on a number of
amendments.

The lengthy bill analysis for CSHB 1567 can be found here. Basically, the
bill would allow the state to contract a company to house federal low-level
nuclear waste as well as waste from states involved in a "compact." Maine
ended its involvement and only Texas and Vermont currently are in the
compact.

Senate approves bills setting up radioactive waste site
05/07/2003
By NATALIE GOTT / The Associated Press

AUSTIN -  A low-level radioactive waste site that would take
Department of Energy waste would be set up under legislation
approved in the Senate on Wednesday after a long debate about how
much material the site should be allowed to handle.

The bill, approved on a 23-6 vote, authorizes the Texas Commission
on Environmental Quality to issue a license to a private company to
administer the site.

Two facilities would be set up. One would handle waste under a
compact that requires the state to dispose of waste from Texas,
Vermont and Maine, although Maine is in the midst of withdrawing
from the agreement. The compact is part of a nationwide plan to
store low-level radioactive waste regionally.

A separate but adjacent facility would take Department of Energy
waste.

While the bill does not say where the waste site could be set up,
bill sponsor Teel Bivins, R-Amarillo, has said Andrews County
residents support setting up a facility in their West Texas County.
A Pasadena-based company called Waste Control Specialists already
operates a hazardous waste storage facility there and has pushed for
the legislation.

"The reality is there is low-level radioactive waste stored on
building tops all over Dallas and Houston and Austin and we would
like to create a stable, suitable site for this waste to be disposed
of so that people in the urban areas are not put at risk," Bivins
told lawmakers.

Low-level radioactive waste is a byproduct of medical, research and
industrial activities. It also is produced by nuclear power plants.
Bivins said a majority of the waste is dirt.

Most of the debate on the bill came on the issue of how much federal
waste Texas should accept.

Bivins' bill allowed for up to 10 million cubic yards of federal
waste to be stored at the site, but Sen. Robert Duncan, Lubbock,
offered an amendment that would have limited that amount to 1.3
million cubic yards.

"I know this is in Sen. Bivins' district, but it's also in my
neighborhood," Duncan told the lawmakers, who approved the
amendment.

The senators finally agreed to allow the site to hold up to 6
million cubic yards of federal waste.

Bivins said he believed companies would be interested in competing
for a permit with that cap in place. Duncan argued against the
change, saying it would make Texas the dumping ground of the United
States.

The Senate shot down an amendment by Sen. Eliot Shapleigh, D-El
Paso, that would have stopped the state from taking Department of
Energy waste.

"The state of Texas, by taking this DOE waste, does one thing. It
makes a profitable operation much more profitable for one operator
and the decision that we make here is important for generations of
Texans," said Shapleigh, D-El Paso.

The House has approved a similar bill. If the House does not concur
with the Senate changes, then a committee of House and Senate
members will be assigned to work out the differences.

Dallas Morning News
Radioactive dump approved by Senate
A bill to authorize creation of the first low-level radioactive waste dump
in Texas won approval from the Senate on Wednesday, but only after the
measure was changed to limit the amount of material that could be stored at
the site.

Radioactive dump approved by Senate

05/08/2003

By TERRENCE STUTZ / The Dallas Morning News

AUSTIN - A bill to authorize creation of the first low-level radioactive waste
dump in Texas won approval from the Senate on Wednesday, but only after the
measure was changed to limit the amount of material that could be stored at
the site.

Unlike the House version of the legislation, which has no limits, the Senate
bill would restrict the radioactive waste at the dump to no more than 6
million cubic yards - mostly of contaminated dirt.

Senators approved the measure on a 23-6 vote. It now returns to the House for
consideration of Senate amendments.

The proposed facility would receive low-level radioactive waste from the
nation's nuclear weapons facilities and from Texas and two other states.

"We need to create a stable, suitable site for this waste to be disposed of so
that people in urban areas are not at risk," said Sen. Teel Bivins,
R-Amarillo, author of the bill.

"The facility would only be authorized to accept and dispose low-level
radioactive waste, which typically has a low potential for harm to human
health and the environment."

But several senators said they were not convinced that the dump would pose no
environmental threat, and they offered a series of amendments to restrict
operations and improve safeguards. Most were rejected.

Sen. Robert Duncan, R-Lubbock, offered an amendment to limit the amount of
radioactive waste to 1.3 million cubic yards - a fraction of the 10 million
cubic-yard limit proposed by Mr. Bivins.

The amendment was initially approved on a 16-14 vote, prompting an irritated
Mr. Bivins to declare that the site would never open with such a restriction.
Senators later adopted another amendment allowing 6 million cubic yards.

"This makes Texas the dumping ground of the United States and the world," Mr.
Duncan said.

The leading candidate for the license is Waste Control Specialists, which
operates a hazardous waste dump in Andrews County in West Texas. The company
is controlled by Dallas billionaire investor Harold Simmons, who has spent
millions of dollars on lobbying and other expenses to obtain the right to
dispose of radioactive waste from the U.S. Department of Energy.

While Mr. Bivins acknowledged that Mr. Simmons' company is a front-runner to
get the license, he insisted the bidding would be open. One company that could
be interested is Envirocare Inc., which operates a low-level radioactive waste
facility in Utah that is the only one now accepting material from the Energy
Department.

E-mail tstutz@dallasnews.com

Posted on Thu, May. 08, 2003
78th Legislature
Jan. 14-June 2
Star-Telegram

Quote of the day
"It's purely politics. It's purely perception."
-- Sen. Teel Bivins, R-Amarillo, on why he was pushing for a cap
on the amount of low-level radioactive waste to be allowed at a
proposed dump site in West Texas.

Waste site plan clears Senate
By John Moritz
Star-Telegram Austin Bureau

AUSTIN - A two-decade effort to establish a dumping ground for
low-level radioactive waste cleared a major hurdle Wednesday when the
state Senate approved a plan that would allow up to 6 million cubic
yards of the material to be buried in West Texas.

The legislation adopted by the Senate significantly changes the
measure that passed the Texas House last month to allow the state to
license a private company to maintain a disposal site for waste that
would remain radioactive.

State Sen. Teel Bivins, R-Amarillo, said the legislation is needed
because radioactive waste generated by hospitals, industries and
utilities is either improperly stored in cities across the state or
not disposed of at all.

"We would like to create a suitable site for this waste to be disposed
of so that the state's urban areas are not put at risk," said Bivins,
the Senate sponsor of House Bill 1567, who emphasized that the site
would not store spent nuclear fuel or waste from nuclear weapons.

The legislation would pave the way for consolidating waste from up to
60 storage sites statewide in one place, most likely in Andrews County
in West Texas. The company that wins the state license would also
oversee the disposal of waste from Maine and Vermont, which already
have a partnership with Texas.

The bill would also allow the company to contract with the U.S.
Department of Energy to dispose of waste from more than 70 other sites
nationwide. Environmentalists say that proposal would increase the
amount of radioactive waste stored in Texas by 200 percent.

The legislation now goes back to the House for consideration of
changes made in the Senate.

Among the Senate-initiated changes were a provision that would make
the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality responsible for issuing
the license and overseeing the work done by the private company. The
House bill would put the dump and the operator under the auspices of
the Texas Department of Health.

The Senate also capped the amount of waste that the Texas site could
accommodate at 6 million cubic yards. The House version contained no
cap.

The issue of how much waste to allow tied the Senate in knots during
more than two hours of debate. Bivins, who represents the district
where the dump will probably be located, proposed setting the cap at
10 million cubic yards.

Lubbock Republican Robert Duncan, whose district is near the site,
offered an amendment that would cap the waste at 1.3 million cubic
yards. Bivins said that no private company would accept such a
restriction.

Sen. Jeff Wentworth, R-San Antonio, suggested a compromise that would
allow for 6 million cubic yards. Bivins embraced the gesture; Duncan
balked.

"I know you're trying to help [but] this doesn't help," Duncan told
Wentworth. "This makes Texas the dumping ground of the world, or of
the United States."

But by an 18-12 vote, senators accepted the compromise.

Texas has spent two decades and $50 million trying to set up a
low-level radioactive waste disposal site to be run by a state agency.
Four years ago, the state tried to establish a disposal site in Sierra
Blanca, south of El Paso, but that failed when residents objected. In
2001, lawmakers abolished the state's Low-Level Radioactive Waste
Disposal Authority.

Although no specific site or company is named in the bill, the
front-runner is Houston-based Waste Control Specialists, which
operates a hazardous waste dump in western Andrews County northwest of
Midland. Backers of the legislation say that the location is among the
few in Texas considered ideal because there are no flooding or ground
water issues.

Erin Rogers of the Lone Star Chapter of the Sierra Club called the
bill "a recipe for environmental disaster and a windfall for one
company."

Austin Chronicle
HOME: VOL.22 NO.37: NEWS: TEXAS WANTS NUKE WASTE

Texas Wants Nuke Waste
BY MICHAEL KING

May 16, 2003:

On May 7 the Texas Senate passed HB 1567, the nuclear-waste dump bill that,
if finally permitted, will enable not one but two private nuke-waste
storage facilities, most likely at Waste Control Specialists' sites in
Andrews Co. Presuming the House ever returns to session, the revised bill
is expected to be quickly approved and sent to the governor. Harold Simmons
of WCS has long been one of Gov. Rick Perry's most lucrative and loyal
financial supporters (more than $400,000 in cumulative campaign
contributions), and there is no doubt the governor will sign the bill.
However, bill sponsor Sen. Teel Bivins, R-Amarillo, insisted the bidding
will be open and WCS will not necessarily win the contract.

A nuclear-waste dump was originally proposed for a site in Sierra Blanca,
in Hudspeth Co., several years ago, and the state created an agency -- the
Texas Low-Level Radioactive Waste Disposal Authority -- to oversee that
project, which was abandoned in 1998 after years of controversy. That dump,
which under HB 1567 is basically being relocated to Andrews Co., would have
held only low-level waste from Texas, Maine, and Vermont -- primarily
decommissioned power-plant material and a small amount of waste generated
by nuclear-medicine facilities. Maine has since moved to leave the
three-state compact, and in the meantime privateers like Simmons have
concluded that there isn't enough money to be made under the original
compact limits.

Hence a second dump, which is proposed to accept U.S. Dept. of Energy waste
(including that from nuclear-weapons manufacture) from all 50 states. Sen.
Robert Duncan, R-Lubbock, initially succeeded in amending the bill to cap
transfers to the dump at 1.3 million cubic yards, but Bivins (whose
district includes Andrews) insisted the dump would not be financially
viable with that limitation. Over Duncan's protests that a higher limit
would make Texas "the dumping ground of the United States and the world,"
Sen. Jeff Wentworth, R-San Antonio, successfully offered a compromise of 6
million cubic yards.

The Senate rejected several other amendments aimed at improving the safety
of transport and storage of the waste. If the House approves Senate
amendments, the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality will oversee
permitting and licensing of the dump. The TCEQ's predecessor agency ended
up pulling the plug on Sierra Blanca (where, among other problems, the
proposed site sat on an earthquake fault), and rad-waste dump opponents
hope to have some effect on the TCEQ permitting process for the Andrews
sites. Meanwhile, Erin Rogers of the Sierra Club called the bill "a recipe
for environmental disaster."

WIPP on list to someday make nukes
By Julie Breaux
Odessa American

The Department of Energy's Waste Isolation Pilot Project in Carlsbad,
N.M., is one of five potential sites of a nuclear weapons-related
production facility, the mayor of Carlsbad says.

"Carlsbad made the short list because of WIPP," said Mayor Bob Forest.

WIPP, located about 10 miles southwest of Carlsbad, is the
government's underground repository for all items used to make nuclear
bombs -  gloves, tools, equipment and the like. said Jay Lees, WIPP
spokesperson. The items are stored in long, wide rooms carved out of a
salt cavern located several thousand feet below ground.

If it's chosen, WIPP would be the site of a facility estimated to cost
between $2 billion and $4 billion to build. It would be called a
"modern pit facility," where plutonium triggers, or "pits," for
nuclear bombs would be made, Forest said.

"We took the WIPP site when no other town wanted it, and now that
we're successful, it's given (DOE) the green light to refurbish the
pits," Forest said. The pits, key components in the chain reaction
that triggers nuclear bombs, are temporarily being manufactured at Los
Alamos National Laboratory in Los Alamos, N.M., until the Energy
Department finds a site for a much larger, permanent facility, Forest
said.

The other sites being considered are:

- Los Alamos
- Pantex, north of Amarillo
- Nevada Test site, northwest of Las Vegas
- Savannah River Site, south of Aiken, S.C.

Forest said the facility would employ about 1,500 people.

The DOE's Rocky Flats Nuclear Weapons Plant near Denver manufactured
plutonium triggers until 1989.

The facility was closed in 1992 after a government investigation found
that plutonium, uranium and other toxic materials were secretly
released from the plant in the Denver area.

Bryan Wilkes, spokesperson for the Energy Department's National
Nuclear Security Administration, said the closure of Rocky Flats in
the early 1990s made it imperative to build another
trigger-manufacturing facility.

The NNSA is responsible for the assembly and disassembly of the
nation's nuclear weapons as part of its Stockpile Stewardship and
Management program.

The stewardship program was created after the United States in October
1992 unilaterally and voluntarily stopped testing nuclear weapons
underground, Wilkes said.

Today, to ensure the reliability of the nation's nuclear arsenal, the
NNSA removes weapons from the stockpile, disassembles them, makes
repairs and replaces the plutonium triggers if and when necessary,
Wilkes said.

"We need the ability to replace that plutonium," Wilkes said. "If we
don't put back a weapon in the stockpile that we take out, then what
we're doing is a slow, unilateral disarmament."

If the WIPP site is chosen, the triggers would be transported to the
Pantex plant in the Texas Panhandle for final assembly in nuclear
bombs, Forest said.

Forest said an overwhelming majority of Carlsbad residents support the
project. Carlsbad has been suffering from the steady decline of oil
and gas production, a foundation of its economy.

"The key to any city growing is you've got to have some good jobs,"
Forest said.

The DOE WIPP site offers "good jobs, good benefits and great job
security," Forest said, adding that he expects no less from the pit
facility.

Forest said he thought the WIPP site would complement a
trigger-manufacturing plant.

"Here in Carlsbad, we get the waste regardless, so we might as well
get the good part of the project."

Neil McDonald, director of economic development for the Odessa Chamber
of Commerce, said he would support the project, "given all the
safeguards that would go into a federal project of that magnitude."

Because of the size of the pit facility, McDonald said the economic
benefits might spill over into Odessa, itself a mid- to
heavy-manufacturing center.
