http://www.oaoa.com/news/nw062203a.htm
Nuclear-waste site sparks debate 
By Bob Campbell
Odessa American

Depending on your viewpoint, the radioactive-waste repository planned about
30 miles west of Andrews off Highway 176 is either a harmless economic boon
for an oil-dependent county or an environmental hazard and political
boondoggle.

Andrews political leaders and some citizens, the state legislators who
sponsored the enabling House Bill 1567 and Senate Bill 824 and
representatives of the waste company say the site isn't over the Ogallala
water aquifer and therefore poses no threat to the environment.

The Sierra Club in Austin, one of the plan's most determined opponents in
the eight years the project has been pending, says all nuclear waste dumps
leak, and this one is close enough to the aquifer to pollute it.

A Sierra Club spokeswoman explained that the club doesn't believe the
proponents' claim about the repository's lack of proximity to the aquifer.

Tom Jones, general manager of Waste Control Specialists, which operates the
facility, said the 16,000-acre site near the New Mexico border has 30 feet
of caliche over a hard formation of 800 feet of red clay that would keep
any leakage from seeping into the water table.

"The Ogallala doesn't extend this far down or over this far," he said.
"We're at the tail end of the aquifer where fingers of it dip down."

With a permit from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Waste Control
is already operating a low-level radioactive waste repository, having
stored 250,000 cubic yards of material from the U.S. Department of Energy.
It employs 72 people, many from Andrews.

With legislation sponsored by Rep. Buddy West, R-Odessa, and Teel Bivins,
R-Amarillo, instructing the Texas Department of Health to accept permit
applications, the company plans to dig an initial concrete-lined hole 1,500
feet square and 75 feet deep, Jones said.

The state health department is the official designated licensing agency
with operations to be supervised by the Texas Commission on Environmental
Quality, formerly the Texas Natural Resources Conservation Commission.

The pit will accommodate 6 million cubic yards of waste. Only 600,000 cubic
yards of waste will have high levels of radioactivity. The waste will come
from the Department of Energy and the interstate Waste Compact to store
commercial waste from Texas, Vermont and Maine. If there are no problems
after five years, the company would be eligible to apply to dig another
pit.

No applications may be submitted until June next year.

Jones said fears that such facilities "always leak" go back to the 1940s
and '50s, when they often did.

"They'd bury chemicals and gasoline in steel tanks underground, and it
wasn't until the early '80s when they realized that 25 percent of those
tanks leaked," he said.

The current repository is run like a landfill with waste materials going
down on a thick sheet of polyethylene plastic and then being covered with
another sheet. The big new repository, expected to be operational by 2005,
will be lined with reinforced concrete and then covered with it.

Waste Control plans to seek a 15-year license, and the Sierra Club is
fearful it will harm the environment, make $100 billion for company owner
Harold Simmons of Dallas and then be left to deteriorate.

Jones disputed that profit projection, saying "lucrative is not the right
word because the state will set our rates. We do expect a reasonable return
on our investment, and we're banking on its being a worthwhile business to
be in."

Sierra Club Grassroots Coordinator Erin Rogers, of Austin, said politics
have been a major determinant in the plan's reaching this advanced stage.

She said West and Bivins pushed hard for an expansion of the limit on
higher grade "B" and "C" grade radioactive materials from 5,000 cubic yards
to 600,000 - a change Sen. Robert Duncan of Lubbock opposed but couldn't
stop when the compromise measure was being decided.

"Finally getting it through was a culmination of the change in political
leadership in the Legislature and massive campaign contributions from
Simmons and Kent Hance," said Rogers, referring to the former Lubbock
congressman and Austin lobbyist.

She said Simmons and his lobbyists have donated $500,000 to leaders like
West and Bivins since 1997, including $360,000 to Gov. Rick Perry.

"Bivins directly threatened other senators, as chair of the finance
committee, to cut off funding for projects in their districts unless they
voted for this bill," she said. "We also know that Hance threatened to find
and finance candidates to run against some of the senators who might vote
against the bill."

Bivins said Friday that "there is absolutely no truth to the allegations by
Ms. Rogers."

Hance said Rogers "is an extremist" and the Sierra Club "never wants the
science to be involved because if the scientific facts are utilized, they
lose.

"I'm not going to help people who disagree with me philosophically," Hance
said. "I'm not going to help liberal Democrats, and I wouldn't expect Erin
Rogers to help conservatives or moderates. The unfortunate thing about this
whole debate is that she and her followers have never told the truth.
They're just sore losers."

Rogers said she's concerned about the eventual effect of Waste Control's
profit motive.

"The cheaper they can dispose of it, the more profit they will make," she
said. "We're worried they will forsake safety for profit."

 ================================================================

West Texas sees a waste opportunity

Desperate for jobs, town looks past hazards in nuclear dump plan

07/12/2003

By MATT STILES / The Dallas Morning News

ANDREWS, Texas - Desolate and arid, this is the land of rusted pipes and
oil fields, where pump jacks outnumber full-grown trees.

In this weathered region, where one can drive for miles without seeing much
civilization, people take note when something new comes around - whether it
be here or in the closest neighboring city, Eunice, N.M, 35 miles west.

If it means well-paying jobs, there's not much concern. Bring it on, they
say, even if it's nuclear waste.

"It's not a threat at all to me," said Bud Hobbs, 70, who retired in 1997
after decades in the oil-services industry. "I've not heard anybody worry
about it."

Out here, folks favor anything that could help wean their economy from the
boom or bust of oil and gas.

Andrews is the only incorporated town in the county where a company, Waste
Control Specialists LLC, hopes to dispose of the waste - mountains of
contaminated dirt, building materials and protective clothing from Texas
sites and federal nuclear facilities - at a location between Andrews and
Eunice. Map: location of proposed dump

The company, majority-owned by Dallas billionaire financier Harold Simmons,
a significant campaign contributor to President Bush and state GOP
leadership, runs a 1,600-acre hazardous waste disposal facility just inside
Texas on a deserted stretch of state highway between Eunice and Andrews.

With only a few local dissenters, the company has earned the trust of both
towns by hiring workers and donating money.

Environmental groups, including Nuke Free Texas, Blue Skies Alliance and
the Sierra Club, opposed the radioactive waste dump plan as it moved this
spring through the Legislature, which approved enabling laws. Waste Control
Specialists is considered the leading candidate for a license, which will
be issued by the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.

The environmental groups, with little local support, cited health risks
from disposing radioactive material and transporting it along Texas
highways.

"This is something that we consider to be offensive," said Ken Kramer,
director of the Lone Star chapter of the Sierra Club in Austin, who fears
that an 18-wheeler could crash into a body of water on its way to the site.
"The larger the volume, the greater the number of shipments, the better the
chances for a problem."

Mr. Kramer's group also bristles at the idea that waste from federal
nuclear sites, such as the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico,
would be allowed into Texas.

But in Eunice, where the streets are quiet and dusty and overnight visitors
stay at the single-story Oil Patch Motel, residents aren't complaining -
despite lacking input on the issue because they live in New Mexico.

The existing hazardous waste dump employs a few-dozen people. Some believe
more might be hired if it expands to handle the radioactive material,
possibly 6 million cubic yards of it - enough to fill a bit more than half
of the American Airlines Center in Dallas.

"I'm sure it'll have a few drawbacks," said JoAnn Davis, 46, a Eunice City
Council member and lifelong resident. "We live in a more dangerous
environment, and we're accustomed to that."

Great expectations

The waste company, which plans to spend several million dollars preparing a
license application for the state environmental quality commission, says
the Panhandle dump could become a $500-million operation in its first
decade provided it receives quick regulatory approval.

The U.S. Department of Energy has said it expects to spend $200 million to
$800 million to dispose of materials from federal sites.

Company officials, who hope to begin receiving the material as early as
2005, say area residents shouldn't worry.

"I would have no qualms at all about building a house out here," said Tom
Jones, general manager of the 23-square-mile site for the last 18-months,
pointing to the bare expanse of parched earth and knee-high mesquite brush.

Mr. Jones, who worked on a hazardous waste incinerator plan during a
20-year career with Texas Instruments before moving to Andrews, said
residents in neighboring towns would be safe.

He's proud that none of his 70 employees has missed a day of work because
of an on-site injury in two years. His workers worry almost as much about
the threat posed by rattlesnakes, spiders and scorpions as they do being
harmed by the waste, he said.

The site would be only the fourth disposal facility of its kind in the
country.

Radioactivity can range from just above background levels found in nature
to highly contaminated in certain cases, such as reactor vessel parts from
a nuclear power plant, according to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

Some items decay quickly, essentially becoming regular trash. Other toxic
items might be at the site for thousands of years.

'It never rains'

If the material were buried, theoretically it could be dangerous to locals
if rain fell on the hole, percolated in the waste, then leaked into the
groundwater. Company officials say the source is too deep to be affected
and isn't potable. Besides, the 14 inches of annual rainfall the county
receives - less than half the total Dallas gets - is not nearly enough to
cause problems.

"The stuff doesn't move without water," said Michael Lauer, a company vice
president based in Dallas. "It never rains out there."

If the company gets its license, it would end a 20-year struggle by
officials to find somewhere to dispose of low-level radioactive materials
from Texas' nuclear power plants, hospitals, utilities and research
facilities.

The disposal site would be the first of its kind in Texas. Amid opposition
based on environmental concerns, state regulators refused in 1998 to
approve a state-run nuclear waste site in Sierra Blanca, near El Paso.

During the 2003 legislative session, Mr. Simmons hired more than a dozen
well-known lobbyists, including former House Speaker Billy Clayton, paying
up to $830,000 to assure the bill's passage. Mr. Simmons also personally
donated $117,000 to the campaigns of the state's top Republican
officeholders in last year's elections, including $75,000 to Gov. Rick
Perry.

Similar waste

In Carlsbad, N.M., about 70 miles from Eunice, a federally managed site,
the Waste Isolation Pilot Plant, began receiving shipments of similar waste
in 1999, storing them in deep tunnels carved into salt deposits.

Environmentalists intensely opposed the facility, although most locals
supported the idea. Today, opposition is largely muted.

"It has employed a lot of people," said Lisa Boeke, the Carlsbad Chamber of
Commerce marketing director. "They've always been a really strong member of
the community."

The Texas company appears to be following that model.

Recent Andrews High School graduate Natalie Mosley, who admits to not
knowing much about the science of the plan, said the company's community
involvement influenced her opinions.Ms. Mosley, 18, said she noticed Waste
Control Specialists' presence after the facility opened in 1997 and new
faces starting showing up at school and the company logo began appearing on
softball and Little League uniforms.

Then this year, the company gave her a $1,000 scholarship - for which she
never applied - to defray tuition at the University of North Texas, where
she plans in the fall to study marketing or public relations. Several
classmates received the same gift, she said.

"It was pretty cool that they picked me," said Ms. Mosley, working behind
the counter at her job inside Ribbons and Bows, a gift shop on Andrews'
central street. "I don't really know how [the site] affects us. But it
doesn't affect my daily life."

E-mail mstiles@dallasnews.com

IEER Press Release  FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  
For further information contact:
Arjun Makhijani, 301-270-5500 Brice Smith, 301-270-5500    

Potential Accidents at New Plutonium Bomb Factory Would Violate Radiation
Protection Standards for the Public  Bomb Plant Would Undermine Nuclear
Test Moratorium and Test Ban Treaty According to Independent Analysis 
Proposed Large Plant Would Also Violate Internal Radiation Safety
Guidelines for Workers

Takoma Park, Maryland, July 16, 2003: More than one-fourth of the
potential accidents analyzed for a new facility designed to manufacture
plutonium triggers for the U.S. nuclear arsenal would violate the DOE's
own guideline for radiation exposure to the public, some by as much as
400%, according to an independent analysis of government documents.

In addition, the accidents analyzed by the government represent only a
fraction of possible scenarios, thus preventing any clear understanding
of the overall risk posed to the public by the facility. These
conclusions are based on a review of the May 2003 draft Department of
Energy (DOE) Environmental Impact Statement on its proposed Modern Pit
Facility (MPF) conducted by the Institute for Energy and Environmental
Research (IEER) in Takoma Park, Maryland. The plutonium "pits" to be made
at the proposed facility are the triggers that initiate the explosion in
modern multi-stage thermonuclear warheads and are similar to the
plutonium explosive in the bomb that the United States used to destroy
Nagasaki during the Second World War.  Sites under consideration for the
DOE's Modern Pit Facility include the Los Alamos National Laboratory
(LANL) and Carlsbad, both in New Mexico; the Savannah River Site near
Aiken, South Carolina; the Nevada Test Site, 60 miles from Las Vegas; and
the Pantex Plant in Amarillo, Texas.

At three of these sites (LANL, Carlsbad, and the Pantex Plant), one-third
to one-half of the accidents analyzed for a plant capable of producing
450 pits per year (ppy) would lead to exposures in excess of the DOE
guidelines for a member of the public.

The maximum allowed exposure to a person offsite under the DOE guideline
is 25 rem, which is 50 times the annual exposure limit to the population
allowed from the normal operation of nuclear facilities.

The most serious accident considered would lead to exposures from twice
to nearly four times the DOE guideline depending upon the site.  The DOE
document claims that once a specific site is chosen, it will then
determine how to bring it into compliance with the regulations. "It is
unacceptable that the DOE has proposed a facility that would violate its
own guidelines," notes Dr. Brice Smith, a research scientist at IEER.

"Without knowing the actual exposures that the DOE will eventually allow
at each location following an accident, it is impossible to accurately
compare the risk they pose to the public."   Additionally, the DOE report
analyzes only a subset of the potential accidents that may occur at an
MPF.

Because the total risk from independent accidents is cumulative, the
draft report offers no basis for determining the actual threat to the
public at any of the proposed sights for pit production .

However, it is not just accidents at an MPF that have the potential for
serious human consequences.

"Normal operation of a 450 pit per year facility would lead to average
worker exposures in excess of the internal DOE recommended administrative
standard at nuclear facilities," notes IEER President Dr. Arjun
Makhijani.

In addition, an examination of the data tables presented in the draft
report indicate that the DOE estimates that over a 40 year operating
period roughly 9 workers will die due to radiation induced cancer.

"This proposed plutonium explosives factory will be dangerous for its
employees," concluded Dr. Makhijani.   The Modern Pit Facility is
supposedly part of the DOE's "Stockpile Stewardship Program" to maintain
the safety and reliability of the U.S. nuclear arsenal. But no problems
that would materially affect the reliability of plutonium pits in the
current U.S. arsenal are identified in the draft report or in the
scientific literature. On the contrary, the results of current research
indicate that aging of pits affects neither the safety nor the
reliability of nuclear weapons.

"Given the remarkably consistent and positive findings of studies
concerning the lack of age-related damage in plutonium, there is no
scientific justification for the claim that pits needs to be replaced
anytime in the foreseeable future," concluded Dr. Smith.

"We have determined from our analysis that even the 20 pit per year
capacity that the DOE hopes to have developed at Los Alamos National
Laboratory by 2007 is likely to be unnecessary, to say nothing of a
massive new facility," adds Dr. Makhijani.   In its discussion of the
case for the MPF, the DOE document wraps itself in the cloak of
"classified analyses." In response, Dr. Makhijani noted that "following
the closure of the Rocky Flats pit production facility in 1989 due to
violations of health, safety, and environmental laws, the Department of
Energy assured the public that classified analysis proved national
security was at risk if the complex remained closed, however the country
has done quite well without Rocky Flats for over a decade."  "Given the
lack of any need for the MPF to maintain the current stockpile, the
likely reason for its development will be to manufacture new pit designs
for new types of weapons," says Dr. Smith.

"The production of new weapons such as the 'mini-nuke' and the
'bunker-buster' is a dangerous drift towards usable nuclear weapons that is
in violation of U.S. commitments under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty,"
adds Dr. Makhijani.

Dr. Makhijani also noted "it is highly unlikely, given current certification
procedures, that pits of new designs would be mass manufactured for
incorporation into the U.S. arsenal unless they were fully tested." This
consideration raises the likelihood of an end to the current U.S. nuclear
test moratorium and the collapse of the international Comprehensive Test Ban
Treaty.

The final public hearing concerning plans to construct the new pit
manufacturing facility is scheduled for today in Washington, D.C.

Previous hearings have been held at locations near each of the five proposed
sites throughout the summer.  It is the conclusion of the IEER analysis that
the "No Action Alternative" is the correct choice and that plans for the
Modern Pit Facility should be scrapped.

IEER's comments on the Modern Pit Facility's Draft Environmental
Impact Statement can be found at http://www.ieer.org/comments/mpf.html

Mining bacteria's appetite for toxic waste 
Researchers try to clean nuclear sites with microbes 

David Perlman, Chronicle Science Editor   
Monday, July 14, 2003   

Scientists are experimenting with some unusual species of bacteria that can
thrive by cleaning up radioactive wastes left over from the Cold War when
nuclear weapons plants across the country were running full blast.

The problem exists wherever uranium has been mined, processed and made into
nuclear bombs. Almost 500 billion gallons of groundwater -- enough to supply
1. 5 million homes for a year -- remain contaminated with uranium and other
toxic chemicals in 36 states, the U.S. Department of Energy estimates.

Another 800 million gallons of waste from uranium mines and weapons plants
lie buried in landfills, trenches and unlined tanks. More than 2 billion
cubic feet of contaminated sediments remain to be cleaned -- a mountain of
radioactive and toxic dirt 2,000 times larger than Egypt's Great Pyramid at
Giza.

For many years, scientists have known about the unusual appetites of some
microbes, including the ability of certain strains to consume uranium and
other deadly poisons. Now researchers are starting to exploit that ability as
a way to clean up nuclear sites, a process called "bioremediation."

STANFORD ENGINEER'S STUDIES Among the experimenters is Craig Criddle, a
Stanford University environmental engineer. He is working with several
classes of microbes that he believes can turn a soluble form of uranium into
an insoluble form. The uranium can precipitate out of the water like sand and
be gathered like a common mineral, he believes.

Next week, Criddle will pursue an experiment at the Oak Ridge National
Laboratory in Tennessee, which produced the uranium for the infamous atom
bomb dropped on Hiroshima, killing almost 80,000 people.

The lab has another legacy. "The nitric acid and uranium oxide waste, a
witch's brew, was dumped into unlined pits there for 31 years and then
covered by a parking lot," Criddle said.

The waste ate its way down into layers of saprolite, a claylike rock, so that
more than 99 percent of it is deep in the soil, he said. The remaining
uranium has contaminated groundwater, a long-term threat to human health,
because the uranium is soluble and moving steadily toward nearby Bear Creek,
which flows through the area.

A complex community of microorganisms thrives by "breathing" oxides of
sulfur, iron, aluminum and even more hazardous compounds like the uranium and
other radioactive elements. As the microbes obtain their oxygen from soluble
uranium oxide, for example, they transform it into a highly insoluble form
called uraninite.

At Oak Ridge, Criddle will be working with several bacteria, including
members of a genus called Desulfovibrio, which numbers more than 30 distinct
species.

Heavy metals such as chromium that were used during the bomb-making era also
pose a human health problem. Similar techniques mobilizing bacteria to remove
chromium, a cancer-causing metal, are also being tested in the Oak Ridge
experiments by a team from UC San Diego's Scripps Institution of
Oceanography, led by marine biologist Bradley Tebo.

Criddle's uranium experiments involve lowering the acidity of the microbes'
environment and nourishing them with ethanol to "get them all happy," as
Criddle says. Doing so encourages them to go to work on the uranium by
reducing oxides of the radioactive uranium and thereby rendering them
insoluble.

Like other researchers in bioremediation, Criddle has support from the
Department of Energy. The agency's program manager, microbiologist Anna
Palmisano, is a former member of the astrobiology group at NASA's Ames
Research Center in Mountain View, seeking microbial analogues on Earth for
possible life on other planets.

"There are wonderful microbes that could be able to help us," Palmisano said.
"But the radioactive elements that are moving into the water are soluble, and 
to get them out, they must be made insoluble."

URANIUM DRIFTING TOWARD RIVER 
Along the Colorado River, about 200 miles west of Denver, is the small town
of Rifle, whose two mines and mills produced almost 17 million tons of
uranium oxide, known as "yellowcake." When the mines shut down about 30 years
ago, they left almost 3 million tons of contaminated uranium tailings.
Uranium dissolved in the water beneath the tailings is moving gradually
toward the Colorado River. Internet maps warn of the Rifle mill site: "No
well drilling or use of groundwater."

After more than a decade of laboratory work, microbiologist Derek Lovley of
the University of Massachusetts at Amherst has built a field site for testing
the ability of a class of microbes, called Geobacters, to attack the uranium
waste problem at the old Rifle mines. Two weeks ago, he began new and large-
scale tests there.

In effect, Lovley and his colleagues have discovered that the Geobacter
bacteria can live or "breathe" in environments where uranium oxides dominate.
They are focusing on the old Rifle mill site to see if they can reduce the
uranium-polluted water to radioactivity levels well below the government's
safety standards.

The genes of Lovley's Geobacter species already have been sequenced by the
Institute for Genomic Research in Rockville, Md., founded by famed scientist
Craig Venter, who raced government scientists to sequence the entire human
genome, and at the Energy Department's Joint Genome Institute, operated in
Walnut Creek by the University of California.

Understanding those genes, according to Lovley, could enable scientists to
engineer new strains of Geobacter even more capable of transforming the
water- soluble forms of uranium into insoluble forms that could be filtered
from streams and underground aquifers.

OTHER MICROBES IN SPOTLIGHT 
Still other strains of microbes are under investigation.
One unique bacterium bears the intriguing name of Deinococcus radiodurans,
meaning "strange berry that withstands radiation." It was discovered by
Oregon radiation researchers in 1956 in a can of meat that had spoiled even
after the meat was sterilized experimentally by intense radiation beams, and
it is by far the most radiation-resistant organism in the world.

Gene-splicers are experimenting to see if the genes of D. radiodurans can be
engineered to produce a new "superbug" that could decontaminate the most
intensely radioactive wastes on Earth -- wastes much more deadly than the
uranium that scientists such as Criddle and Lovley are hoping to clean up. 

E-mail David Perlman at dperlman@sfchronicle.com.

UTPB geologist: Waste dump plan raising questions
By Bob Campbell, Odessa American
07-25-03

A UTPB geologist said he is worried about conflicts between a Texas Tech 
report on a proposed nuclear waste repository site in western Andrews County 
and state and federal maps that show it standing directly over the Ogallala 
aquifer.

Richard Erdlac, who works at the University of Texas of the Permian Basin's 
Center for Energy and Economic Diversification northeast of Odessa, said 
studies by the U.S. Geological Survey and the Bureau of Economic Geology at 
the University of Texas in Austin are at odds with an analysis performed by 
Tech's Water Research Institute.

Erdlac said he is also concerned about differences between the Waste Control 
Specialists plan near Andrews and the U.S. Department of Energy's Waste 
Isolation Pilot Plant (WIPP) site, 26 miles southeast of Carlsbad, N.M.
Referring to a June 22 OA story about the Andrews plan, he said, "When I saw 
the article and looked at the maps, I thought, how can it be that this is not 
in the Ogallala when existing maps in the public domain show it going through 
there? There is a definite conflict of opinion here that needs to be 
reviewed."

Erdlac said Tom Jones, general manager of the low-level radioactive waste 
repository that has already stored 250,000 cubic yards of DOE material, has 
invited him to visit the site 30 miles west of Andrews off Highway 176. He 
plans a "walk-over" inspection at the earliest opportunity.

The operation employs 72 people, many from Andrews.

The geologist said the plan to encase 6 million cubic yards of waste in a 
1,500-square-feet, 75-feet deep pit with reinforced concrete raises the 
specter of the concrete cracking due to temperature extremes or even 
earthquakes.

"Let's face it," Erdlac said. "The concrete will break. The natural heating 
and cooling will eventually cause it to crack, like sidewalks. This is 
strictly my own interest. I have no funding and am not seeking any funding."

While the Waste Control repository will apparently be relatively near the 
surface, he said, the WIPP site is 2,500 feet deep, encased in salt to create 
an impermeable buffer between the waste and underground water deposits.

Erdlac also has questions about the exact nature of the radionuclides to be 
stored in Andrews County. A last-minute amendment by Rep. Buddy West, R-
Odessa, to the bill sponsored by West and Sen. Teel Bivins, R-Amarillo, 
increased allowable high-level waste at the repository from 5,000 cubic yards 
to 600,000 cubic yards.

Jones said he wants the geologist to visit and see the 30 feet of caliche 
over 800 feet of red clay that would keep any leakage from seeping into the 
water table.

He said Tech's Water Research Institute, directed by Ken Rainwater, did a 
study showing the site was not over the Ogallala Aquifer "several years ago" 
and updated it recently for the Andrews Industrial Development Board.

Jones said Permian Basin residents should not worry about an accident and 
waste spill involving a DOE or three-state Waste Compact truck making 
national news and hampering the region's economic development.

In thousands of runs to other waste sites around the nation, he said, there 
have been a few accidents where vehicles ran in front of trucks and were hit 
but no radiation releases.

However, news reports on March 15, 2002, said a tractor-trailer rig carrying 
radioactive medical waste overturned on Interstate 65 in Tennessee. The truck 
hit the Duck River bridge and a guardrail, overturned and spilled waste that 
was carried in cardboard containers.

South of the Columbia-Chapel Hill exit in Maury County, the spill closed I-65 
from 5 a.m. to 2 p.m. that day, reports said. The truck was off-loaded and 
towed, and there was no danger to the public or the environment because the 
radioactivity was low-level, Tennessee emergency management spokesmen said.

Jones said low-level waste would be transported west of Andrews in drums with 
lids held by clamp rings and that high-level material would be in reinforced, 
sealed drums that are impact-resistant.

If Waste Control wins a 15-year license from the Texas Department of Health 
after the bidding period begins next June, Jones said, two Texas Commission 
on Environmental Quality inspectors will work there full-time.

Hance briefs Foundation on permitting process
(Sunday, July 27, 2003

Austin resident and former legislator and congressman Kent Hance updated the
Andrews Industrial Foundation Wednesday, concerning the low-level radioactive
waste bill recently passed by the Texas Legislature.

Hance, representing Waste Control Specialists of Andrews, briefed the
Foundation on the permitting process.  The low-level waste bill, which had
encountered stiff opposition the last three legislative sessions, was finally
approved in May during the 78th Session of the legislation. The bill,
however, still drew criticism from environmental groups and in the Senate,
where it ultimately was passed after 19 amendments were added in a compromise
between challengers, including Sen. Robert Duncan, Republican, of Lubbock,
and bill sponsor Teel Bivins, Republican, of Amarillo.

Hance credited Sen. Bivins and Rep. Buddy West and staffer Julie Williams in
the House with being the mainstays behind the passage of the bill, which
allows a private company to be licensed for operating a low-level facility in
an arid and low-populated environment.

Whatever company receives the permit will be allowed to receive and dispose
of low-level radioactive waste from around Texas and from Vermont, which has
agreed to pay Texas for disposal of its low-level waste.

Hance said WCS would definitely apply for the permit, which includes an
application fee of $500,000, and will take several years to complete. The
permitting process will be done through the Texas Commission on Environmental
Quality, formerly the Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission. WCS is
expected to have a better than average chance of being approved by TCEQ to
hold the license, which also allows the company to receive Department of
Energy Waste.

Hance said other companies would likely also apply for the license, including
Envirocare of Utah, which had owned land in Andrews County before agreeing to
close and leave the state during a lawsuit against the company by WCS.

Hance said Envirocare is applying for the A and B type low-level radioactive
waste, but not the federal waste, which it already accepts at its waste
treatment center in Utah.

Hance said he felt confident WCS could receive the license, but cautioned it
would not be an overnight deal and would no doubt be a lengthy process. He
said part of the reason is the license has to be written and the companies
applying go through a review process.

Hance also discussed other issues involving WCS saying there had been
dialogue with officials with the Waste Isolation Pilot Project (WIPP) near
Carlsbad, N.M. regarding temporary storage of some Trupack containers, which
carry plutonium-contaminated waste from various sites, to the WIPP site in
Eddy County, N.M.

Other dialogue is underway with officials concerning a proposed uranium
enrichment plant to be built five miles east of Eunice, N.M., across the
border from WCSâ site. The plant would concentrate uranium ore to a purity
used in commercial energy generators.

The enriched uranium is used strictly for the generation of electricity and
not for defense purposes.

Several members of the Foundation expressed an interest in WCS having a
public relations person within the community to handle issues and education
on projects.

Foundation member Russell Shannon said the company needed to have someone in
the community that is able to communicate with local residents and others
when needed to explain the details associated with projects, like the low-
level radioactive permit.

Others agreeing with Shannon were Father Bernard Gulley of Our Lady of
Lourdes Catholic Church, retired oilman Darrell Jackson, oilman Brad Bunn,
Ira Lee Brannan, retired CPA, car dealership owner Mike McGarrity, and
Foundation president Lloyd Eisenrich.

http://www.oaoa.com/news/nw072703b.htm

07-27-03
The issues behind the Andrews waste site
By Ruth Friedberg
Odessa American

A state agency is in the process of writing rules for a private company to 
operate a low-level radioactive waste disposal facility.

Environmentalists are still trying to stop the site from being permitted 
citing concerns about water table contamination, transportation and security.
The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality should be ready to take 
proposals from companies by next June, said agency spokeswoman Adria 
Dawidczik.

People can comment on the rules until they are brought before TCEQ 
commissioners on Aug. 6, she said. Area residents can keep up with things on 
the TCEQ Web site.

Once a proposal is decided on, about a year from now, a hearing will be held 
providing another chance for people to comment.

Open for business

Waste Control Specialists already operates a low-level radioactive storage 
facility in western Andrews County and wants to operate a disposal facility 
as well.

Tim Barney, senior vice president with Envirocare in Salt Lake City, Utah, 
said his company will decide in the next few months whether it wants to apply 
for a license to operate a waste facility in Texas as well. Barney said the 
company sold a site to Waste Control Specialists and had an option on another 
site near Monahans which it let expire.

Envirocare currently operates a low-level radioactive waste site about 80 
miles west of Salt Lake City.

Kent Hance, chairman of the Waste Control board, said licensing would take 
three to four years.

Texas lawmakers passed legislation this past session enabling a private 
entity to get a license to dispose of low-level radioactive waste, Hance said.
Hance was in town last week to talk about the status of efforts to get the 
license and offer information about it. He said the process of getting the 
license is "very thorough."

The plan

Hance said the company is applying for one permit for two landfills that 
would operate side by side. One site would be for material from the U.S. 
Department of Energy and the other would be material from Texas, Vermont and 
Maine under the interstate Waste Compact.

Waste Compact material would be mostly medical waste such as boots, rubber 
gloves and suits. Some of the waste would come from nuclear plants. Federal 
waste would be dirt.

Low-level radioactive waste can be transported by dump truck (with a 
covering) or by railroad, said Mike Woodward, an attorney for Waste Control 
Specialists.

Waste Control plans to dig an initial concrete-lined hole 1,500 feet square 
and 75 feet deep. Right below the surface is 800 feet of clay. Hance said 
there are also monitor wells around the site and sump pumps that pump the 
water into a holding well when it rains.

The pit would hold 6 million cubic yards of waste. Only 600,000 cubic yards 
of waste will have high levels of radioactivity.

Hance said Waste Controls would file an application in January, and TCEQ will 
start processing them in July. Hance said both sites would open at the same 
time - probably in 2007.

"It'll be up to the agency. Weâll have to prove we can do it in a manner 
that's safe to the public," Hance said.

He said there are 1,550 sites producing radioactive material and 63 storage 
sites in Texas.

Waste Controlâs storage facility has been operating for six or seven years on 
a permit from the U.S. Department of Energy. It employs 72 people, Hance said.
If it got the disposal facility, that number would rise to 150 to 200 
employees, Hance said.

Jobs wanted

Andrews City Manager Glen Hackler said the community got together eight or 10 
years ago to get this type of industry to the area to help diversify the 
economy. "Community support has been very good," he said, adding that a 
number of delegations have gone to Austin to pursue legislation enabling the 
site.

Hackler said people saw it as a chance to add higher-paying jobs to the 
economy. Lloyd Eisenrich, president of the private, nonprofit Andrews 
Industrial Foundation, said the median per capital income in Andrews was 
about $36,000 a year in the 2000 census.

Community leaders approached Hance when he was a U.S. Congressman to get a 
radioactive storage facility in Andrews County, Eisenrich said.
This was back in the early 1980s when diversification became a big issue and 
oil prices were falling, Eisenrich said.

Susan Jablonski, low-level radioactive waste specialist for TCEQ, said there 
is a lot of public interest in radioactive waste disposal. "We're trying to 
involve as many stakeholders as possible," she said.

The opposition

Fran Sage, conservation chair of the Big Bend Regional Sierra Club, said 
environmentalists are concerned about the state giving up a radioactive waste 
license and letting a private company have it, thereby giving up a certain 
degree of control.

Ken Kramer, state director of the Sierra Club in Austin, said Waste Control 
wants the cheapest type of disposal. "Basically what theyâre going to be 
doing is throwing the stuff in the ground and burying it," Kramer 
said. "They'll profit from it and leave the state of Texas and the taxpayers 
holding the bag."

Hance refuted that claim. He said Waste Control has to put up bonds and 
financial assurance. "We have financial assurance from the first day to take 
care of closing," he said.

Kramer said the Sierra Club would prefer an aboveground facility where waste 
could be removed and rendered harmless as technology changes over the years 
and centuries.

"The Sierra Club is against anything nuclear. The key is this is going to be 
decided by science, not by the emotions of people who know nothing about it 
or choose to ignore the facts," Hance said.

Hance said an aboveground facility would make it easier for someone to steal 
material and would be more subject to tornadoes.

Kramer acknowledges that the Sierra Club has a tough fight to defeat the 
facility, but he said the last 20-plus years have shown "it's not easy" to 
get one of these sites approved.

Water worries

Environmentalists have said the site is over the Ogallala water aquifer, but 
Hance said Waste Controls has drilled more than 100 testing wells and the 
Andrews Industrial Foundation, a nonprofit corporation, hired Texas Tech 
Water Resources Center to do a study. Hance said the study showed the site is 
not over the aquifer. He added that liquids would not be put in the landfill.

Karen Keith, Webmaster for Friends of Ward County, said her grassroots group 
is afraid the radioactive material could leak into the Pecos alluvial 
aquifer. She added that the site is actually five miles outside of Eunice, 
N.M., at the edge of Andrews County. If leakage occurred, she said, it could 
pollute the Pecos River into the Rio Grande.

Sage adds that this is not just a local matter.
"This is not just whether one town in the state of Texas wants this. It's an 
issue for the whole state," Sage said.
 
 
 =========================================================
 
  'Dr Strangeloves' Meet to Plan New Nuclear Era
  By Julian Borger
  The Guardian
  Thursday 07 August 2003

US government scientists and Pentagon officials will gather today behind tight
security at a Nebraska air force base to discuss the development of a
modernized arsenal of small, specialized nuclear weapons which critics believe
could mark the dawn of a new era in proliferation.

This is a confab of Dr Strangeloves. The fact that the Pentagon is barring the
public and congressional staff from this key meeting on US nuclear weapons
policy suggests that the administration seeks to discuss and deliberate on its
policies largely in secret.

The Pentagon has not released a list of the 150 people at the secret meeting,
but according to leaks, they will include scientists and administrators from
the three main nuclear weapons laboratories, Los Alamos, Sandia and Livermore,
senior officers from the air force and strategic command, weapons contractors
and civilian defense officials.

Requests by Congress to send observers were rejected, and an oversight
committee which included academic nuclear experts was disbanded only a few
weeks earlier.

The purpose of the meeting, at Offutt air force base, only became known after a
draft agenda was leaked earlier this year, which included discussions on a new
generation of low-yield "mini-nukes", "bunker-buster" bombs for possible use
against rogue states or organizations armed with nuclear, biological or
chemical weapons.

The session will also debate whether development of the weapons will require
the White House to end the US moratorium on nuclear testing declared in 1992.

Major Michael Shavers, a Pentagon spokesman, said: "We need to change our
nuclear strategy from the cold war to one that can deal with emerging threats."

He said the administration remained committed to the test moratorium (the US
has not ratified the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, but has pledged to observe
it). But he said: "The meeting will give some thought to how we guarantee the
efficacy of the [nuclear] stockpile."

While insisting that it has no plans to resume testing, the administration has
asked Congress for funds for a project that would cut down the amount of time
it would take for the cold war-era test site in Nevada to start functioning
again.

Yesterday, a steady stream of men in summer suits and uniforms arrived at Omaha
airport, to be met by welcoming parties of air force officers and taken to the
Offutt base, 10 miles to the south in the small town of Bellevue.

The lushly-landscaped base, where the gray shell of a B-52 bomber has been
mounted behind a screen of fruit trees, sits atop a labyrinth of high-tech
bunkers from where strategic command is poised, 24 hours a day, to fight a
nuclear war. It inspired the setting for the 1964 film Dr Strangelove. It is
where President George Bush was flown on September 11 2001, when it was thought
that the terrorist attacks could be part of a sustained onslaught on the US.

The place and time of the Offutt meeting is infused with apparently unintended
historical irony. The visitors arrived on the anniversary of the Hiroshima
bombing and the last will be leaving on Saturday, the anniversary of the attack
on Nagasaki. The B-29 planes which dropped those nuclear bombs, Enola Gay and
Bock's Car, were both built at Offutt.

The use of those weapons marked the beginning of the cold war and the first
nuclear age. Today's meeting, many observers believe, could mark the start of a
second.

"This is a confab of Dr Strangeloves," said Daryl Kimball, head of the Arms
Control Association, a national non-partisan membership organization dedicated
to working for arms control.

"The fact that the Pentagon is barring the public and congressional staff from
this key meeting on US nuclear weapons policy suggests that the administration
seeks to discuss and deliberate on its policies largely in secret."

The uncanny echoes of Hiroshima and Nagasaki did not go unnoticed by a handful
of Catholic protesters from Iowa who have gathered at Offutt to mark the
anniversaries for the past 25 years.

Blasphemy

Father Frank Cordaro, the leader of the protest group, said: "This is an
American blasphemy to life and to God. They are going to violate another treaty
by developing small nuclear weapons. We had made the promise not to do these
weapons, but this sole superpower is just ignoring the non-proliferation
treaty. That's madness."

Today's meeting traces its origins to a report by the National Institute for
Public Policy (NIPP) published in January 2001 as the Bush administration took
office. The report argued for a "smaller, more efficient, arsenal" of
specialized weapons. Some deeply buried targets, it argued, could only be
destroyed by "one or more nuclear weapons". Only by developing these new
weapons could the US maintain its deterrent, it said.

Paul Robinson, the head of the Sandia weapons laboratory, who is attending the
Offutt meeting, believes that America's new adversaries would be more
successfully deterred if the line between conventional and nuclear weapons was
blurred.

Senior jobs

He argued in a recent commentary in the Albuquerque Tribune that "military
strategy is evolving to consider combinations of conventional and/or nuclear
attacks for pre-emption or retaliation."

Many of the NIPP report's authors went on to take senior positions in the
administration, including Linton Brooks, head of the national nuclear security
administration which oversees new weapons projects, Stephen Hadley, the deputy
national security adviser, and Stephen Cambone, undersecretary of defense for
intelligence.

The report became the basis for the administration's Nuclear Posture Review in
late 2001 which contemplated the use of nuclear weapons pre-emptively against
rogue states, to destroy stockpiles of nuclear, chemical or biological weapons.

The officials involved in compiling both documents will play a prominent role
at Offutt, but scientists and officials with dissenting views have not been
invited.

"I was specifically told I couldn't come," a congressional weapons expert said.

Greg Mello, the head of the Los Alamos Study Group, a watchdog organization,
said: "There will be tons of contractors there from the weapons labs and the
weapons plants. Contractors can come, but Congress can't."

The Pentagon insists that today's meeting is technical rather than
policy-making, but critics are concerned that it is being used to build up
momentum behind the development of the weapons, despite opposition from
Congress.

"I'm suspicious that further down the road, they're going to say 'this was
decided at Offutt', or 'this comes out of the recommendations at Offutt', a
congressional staff member said.

(In accordance with Title 17 U.S.C. Section 107, this material is distributed
without profit to those who have expressed a prior interest in receiving the
included information for research and educational purposes.)

http://www.tennessean.com/local/archives/03/08/38349126.shtml?Element_ID=38349126
Trousdale County rejected for proposed uranium enrichment plant
August 27, 2003

Trousdale County has been officially rejected for a proposed $1.1
billion uranium enrichment plant by Louisiana Energy Services.

Officials for the international business group will pursue the project
in Eunice, N.M., where officials have pledged hefty tax incentives.
Community support is also strong.

LES announced the decision this morning, ending weeks of speculation
about the project's fate. LES first named Trousdale County as its top
choice last September.

"We have just run out of time to make this work in Tennessee," LES
president Jim Ferland said. "We could not afford to wait for the right
conditions in Trousdale County."

Last month, Trousdale County leaders passed a resolution supporting
tough restrictions on the LES project, including no toxic air or water
emissions and a 90-day storage limit on nuclear waste. LES called the
storage limit a "deal-breaker."

"We didn't want to become another dump," Trousdale County Executive
Jerry Clift said.

The project would have brought about 200 new jobs to Trousdale County,
which still remains a contender for a new state prison.

============================
 
Thursday, 08/28/03 
LES fight over; Trousdale looks to prison 
 
By KELLI SAMANTHA HEWETT
Staff Writer

With yesterday's loss of a proposed $1.1 billion uranium enrichment plant, 
Trousdale County leaders are aiming for a new state prison to bring jobs to 
the struggling county.

A prison announcement is scheduled to come by Sept. 5, according to a state 
Department of Correction spokeswoman, and many county residents are hopeful 
they will win.

"A prison is something that certainly deserves looking into," said Terry 
Sweeton, an LES plant opponent.

Officials for the international business group Louisiana Energy Services 
ended a year of negotiating with the county yesterday by announcing their 
decision to take the uranium enrichment plant to rural Eunice, N.M. In Lea 
County, N.M., $1.8 billion in tax revenue bonds and little public opposition 
await them.

"We have just run out of time to make this work in Tennessee," LES 
President Jim Ferland said in a media release. "We could not afford to wait 
for the right conditions in Trousdale County."

LES spokesman Marshall Cohen said construction could begin in New Mexico by 
early 2007, if all state and federal licenses and permits are secured. New 
Mexico is home to a number of other nuclear-related industries and attempted 
to recruit a LES competitor in 1999.

Leaders from New Mexico rekindled a courtship with LES earlier this year 
after learning about the Tennessee resistance. The official announcement in 
New Mexico is set for Tuesday.

"The public and the political people are 100% behind it, from the federal to 
the state to the county and city," said Eunice Mayor James Brown, whose town 
is heavily dependent on the oil-refining industry.

"We are quite accustomed to living with what is potentially dangerous," 
Brown said.

LES cited restrictions adopted by the Trousdale County Commission last month 
as the reason for moving to New Mexico, but local leaders voiced few regrets.

"We did what we thought was right for the county and Middle Tennessee," 
Trousdale County Executive Jerry Clift said.

Trousdale County became a late contender for the new prison earlier this year 
after leaders expressed an interest in the facility. A similar project faced 
heavy opposition in the 1990s, but the need for jobs and the fear of a 
nuclear-related industry has caused a change of heart among many locals, 
leaders say.

For months Trousdale County commissioners were torn between the prospect of 
210 permanent jobs from the LES plant and its potential environmental risks. 
In July they passed a set of guidelines for the plant that were tougher than 
federal regulations. Key concerns included toxic air and water releases from 
the plant and long-term local storage of nuclear waste.

Trousdale County is about 50 miles northeast of Nashville and discharged 
water would have flowed into the Cumberland River, the source of Nashville's 
drinking water.

"It makes sense where they have chosen," said Bill Rickman, who signed on 
as the county's nuclear expert last year and created the guidelines.

Rickman said the southeast New Mexico site is safer because of the lower 
population in the surrounding areas. The drier climate, Rickman said, also 
reduces the risks stemming from accidental releases or spills.

New Mexico state Sen. Carroll Leavell, who represents Lea County, emphasized 
the local interest in safety.

"New Mexico is not a lax state when it comes to the environment," Leavell 
said. "It's not going to be running loose and free out there."

Middle Tennessee environmental experts are also pleased that the plant issue 
is no longer Tennessee's to address.

"To paraphrase Dr. Martin Luther King, 'Free at last, free at last. Thank 
God almighty, the people of Hartsville are free at last,' " said LES 
opponent Will Callaway of the Tennessee Environmental Council.

For many elected leaders here, the unanswered environmental questions were a 
deciding factor on their positions.

"There was no company in the U.S. that could separate the uranium from the 
gas" for permanent nuclear waste storage, said state Sen. Mae Beavers, R-Mt. 
Juliet, who represents Trousdale County. "It was a pretty easy decision for 
me if they couldn't dispose of the waste."

Kelli Samantha Hewett covers growth issues. Contact her at 726-5938, or 
khewett@tennessean.com.

County supports WCS' low-level permit efforts
(Wednesday, September 10, 2003
Andrews County News
by DON INGRAM
Publisher

Andrews County Commissioners Monday approved a resolution supporting and 
endorsing Waste Control Specialistsâ efforts in obtaining a permit to dispose 
of low-level radioactive waste.

HB 1567, approved by the Texas Legislature last spring, allows a private 
company to be licensed to accept and dispose of low-level radioactive waste 
from sites from across the state.

The passage of the bill was a major accomplishment by supporters of WCS, 
including the Andrews Industrial Foundation, which has supported the company 
from the very outset.

WCS currently employs about 77 people, the majority of which are residents of 
Andrews. If WCS is granted the permit to be come the state's low-level waste 
disposal site, officials believe it would expand the company's payroll and 
lead to other spin-off industries.

The four county commissioners and county judge unanimously adopted Monday's 
resolution of support for WCS, and it is the third resolution of support 
adopted by Andrews County since the inception of the company.

The resolution supports WCSâ efforts to be the state's depository for low-
level radioactive waste within the Texas Compact, which also includes 
Vermont, which will pay the state for accepting their low-level waste.

In addition, HB 1567 allows the private company to accept low-level 
radioactive waste from the Department of Energy and other federal agencies.

"Whereas, the proposed low-level radioactive waste would be disposed of 
pursuant to license and authorization from appropriate state and/or federal 
government authorities as required by law; and whereas, the addition of these 
waste streams added to the WCS facility's capabilities is a welcomed type of 
business within our local regional economy."

"Be it therefore resolved that on the 8th day of September, 2003, the Andrews 
County Commissionersâ Court, meeting in regular session, unanimously endorses 
and supports the efforts and application of Waste Control Specialists LLC for 
licensing for the disposal of Texas Compact and federal agency low-level 
radioactive waste streams."

On hand for the meeting were WCS officials Kent Hance, vice president; Tom 
Jones, general manager; Wesley Burnett, community representative; Joyce 
Orsak, human resources; Mike Woodward, Austin attorney; and Tony Profitt, 
spokesman and public relations.

Hance thanked the court for their support, adding that WCS will continue to 
be a "good corporate citizen," of Andrews County. The company routinely 
donates to local projects, events and scholarships. It's also been a major 
contributor to the Andrews Education Foundation. 

Hance said WCS hopes to be approved for the license from the Texas Commission 
on Environmental Quality and receive the license within two years, which he 
said could result in over a hundred "high-tech" jobs for Andrews County.

The state and Andrews County will each receive five percent of the proceeds 
that WCS receives for the operation, which Hance said should be significant. 
Hance indicated that the uranium plant being proposed for Lea County near the 
state line was helped along by WCSâ location nearby.
 
WCS currently holds licenses to receive and dispose of hazardous waste and to 
receive and store some low-level radioactive waste. It has been in operation 
for seven years and is located 30 miles from Andrews on State Highway 176.
As a condition of HB 1567, applicants must receive approval from the host 
county where the licensee plans to conduct business. 

Other matters
Commissioners also approved hiring the law firm of Perry & Kellogg of San 
Antonio in connection with a lawsuit against oil companies, which allegedly 
underpaid their ad valorem taxes.

Several oil companies reportedly misrepresented their oil values during the 
late 1980s and 1990s, which resulted in the underpayment. The underpayment 
may have amounted to about $12 million.

The court approved several contracts with local health officials in 
connection with services at the Andrews County Health Department. Department 
supervisor Deb McCullough presented the court with a list of several health 
providers that the clinic uses from time to time. 

The providers included doctors Robert W. Garcia, medical director; Brian 
Gordon, Ruben Cala, Satish Nayak, Armand Wiltz, Nagarj Mysorekar, and Natver 
Jariwala. Other health providers included Larry J. Allen, Peggy Thurston, 
Karen Wolters, Nancy Johnson, Darlene Norton, Robert S. Leeper and Kelly J. 
Yarbro.  Also Dennis K. Neely, OD; Robert E. Sears, DDS, Windle Harper, DDS, 
and local pharmacists Jerry Trower, Jerry Jones and Jimmy D. Martin.

The court also approved the purchase of a used 1994 International water truck 
in the amount of $12,527 for Precinct 4. County judge Richard Dolgener 
updated the court on a surprise jail visit by the state jail inspectors last 
Thursday, saying the facility was approved for another year.

New Mexico officials announce LES project
Andrews County News
Sunday, September 07, 2003

A host of dignitaries from New Mexico and others were on hand Tuesday morning 
to officially announce the site for a uranium-enrichment plant just east of 
Eunice, N.M.

The plant is being constructed by Louisiana Energy Services or LES and will 
be located near the Texas-New Mexico border and will produce enriched uranium 
for the country's nuclear power plants.

The project, expected to take about seven years to complete, will likely have 
a large economic impact to Eunice, Lea County and the area, with over 600 
workers expected to construct the facility and around 200 permanent jobs 
thereafter.

On hand for Tuesday's announcement were New Mexico Governor Bill Richardson, 
U.S. Senator Pete Domenici, U.S. Senator Jeff Bigaman, officials with LES, 
Lea County, Westinghouse, the Department of Energy and others.

LES officials decided to go with the Eunice, N.M. site because of a more 
favorable economic package and other incentives. The company had been looking 
at a site in Tennessee before deciding on the Eunice site, located about four 
miles east of Eunice on SH 176. 

Jim Ferland, president of LES, said he was greatly impressed with the way New 
Mexico officials had sought the company for diversifying the area. He said 
LES would be a "good corporate citizen to Eunice, Lea County and New Mexico."
Ferland said the project would use state-of-the-art technology and produce 
enriched uranium for nuclear power plants at a competitive price. He said a 
similar operation in Europe had a spotless reputation and had been in 
operation for over 30 years.

Both Gov. Richardson and Sen. Domenici expressed optimism that the plant 
would bring jobs and an economic revitalization to Southeastern New Mexico. 
The project is expected to cost about $1.2 billion to construct and have an 
annual payroll of $20 million.

The permitting part of the project will take three or four years, followed by 
the construction phase. Ferland said permanent workers would be brought in 
before the actual construction is completed.

Invited guests from Andrews attending the ceremonies included Andrews 
Industrial Foundation President Lloyd Eisenrich, Wesley Burnett, community 
relations for Waste Control Specialists, Tom Jones, WCS Manager, Joyce Orsak, 
WCS, Andrews City Manager Glen Hackler, Andrews Mayor Bob Zap, city 
councilman Brad Bunn, Andrews County Judge Richard Dolgener, and Don Ingram, 
Andrews County News.

State pushes ahead nuclear waste plan 
September 9, 2003
Rutland Daily Herald
By Darren Allen

Montpelier - Vermont officials are planning to pay $12.5 million next month 
toward construction of a radioactive waste dump that might never be built. 
Under legislation passed 10 years ago, Vermont joined with Maine and Texas in 
an agreement under which the two New Enlgand states would pay $27.5 million 
each to send low-level radioactive waste to Texas, which was to find a site 
for disposing of it. Maine dropped out of the compact last year.

The legislation came in response to a federal law that said in essence that 
the federal government would take responsibility for disposing of high-level 
waste - mainly spent nuclear fuel - while the states would take 
responsibility for low-level waste. Low-level waste presents a wide range of 
hazards, depending on the source and type of radiation, according to 
information published on the Nuclear Regulatory Commission Web site.

"The radioactivity can range from just above background levels found in 
nature to very highly radioactive in certain cases, such as parts from inside 
a reactor vessel in a nuclear power plant," the Web site says.

Vermont ships the lowest of its low-level waste to a private firm's disposal 
site in Utah. The more highly radioactive of the low-level waste is shipped 
to Barnwell, SC, to a site that will be closed in 2008. More than 98 percent 
of Vermont's low-level waste comes from the Vermont Yankee nuclear power 
plant in Vernon, with tiny amounts coming from the University of Vermont, 
Middlebury College, and the Veteran's Administration Hospital in White River 
Junction.

Texas first focused on a potential site in the southwestern part of the 
state, about 90 miles from El Paso, but the proposed Sierra Blanca site 
failed to win needed permits. Earlier this year, Texas lawmakers authorized 
another search for a site, and included in the legislation the requirements 
that other compact states - for now, only Vermont - make a $12.5 million 
payment by Nov. 1. Vermont law allows the state in turn to bill its waste 
generators for that amount on a proportional basis. 

Monday, Auditor of Accounts Elizabeth Ready told the Legislature's Joint 
Fiscal Committee, which reviews budgetary matters when the full legislature 
is not in session, that it and other state officials should ask lots of 
questions before sending Texas the $12.5 million.

"If Texas if unable to cause the site to be built, what would happen with the 
$12.5 million?" she asked during testimony to the committee. 

Ready said in a later interview that she is concerned that Vermont Yankee's 
owners, Entergy Nuclear, might balk at making additional payments if the 
first didn't result in a site's being opened. At that point, under federal 
law, the onus would be back on the state to dispose of the waste she said.

William Sherman, nulcear engineer with the state Deparment of Public Service, 
confirmed Ready's understanding of federal law but he expressed confidence 
that Texas would be able to build the facility.

"It's our firm expectation that they will develop a site," Sherman told the 
committee.

Ready noted that none of the other multi-state compacts around the country 
had been able to build a disposal site, and said some had been dissolved. She 
said environmental groups in Texas were raising questions abou the newest 
proposal site in west Texas. 

Robert Williams, spokesperson for Vermont Yankee and Entergy, said his 
company's only interest was that low-level waste not be disposed of in 
Vermont and that it be disposed of in a safe way.

"Compact participation and payments, and things like that - those decisions 
would be made by state governments," Williams said.

Tuesday, September 16, 2003
Fun with fusion: 
Freshman's nuclear fusion reactor has USU physics faculty in awe 
By Alan Edwards Deseret Morning News

      LOGAN - A widespread belief among physicists nowadays is that modern 
science requires squadrons of scientists and wildly expensive equipment.
Craig Wallace and Philo T. Farnsworth are putting the lie to all that.

Spanish Fork High graduate Craig Wallace shows off his nuclear fusion 
reactor, based on the plans of Utah's own Philo Farnsworth, the inventor of 
TV.

Wallace, a baby-faced tennis player fresh out of Spanish Fork High 
School, had almost the entire physics faculty of Utah State University 
hovering (and arguing) over an apparatus he had cobbled together from parts 
salvaged from junk yards and charity drops.

The apparatus is nothing less than the sine qua non of modern science: 
a nuclear fusion reactor, based on the plans of Utah's own Philo Farnsworth, 
the inventor of television.

The reactor sat on a table with an attached vacuum pump wheezing away. 
A television monitor showed what was inside: a glowing ball of gas surrounded 
by a metal helix.

The ball is, literally, a small sun, where an electric field forces 
deuteron ions (a form of hydrogen) to gather, bang together and occasionally 
fuse, spitting out a neutron each time fusion occurs.

"Here I am with this thing here," Wallace mused, looking at his 
surroundings. "Who'da thought?"

Wallace and Farnsworth are much alike. Both are (or were ÷ Farnsworth 
died in 1971) tinkerers. While Wallace was in grade school, his mother got a 
flat tire while he was riding with her. He fixed it. For his part, Farnsworth 
began improvising electric motors at a young age. Both went on to bigger and 
better things.

"He was never motivated to take science," said Wallace's father, Allen 
Wallace. "It was really the tinkering that motivated him."

When Craig was a sophomore in high school, browsing the Internet he 
discovered that Farnsworth had come up with a way to create deuteron ion 
plasma, a prerequisite to fusion.

While it was not good for production of energy (the source of much 
embarrassment to the University of Utah in the cold fusion debacle in the 
late 1980s), Farnsworth's design did emit neutrons, a useful tool for 
commercial applications and scientific experimentation.

USU freshman physics major Craig Wallace, center, demonstrates his experiment 
to USU professors John Raitt, left, and Farrell Edwards.

Jeffrey D. Allred, Deseret Morning News 

"He (Farnsworth) was after the Holy Grail of excess energy, but 
everyone agrees that it's mostly useful as a neutron generator," Allen 
Wallace said.

About 30 such devices exist around the country, owned by such entities 
as Los Alamos National Laboratories, NASA and universities. ("I bet I'm the 
only high school student that has one," Craig Wallace said.)

Looking at Farnsworth's plans for the first time, Craig and his father 
both had the same thought: Now there's a science project.

They set to work. They found a neutron detector in an Idaho Falls scrap 
metal yard. Craig built a neutron modulator (which slows down the emitted 
neutrons so they can be detected) out of a few hundred spare CDs. They found 
a broken turbo molecular pump lying forgotten at Deseret Industries.

Too poor to buy pricey deuterium gas, Craig bought a container of 
deuterium oxide, or heavy water, for 20 bucks and came up with a way to make 
it a gas and get rid of the accompanying oxygen by passing it over heated 
magnesium filings.

Not bad for a backyard amateur who considered himself more mechanic 
than scientist.

"I teased him that he was now officially a science geek," Allen Wallace 
said.

One professor Friday stood nervously away from Wallace's reactor ÷ 
which is notably free from any shielding ÷ but he needn't have worried: 
Wallace's detector measures 36 neutrons per minute just in background 
radiation from space, and the device's usual output adds only four neutrons 
per minute. People in airplanes absorb much more than that.

It took two years of gathering materials and six months of assembly, 
but the final product actually, incongruously, works.

"(This was) the day I achieved a Poisser plasma reaction," Wallace 
wrote next to a picture of the glowing ball. "Probably the coolest thing I 
have ever seen."

Others thought it was cool, too. Wallace began winning contests ÷ 
local, state, national ÷ culminating in second place in the International 
Intel Science and Engineering Fair last May in Cleveland. He's now beginning 
work on a USU physics degree.

"The whole thing combines chemistry, engineering, physics," he 
said. "Put them all together and you come out with something pretty sweet."

Farnsworth would have been proud.

http://albany.bizjournals.com/albany/stories/2003/09/29/daily10.html?

September 30, 2003
Assemblyman urges inquiry into National Lead site
Eric Durr- The Business Review

State Assemblyman Robert Prentiss (R-Colonie) is urging the Federal Agency 
for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry to launch a public health 
assessment of the National Lead Company industrial site in Albany, N.Y. 

The assessment would be useful in a class action lawsuit under consideration 
by Albany-area residents against National Lead's successor company, Houston, 
Texas-based NL Industries Inc., Prentiss said. 

The Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry recently completed a 
health consultation draft report on health risks related to the National Lead 
site at 1130 Central Ave. In that report the agency said there could be a 
link to pollution on the site and lung cancer and kidney disease. 

National Lead purchased the 11.2 acre site from Magnus Metal Company In 1937 
and operated a brass foundry at the location. After World War II the company 
began casting aluminum aircraft frames there, according to the Environmental 
Protection Agency. 

In 1958, the nuclear division of National Lead began producing items 
manufactured from uranium and thorium under a license from the Atomic Energy 
Commission. Operation of the brass foundry ended in 1960. 

>From 1958 to 1984 the company used radioactive materials consisting mostly of 
depleted uranium. But smaller amounts of thorium and enriched uranium were 
also used between 1960 and 1972. 

The company reduced depleted uranium tetrafluoride to depleted uranium metal 
which was then made into shielding components, ballast weights, and 
projectiles. In addition, from 1966 to 1972, National Lead manufactured fuel 
from enriched uranium for experimental nuclear reactors. 

In 1984 the state shut down the company's operations because of airborne 
releases of radioactive materials that exceeded court-ordered standards. 

In 1979 scientists at Knolls Atomic Power Laboratory in Schenectady, N.Y., 
discovered traces of depleted uranium 26 miles away from the National Lead 
plant that could only have come from that facility, said former Knolls 
research Leonard Dietz, a retired physicist. Air filters installed at the 
Navy's nuclear reactor training facility in Malta, N.Y., were contaminated 
with material from the National Lead site, he said. 

While the Army Corps of Engineers is cleaning up the Central Avenue location, 
federal officials need to examine the potential health risks that could have 
been caused by depleted uranium emissions from the plant, Prentiss said. 

He has a list of 100 names of area residents who have unusual health problems 
that could be related to the National Lead site, Prentiss said. A New York 
City-based environmental law firm is looking at the potential for a class 
action lawsuit, the Assemblyman said. 

Prentiss said he could not yet name the firm that was considering the 
lawsuit. 

One of those who would join the class action is Albany resident Ron Russo, 
who is suffering from kidney disease, a rare form of lung cancer, and 
diabetes. 

As a child he lived four blocks away from the National Lead plant and he and 
his friends used to play on and around the site, Russo said. His mother died 
of lung disease and renal failure, and his father died of kidney disease and 
lung disease, Russo said. 

He's convinced that his illnesses and those of his parents are related to the 
National Lead site. 

"They just didn't care then," the 48-year old Russo said. 

edurr@bizjournals.com | 518-640-6808
