Vt. must pay for nuclear waste site
October 3, 2003
By DAVID MACE Vermont Press Bureau 

MONTPELIER - Vermont has little choice but to pay Texas $12.5 million to 
develop a low-level radioactive waste dump that Vermont may use, the attorney 
general's office said. 

But some lawmakers want Gov. James Douglas to re-negotiate the deal. 

While acknowledging it's Douglasâ call to make, the Legislature's Joint 
Fiscal Committee voted Friday to advise him to see if he can persuade Texas 
to let Vermont withhold the money until Texas actually has a site permitted. 

Senate President Pro Tem Peter Welch, D-Windsor, the committee's chairman, 
questioned whether the first of two payments should be sent when Texas has 
been unable to find an acceptable site for the waste dump and won't have to 
give the money back if it can't. 

"If the money is sent, and there's no licensed facility, that (money) will 
not be available to pay for a site that might be licensed," Welch said. 

The questions about whether Vermont should stick with its Texas deal were 
raised last month by State Auditor Elizabeth Ready, who said several 
conditions of the multi-state agreement had changed and asked whether the 
state should re-evaluate its participation. 

Ready questioned whether Vermont should make the payment because: 

- The new site hasn't been approved and is under fire from environmentalists. 

- A private company with designs on opening a dump that would take both low-
level civilian and military waste is apparently involved in the new site. 

- The new law could conflict with the language of the compact that protects 
Vermont from liability for the dump site. 

Vermont joined the multi-state compact with Maine and Texas in 1993. Congress 
approved the plan for Maine and Vermont to ship their low-level waste -
contaminated equipment and clothing from nuclear power plants and a small 
amount of radioactive medical waste - to Texas in 1998. 

Federal law says states that build a nuclear waste dump must allow other 
states to put their waste in it unless they are part of such a compact. So 
the deal was seen as mutually beneficial because Texas could deny other 
states access to their dump in exchange for taking waste from two small 
states that produced little waste of their own. 

However, Maine pulled out of agreement last year because the state shut down 
its only reactor, Maine Yankee, in 1998 and found other places to put its 
waste. 

A new law passed in Texas this year sets up a process for locating a new 
site, including by private developers, and demands the first $12.5 million no 
later than Nov. 1. 

Entergy's Vermont Yankee nuclear plant will be responsible for paying almost 
all of the money, with a small amount coming from hospitals and other 
sources. 

Yankee cannot raise the rates it charges customers to make back the money, 
but has maintained that its the government's decision about whether to stay 
in the compact. 

In September, the committee sought a ruling from the Vermont attorney 
general's office, which said the state had little choice but to pay the money 
under the compact, which is federal law. 

The opinion by Assistant Attorney General William Rice said virtually all of 
Ready's fears were misplaced, and that Texas could sue or throw Vermont out 
of the compact if it failed to pay. Rice also gave a glum assessment of 
Vermont's chances of winning a court fight, noting that its defenses would be 
weak. 

"Although we believe that these defenses could be raised in good faith, we 
are not optimistic of their chances of success," he wrote. 

He noted that if Vermont were kicked out of the compact, it would still be 
obligated to find some place to dispose of its nuclear waste. 

That point wasn't lost on Senate Minority Leader John Bloomer, R-Rutland. 

"If you back out of Texas, you'd better have another plan," he told Welch and 
other Democrats who were questioning the deal Friday. 

Bloomer ultimately agreed that it wouldn't hurt to ask Texas if theyâd let 
Vermont hold off on the payment until the site was licensed. 

"The administration believes that we are contractually required to make the 
payment under the terms of the agreement.  However, we will make the 
inquiries the joint fiscal committee recommended," said Douglasâ press 
secretary, Jason Gibbs. "Weâll ask, but we know we have to pay."

Afterward, Ready said she still had reservations about the deal. 

"My whole sense of this is Vermont is pouring this money down a rat hole, and 
it's a nasty nuclear rat hole," she said. "I hope I'm wrong about this, and 
they're right." 

Susan Jablonski, radioactive waste specialist with the Texas Commission on 
Environmental Quality, said the state is making rules for how applications to 
build and run the site will be handled, and recently took public comment on 
the matter. 

In other business Friday, the Joint Fiscal Committee approved the compromise 
between House and Senate budget leaders and the Douglas administration to 
save the jobs of nine of the 29 workers in the Department of Employment and 
Training who were slated to be laid off. 

Some committee membersâ frustration about the cuts remained, and officials 
with the Vermont State Employees Association, the state employees union, 
continued to call for saving the remaining jobs. But the committee ultimately 
signed off on the plan. 

The administration had proposed laying off the workers earlier this summer, 
saying that a $1 million cut in federal funding and an equal increase in 
payroll expenses jeopardized DET's Jobs and Training Division. They 
ultimately found $300,000 in the state's social welfare department that would 
bring in a matching amount from the federal government. 

"It makes no sense," Welch said of the cut, arguing that with unemployment 
still a problem the workers were needed now more than ever. 

"It's not anything that any of us want to do," said Rep. Richard Westman, R-
Cambridge, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee. "We don't have the 
authority at this point to raise taxes." 

Contact David Mace at david.mace@timesargus.com.

Fort Worth Star Telegram, TX - Oct 4, 2003
Vermont lawmakers seek to re-negotiate Texas nuclear waste deal
Associated Press

MONTPELIER, Vt. - Vermont has little choice but to pay Texas $12.5 million to 
develop a low-level radioactive waste dump, the attorney general's office 
said.

But some lawmakers want Gov. James Douglas to re-negotiate the deal.

see if he can persuade Texas to let Vermont withhold the money until Texas 
actually has a site permitted.

"The administration believes that we are contractually required to make the 
payment under the terms of the agreement," said Jason Gibbs, Douglas' press 
secretary. "However, we will make the inquiries the joint fiscal committee 
recommended. We'll ask, but we know we have to pay."

Senate President Pro Tem Peter Welch, D-Windsor, the committee's chairman, 
questioned whether the first of two payments should be sent when Texas has 
been unable to find an acceptable site for the waste dump and won't have to 
give the money back if it can't.

The questions about whether Vermont should stick with its Texas deal were 
raised last month by State Auditor Elizabeth Ready, who said several 
conditions of the multistate agreement had changed and asked whether the 
state should re-evaluate its participation.

Vermont joined the multistate compact with Maine and Texas in 1993. Congress 
approved the plan for Maine and Vermont to ship their low-level waste - 
contaminated equipment and clothing from nuclear power plants and a small 
amount of radioactive medical waste - to Texas in 1998.

The deal was seen as mutually beneficial because Texas could deny other 
states access to their dump in exchange for taking waste from two small 
states that produced little waste of their own.

However, Maine pulled out of the agreement last year because the state shut 
down its only reactor, Maine Yankee, in 1998 and found other places to put 
its waste.

A new law passed in Texas this year sets up a process for locating a new 
site, including by private developers, and demands the first $12.5 million no 
later than Nov. 1.

Vermont Assistant Attorney General William Rice said Texas could sue or throw 
Vermont out of the compact if it failed to pay.

That point wasn't lost on Senate Minority Leader John Bloomer, R-Rutland.

"If you back out of Texas, you'd better have another plan," he told Welch and 
other Democrats who were questioning the deal Friday.

Bloomer ultimately agreed that it wouldn't hurt to ask Texas if they'd let 
Vermont hold off on the payment until the site was licensed.

Afterward, Ready said she still had reservations about the deal.

"My whole sense of this is Vermont is pouring this money down a rat hole, and 
it's a nasty nuclear rat hole," she said. "I hope I'm wrong about this, and 
they're right."

=========================================================================
Des Moines Register
Dean role in accord on waste assailed
The former Vermont governor says he was just following a federal requirement.
By THOMAS BEAUMONT
Register Staff Writer
10/05/2003

A 1993 agreement to send Vermont nuclear waste to Texas has resurfaced a 
decade later in a political attack by Massachusetts Sen. John Kerry on a 
chief rival for the 2004 Democratic presidential nomination, former Vermont 
Gov. Howard Dean.

Kerry said last week that Dean showed environmental and ethnic insensitivity 
when he signed a compact to allow Vermont and Maine to send low-level nuclear 
waste to the largely Hispanic west Texas town of Sierra Blanca.

Kerry's attack comes as Dean's chief rivals in the early nominating states of 
Iowa and New Hampshire - where Dean leads in polls - seek to link the former 
governor with more conservative positions than his liberal stances now 
suggest.

Dean has defended the compact by saying that Vermont was responding to a 
federal requirement that states dispose of their nuclear waste and that his 
state had no role in choosing the site.

A Texas environmental agency ultimately blocked the nuclear waste dump from 
being built there.

Environmentalists in Texas and Vermont said Dean did nothing to urge Texas to 
reconsider the location, despite an outcry from environmental and Latino 
activists and Democrats in Congress.

They also said there was little Dean could have done about the site selection 
because that was Texas' legal responsibility.

"I fought against Howard Dean on this for a long time, but the bottom line is 
the federal government gave states title to nuclear waste," said former 
Vermont state Sen. Elizabeth Ready, an anti-nuclear activist. "Even though I 
unalterably opposed the position of my own governor, what would Kerry have 
done if he had a legal obligation?"

Ready, a Democrat, is now Vermont's state auditor and supports Dean's 
presidential bid.

Kerry's attack comes less than four months before the Jan. 19 Iowa caucuses. 
It seeks to implicitly discredit Dean's claim to the mantle of the late 
Minnesota Sen. Paul Wellstone, who called the attempt to bury nuclear waste 
at Sierra Blanca "environmental racism."

Congress passed the compact in 1997 and President Clinton signed it, over the 
objections of Wellstone, environmentalists and the nuclear power company that 
would have been the main contributor to the site. Kerry and Wellstone were 
among 15 senators who voted against the measure.

The compact had been rejected two years earlier in the U.S. House, in part 
because of concerns that the site is geologically unstable and close enough 
to the Rio Grande to pose a serious pollution threat.

As controversial was the fact that Sierra Blanca, a town of about 500 
residents 16 miles from the Mexican border, is overwhelmingly Hispanic.

"People who were involved in the fight over Sierra Blanca considered it an 
environmental justice issue," said Margot Clarke, outreach coordinator for 
the Texas Sierra Club, an environmental group that opposed placing the dump 
at Sierra Blanca.

In 1993, Dean signed the agreement with then-Gov. Ann Richards of Texas to 
store the low-level nuclear waste from Vermont's one nuclear power plant in 
Texas. Two years earlier, the Texas Legislature had identified Sierra Blanca 
as the preferred site.

But Dean, who left office after his term ended last year, said the agreement 
did not specify where the waste would be stored.

"The Texas agreement did not say the waste would go to Sierra Blanca," Dean 
said in an interview last week with The Des Moines Register. "This was really 
Texas' call where they wanted to send the waste."

Dean said the issue doesn't stand out as a divisive one. He signed the 
agreement with Texas, which Maine later joined, after the Vermont Legislature 
passed it. The Vermont House was controlled by Democrats, the Senate by 
Republicans.

"I don't remember a big fight about this," he said. "There could have been 
one. I just don't remember."

Kerry, who first raised the issue while campaigning in Texas last week, said 
Dean should have objected to the site.

"They should not ship nuclear waste to a Latino community where they don't 
have the clout," Kerry said in a telephone interview Saturday. "Howard Dean 
knew that was the site, and he never stood up and said, "Don't go there." "

David Frederick, a Texas lawyer who represented opponents of the waste-
storage plan, said Vermont and Maine officials entered the agreement knowing 
Texas lawmakers had chosen Sierra Blanca as the site two years earlier.

"It was a case of picking on the weakest among us to receive their trash," 
Frederick said. "Now that's not the whole argument, but if either Vermont or 
Maine felt sufficiently strong about it, they could have weighed in. But they 
did not. They explicitly supported Texas' decision."

Vermont environmentalists lobbied the state geologist and nuclear engineer, 
both of whom supported sending the waste to Sierra Blanca. Vermont Sierra 
Club President Lea Terhune said activists met with Dean's staff but believed 
they would have had to influence a small number of experts to sway Dean.

"I was annoyed at the time and was kind of bothered by the fact that he 
didn't seem to care," Terhune said. "But he was never cozy with 
environmentalists. He's not really cozy with anybody. He wasn't our boy, but 
he wasn't anybody's boy."

The Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission rejected the application 
for the permit to build the dump at Sierra Blanca in 1998, citing geological 
instability. The waste ultimately was shipped to South Carolina, according to 
Dean.

Environmental activists say then-Gov. George W. Bush's re-election campaign 
in Texas and possible presidential hopes may have influenced the Bush-
appointed commission to avoid a potentially ethnically charged political land 
mine.

Kerry has tried to link Dean with Bush on the deal, although its signing 
predated Bush's governorship. Dean and Bush were serving as governors at the 
time the issue was before Congress in 1997.

"Nevertheless, Howard Dean and George W. Bush went ahead with their 
agreement," Kerry said. "Paul Wellstone and I fought against it."

Dean, taking a line from the late Minnesota liberal, has said he 
represents "the Democratic wing of the Democratic Party."

Kerry's attack is the second in the last month in which one of Dean's rivals 
has tried to associate him with Republicans.

Last month, Rep. Dick Gephardt of Missouri linked Dean to former Republican 
House Speaker Newt Gingrich for Dean's support of cutting Medicare in 1995. 
Dean has said he favored the cuts to save the federal health insurance 
program from insolvency.

"The candidates from Washington are trying to put Governor Dean in a box with 
right-wing Republicans because they stood with President Bush on the war with 
Iraq. They recognize that's a weakness," Dean spokeswoman Sarah Leonard said 
Saturday of Kerry's attack. Dean opposed the war; Kerry and Gephardt voted 
for the resolution in Congress that allowed it.

Recent polls show Gephardt's support in Iowa is second to that of Dean. 
Gephardt, who won the 1988 caucuses, has predicted he will win the 2004 
caucuses.

Kerry is the closest rival behind Dean in New Hampshire, where the Jan. 27 
primary is considered a must win for New Englanders. 

==================================

State pushes ahead nuclear waste plan 
September 9, 2003
Rutland Daily Herald
By Darren Allen

Montpelier - Vermont officials are planning to pay $12.5 million next month 
toward construction of a radioactive waste dump that might never be built. 
Under legislation passed 10 years ago, Vermont joined with Maine and Texas in 
an agreement under which the two New Enlgand states would pay $27.5 million 
each to send low-level radioactive waste to Texas, which was to find a site 
for disposing of it. Maine dropped out of the compact last year.

The legislation came in response to a federal law that said in essence that 
the federal government would take responsibility for disposing of high-level 
waste - mainly spent nuclear fuel - while the states would take 
responsibility for low-level waste. Low-level waste presents a wide range of 
hazards, depending on the source and type of radiation, according to 
information published on the Nuclear Regulatory Commission Web site.

"The radioactivity can range from just above background levels found in 
nature to very highly radioactive in certain cases, such as parts from inside 
a reactor vessel in a nuclear power plant," the Web site says.

Vermont ships the lowest of its low-level waste to a private firm's disposal 
site in Utah. The more highly radioactive of the low-level waste is shipped 
to Barnwell, SC, to a site that will be closed in 2008. More than 98 percent 
of Vermont's low-level waste comes from the Vermont Yankee nuclear power 
plant in Vernon, with tiny amounts coming from the University of Vermont, 
Middlebury College, and the Veteran's Administration Hospital in White River 
Junction.

Texas first focused on a potential site in the southwestern part of the 
state, about 90 miles from El Paso, but the proposed Sierra Blanca site 
failed to win needed permits. Earlier this year, Texas lawmakers authorized 
another search for a site, and included in the legislation the requirements 
that other compact states - for now, only Vermont - make a $12.5 million 
payment by Nov. 1. Vermont law allows the state in turn to bill its waste 
generators for that amount on a proportional basis. 

Monday, Auditor of Accounts Elizabeth Ready told the Legislature's Joint 
Fiscal Committee, which reviews budgetary matters when the full legislature 
is not in session, that it and other state officials should ask lots of 
questions before sending Texas the $12.5 million.

"If Texas if unable to cause the site to be built, what would happen with the 
$12.5 million?" she asked during testimony to the committee. 

Ready said in a later interview that she is concerned that Vermont Yankee's 
owners, Entergy Nuclear, might balk at making additional payments if the 
first didn't result in a site's being opened. At that point, under federal 
law, the onus would be back on the state to dispose of the waste she said.

William Sherman, nulcear engineer with the state Deparment of Public Service, 
confirmed Ready's understanding of federal law but he expressed confidence 
that Texas would be able to build the facility.

"It's our firm expectation that they will develop a site," Sherman told the 
committee.

Ready noted that none of the other multi-state compacts around the country 
had been able to build a disposal site, and said some had been dissolved. She 
said environmental groups in Texas were raising questions abou the newest 
proposal site in west Texas. 

Robert Williams, spokesperson for Vermont Yankee and Entergy, said his 
company's only interest was that low-level waste not be disposed of in 
Vermont and that it be disposed of in a safe way.

"Compact participation and payments, and things like that - those decisions 
would be made by state governments," Williams said.

http://www.andrewscountynews.com/news/get-news.asp?id=1515&catid=1&cpg=get-
news.asp
New WCS official visits in Andrews
(Thursday, October 09, 2003

Local officials Monday met with the new chief operating officer of Waste 
Control Specialists.

George Dials of Albuquerque, N.M. was named the president and COO of WCS 
replacing Shaun E. McCabe.

Dials, a graduate of MIT with a degree in nuclear engineering, was manager of 
the Carlsbad Area Office of the Department of Energy during the early 
development of the Waste Isolation Pilot Plant (WIPP) 30 miles east of 
Carlsbad. 

Dials, and WCS Chairman Kent Hance, met with members of the Andrews 
Industrial Foundation and others concerning the companyâs goal in obtaining a 
permit to treat and dispose of the stateâs low-level radioactive waste.
A bill passed by the Texas Legislature this past session allows for a private 
company to hold the license for the stateâs depository for low-level 
radioactive waste.

The bill also allows the company to handle similar waste from the Department 
of Energy. WCS already operates a hazardous waste facility 30 miles west of 
Andrews on SH 176.

Dials, a West Point graduate who was decorated with the Silver Star during 
the Viet Nam War, has past experience in nuclear-related businesses, 
including being the former president of the Louisiana Energy Services, the 
company which proposes to build a $2 billion uranium-enrichment plant just 
east of Eunice, N.M. near the Texas border on SH 176.

Dials, who had only been on the job for a few days, said he was excited to be 
working for WCS and majority owner Harold Simmons of Dallas.

Hance said Dialsâ experience in the business and with working with the 
Department of Energy and other agencies would be an important asset in WCS 
being licensed by the Texas Commission of Environmental Quality.

Hance said he had wanted the best in the business and felt Dials represented 
that in the field of handling low-level radioactive waste. Hance said Dialsâ 
experience would also greatly aid the business side of operating the plant.

Dials said WCS was a quality waste facility and would continue to be a top-
notch facility when permitted by the state as the low-level radioactive waste 
depository. Dials said he believed in being up-front with people, including 
the public, and would continue to do so regarding WCS and its activities.

Dials said he felt WCS would be successful in being licensed by the state and 
that the additional workload would result in a better company and more jobs 
at the plant. He said the company would continue to be active in the 
community.

Dials plans to live in Dallas where the corporate headquarters is located for 
WCS, but said he plans to be in Andrews and at the site a lot in the coming 
months and years.

NRC on fact-finding mission in area; meet locally
(Sunday, October 05, 2003

Officials with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) visited in Andrews 
Friday about the proposed uranium-enrichment plant in Lea County.

The NRC members were in Andrews after visiting in other communities in New 
Mexico, including Eunice, N.M., Hobbs, N.M. and Tatum, N.M.
The tour was an initial fact-finding mission, the first of probably many 
other visits to New Mexico, which will include public meetings and a hearing 
concerning the project.

The NRC officials said they were in Andrews because of the communityâs 
proximity to the site where the plant would be constructed. 
New Mexico officials last month announced the project during a press 
conference at the site, where state and national legislators touted the plant 
for its potential to bring economic diversification to southeastern New 
Mexico.

Louisiana Energy Services is seeking a license from the NRC for a uranium 
enrichment plant east of Eunice near the Texas-New Mexico border. The site 
was evidently chosen because a similar enrichment project was proposed 
several years ago when preliminary work was completed on the location, 
including site characterization. 

Local, county, state and national representatives also drew LES to the region 
because of their warm reception.

Basically, the plant will produce enriched uranium for nuclear power plants 
through a process, which is already used successfully in the Netherlands.
The NRC is neither a proponent nor opponent of the project, but is the 
licensing agent. LES has submitted plans for the gas centrifuge enrichment 
facility, which would cost about $1.2 billion and take about seven years to 
complete.

During the construction, LES would employ about 600 workers and around 200 
permanent jobs thereafter.

On hand for the meeting were Timothy C. Johnson, Office of Nuclear Material 
Safety, Brian W. Smith, chief special project secretary, and Melanie C. Wong, 
all of Washington, D.C.

Locals attending the meeting included Andrews Industrial Foundation president 
Lloyd Eisenrich, Andrews Mayor Bob Zap, Industrial Foundation member Russell 
Shannon, Andrews City Manager Glen Hackler and Andrews County Judge Richard 
Dolgener.

Also attending were WCS representatives Tom Jones, plant manager, and WCS 
community relations specialist Wesley Barnett.

Johnson said that among the NRCâs main goals would be an evaluation of the 
proposed plant regarding safety for the public and the workers.
The delegation said there would be additional meetings in the future at 
communities likely to the affected by the plant. Wong said ãscopingä sessions 
would determine concerns from the public about safety issues and other 
related concerns.

Information collected during the meetings would be used by the NRC to 
formulate an environmental impact study, critical in the issuance of the 
license for the LES.

A hearing concerning the assessment would likely be held in Eunice or in 
Hobbs, N.M. Input from the public would be taken during these sessions from 
people with ãstanding,ä or those who can show they will be affected by the 
construction of the plant.

Johnson said similar uranium enrichment plants in Europe have operated 
successfully for over 30 years without any major accidents. He said the NRC 
oversees other types of nuclear energy projects.

The uranium ore needed for the project would be transferred to the site by 
truck, although a rail spur has been constructed nearby by Waste Control 
Specialists and could be a possibility.

Johnson said the ore is transported in cylinders, which have stringent safety 
standards, adding that the transportation of nuclear material has an 
excellent record during the last 40 years.

Tentatively, a public meeting will be held in early November in Eunice, N.M. 
concerning the project.

Vermont goes forward with waste disposal payment 
John Dillon 

http://www.publicbroadcasting.net/vpr/news.mediaplayer?
STATION_NAME=vpr&MEDIA_ID=428983&MEDIA_EXTENSION=asf&MODULE=news

 MONTPELIER, VT (2003-10-07) 

(Host) Vermont will pay Texas to develop a nuclear waste dump, even though 
construction for the project hasn't started. The Douglas administration says 
the state is obligated to pay the money under a 1993 contract. But critics 
say the state should renegotiate to strike a better deal.

VPR's John Dillon reports:

(Dillon) A federal law makes the states responsible for low level nuclear 
waste. So ten years ago Vermont and Maine struck a deal to ship the waste - 
primarily contaminated equipment and clothing - to Texas. But Vermont never 
made the first payment of $12.5 million because the first dump site was 
rejected by Texas.

Now Texas has passed a law that allows private developers to build a new 
dump. Texas asked Vermont to pay the $12.5 million by November 1. State 
Auditor of Accounts Elizabeth Ready says it's a bad idea to send the check 
now.

(Ready) "There is no site, no compact and no group of states has been 
successful in locating a site. And until we have a permitted site I really 
don't want to see $12.5 million going from Vermont to Texas. I don't think 
it's a prudent move. I think we would be very well served to renegotiate this 
particular deal in light of these changes."

(Dillon) Ready worries that if the money is spent and the site isn't built, 
the state won't have the funds available to invest in an alternative.

(Ready) "There are some real concerns about this site. First of all, it is 
located on a primary aquifer, the Ogalala Aquifer in Texas. It may well end 
up with the same kind of fate as the last site, which was ultimately rejected 
by a Texas environmental commission. So before we pony up, before we pay this 
money. I think there are some very serious questions that need to be 
answered."

(Dillon) The bill will ultimately be paid by the generators of the waste, 
mainly Entergy Vermont Yankee, the company that owns the state's only nuclear 
power plant. 

Administration Secretary Michael Smith says Entergy has promised that the 
funds won't come from ratepayers. And he says a legal opinion by the attorney 
general's office shows the state has no choice but to make the payment. 

(Smith) "We're going to be talking with Texas. But our legal standing is 
fairly clear about what we're obligated to do. When the compact was first 
negotiated these issues were discussed, and still the fact is that Texas is 
obligated to build the facility. And that's what we are going to assume Texas 
will do."

(Dillon) Smith says the state will make the payment to Texas next month and 
then collect the money from the generators of the low level waste. 

For Vermont Public Radio, I'm John Dillon in Montpelier.


© Copyright 2003, VPR

Cold War graveyard  
By Jerry Needham  
San Antonio Express-News  
Web Posted : 10/12/2003 12:00 AM  
   
FALLS CITY ÷ Behind a chain-link fence decorated with yellow radiation 
warning signs, a half-mile-long mountain of Texas Hill Country limestone 
rises as a massive monument to the Cold War. 
 Radiation site inspectors Carl Jacobson and Tom Kirkpatrick climb a 60-foot 
mound that covers radioactive dirt and uranium wastes near Falls City. 
Gloria Ferniz/Express-News  

"That's a big ol' mound, a big ol' graveyard," says Fabian Niestroy, 67, 
surveying the pile of rock from the 500 acres his family owns across FM 1334 
from the disposal cell, 8 miles southwest of this town.

The pile is big because it's covering 6 million cubic yards of radioactive 
dirt and uranium processing wastes ÷ most of which was moved there by heavy 
equipment during a site cleanup 10 years ago.

Contractors for the Energy Department, which owns the 232-acre site, then 
buried it under almost a million cubic yards of clean dirt hauled from a mile 
away.

This sparsely populated area, about 45 miles south of San Antonio, had a big 
role in the early nuclear age. The discovery of huge deposits of uranium here 
in the 1950s brought a boom for more than two decades in jobs mining the ore 
and milling it into concentrated material for use in nuclear weapons and 
power plants. 

But the boom turned to bust in the 1980s when the market found cheaper and 
richer ore in Canada and Australia. Left behind were piles of radioactive 
wastes and contaminated aquifers. 

"My dad owned this land since '43 or '44," Niestroy said, baling hay during a 
recent visit. "I saw the mining start up and end out here."

This flat Texas prairie is brush country, and the farmers and ranchers who 
scratch out a living here ÷ many of whom profited from the mines during good 
times ÷ don't seem terribly concerned about the radioactive mess left behind. 
And a recent health study seems to support that attitude.

Many residents seem comfortable enough with the situation to make light of it.

"We can see our cows at night," rancher Niestroy joked over a beer at a local 
bar. "They glow in the dark." 

Niestroy, who moved to San Antonio in 1957 and now raises only cattle and hay 
on his acreage, said his family leased out the land for two mines on the 
property.

"All the mining did concern me at first because of all that stuff they 
removed from all those mines," Niestroy said.

"Let me drink a beer so I don't start glowing," echoes Doyle Culpepper, 52, 
who was born and raised out here where the uranium mines later sprang up. 

For the past 25 years, he's owned the Saddle Tramp and Mule Skinner Inn, a 
beer joint on FM 791 on the mile between the Falls City and Conquista 
disposal cells. The Conquista is another former mill site being cleaned up by 
its owner, Conoco.

"It's a lot better than it was when we had all these open acid pits around 
here," Culpepper said. "I'd say it's 100 percent safe here right now. 
Everything's closed up like when we were kids. It's OK now as long as nobody 
goes bothering it."

The government estimates 1.2 billion gallons of groundwater at the rock-
covered site, formerly owned by Susquehanna-Western Inc., is contaminated 
with materials that include arsenic, cadmium, chromium, molybdenum, alpha 
radiation, nitrate, radium, selenium and uranium.

The Energy Department determined that it would take $350 million to clean up 
the aquifer.

The agency decided not to clean up the dirty water, which has drifted about a 
half-mile from the site in one direction, because the groundwater in that 
area is of limited use due to naturally occurring contamination. 

No one is drinking from the aquifer in the affected area, and only livestock 
drink from any wells that draw from the aquifer within a few miles. 

"Nobody I know drinks the water out here anymore," Culpepper said. "Since the 
late 1970s, we've gotten our water from Three Oaks (Water Supply Corp.)."

Three mills and more than 40 mines were in operation in Karnes County from 
the 1960s to the 1980s. But working with the radioactive material doesn't 
seem to have caused physical harm to its residents, according to one new 
study.

That study, published last month in the Journal of Radiological Protection, 
found fewer-than-expected cancer deaths in the county.

Four researchers from the International Epidemiology Institute in Rockville, 
Md., studied data from 1950 to 2001 and found cancer death rates in the 
county were similar before, during and after mining and milling of the 
radioactive ore.

They reported they found no difference in cancer death rates in Karnes County 
and those in four similar South Texas counties. They also reported "no 
significant increases in Karnes County for any cancer" when compared with the 
South Texas, Texas or U.S. population.

The Falls City Disposal Site incorporates wastes from Texas' first uranium 
mill, owned and operated by Susquehanna-Western from 1961 through 1973. After 
concentrating the uranium from sandstone ore with a sulfuric acid leaching 
process, it sold the material under contract to the U.S. Atomic Energy 
Commission and to nuclear power plants.

Solution Engineering Inc. bought the property, and from 1978 to 1982 further 
extracted uranium from the piles of tailings using acid solutions.

Congress in 1978 passed a law making the Energy Department responsible for 90 
percent of the cleanup and remediation costs at uranium milling sites that 
had provided material to the government but had ceased operating at that time.

The Susquehanna-Western site at Falls City was one of 24 sites nationwide 
that qualified. The surface cleanup began in 1992 and was completed in 1994 
at a cost of $56 million.

Niestroy said he's glad the federal government came in for the cleanup. They 
removed the contaminated dirt from his property. The feds also bulldozed a 
big hill of clean dirt the mining company had removed from atop the uranium 
layer into a huge pit the company had left.

To protect the huge pile from erosion, 140,000 cubic yards of crushed 
limestone ranging in size from 13 inches to 20 inches were hauled 150 miles 
to the site from Marble Falls ÷ by train to Cambellton, and then by truck. 
The rocks cover the sides of the 62-foot-high, 2,000-foot-wide heap to a 
depth of 2 feet.

"Essentially, this repository has to last forever, and it's built to do 
that," Carl Jacobson, program manager for Energy Department contractor S.M. 
Stoller Corp. of Grand Junction, Colo., said during an annual inspection of 
the site.

"Falls City, Texas ÷ Uranium Mill Tailings Repository ÷ No Trespassing ÷ By 
Order of the U.S. Department of Energy," read the signs that also contain the 
universally known three-spoked symbol for radiation.

"The disposal cell at Falls City is designed and constructed to last for 200 
to 1,000 years," notes an Energy Department fact sheet. "However, the general 
license has no expiration date, and DOE understands its responsibility for 
the safety and integrity of the Falls City site will last indefinitely."

"You can't find anything (radioactive readings) above background on any of 
the sites," Jacobson said. "We've got a few sites where houses are moving in 
next door."

Three other South Texas uranium mills still were operating when Congress 
passed the law in 1978 that authorized the Energy Department to clean up 
abandoned mills that had sold uranium under contract to the U.S. government.

They later closed and the owners became responsible for putting the property 
back into a near-natural condition before their transfer to the Energy 
Department for perpetual care. The Texas Department of Health's Bureau of 
Radiation Control has overseen those efforts.

Those sites are:

Conquista, a 600-acre site on FM 971 about 7 miles southwest of Falls City in 
Karnes County and owned by Conoco. The 250-acre disposal cell contains 6.5 
million cubic yards of mill tailings generated during milling operations 
between 1972 and 1982. 

Panna Maria, a 300-acre site on FM 81 between Hobson and Panna Maria in 
Karnes County and owned by Chevron and, now, Rio Grande Resources. The 150-
acre disposal cell contains 7.4 million cubic yards of wastes from the ore 
processing operations that took place there from 1979 to 1992.

Ray Point, a 60-acre site on FM 1358 near Ray Point in Live Oak County. The 
39-acre disposal cell contains 360,000 cubic yards of wastes generated during 
mining and milling operations from 1970 to 1973. Exxon began decommissioning 
the mill in 1979.

Those sites look similar to a large hill or mound with no trees, with a heavy-
duty fence surrounding it all. Groundwater contamination also is a concern at 
those locations.

Falls City, Conquista and Panna Maria are leased to ranchers who bale hay on 
the property. 

All that mining may have brought some bad stuff to the surface, Culpepper 
said, but it also brought some good times for a while.

"There were a lot of people working then," Culpepper said. "It was the first 
job for a lot of us. I was working there when I was 16 years old. I worked in 
a bunch of it ÷ heavy equipment operator and welder."

op=modload&name=News&file=article&sid=4299
Expert: Radioactive waste should not come into Utah
Monday, October 20, 2003 - 12:00 AM 
The Associated Press  |  
THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

SALT LAKE CITY -- A former federal energy department policy adviser says 
radioactive waste from an Ohio Superfund site should not be brought to a 
Tooele County landfill.

"This is not your garden variety of low-level waste," said Robert Alvarez, 
senior policy adviser to three Energy secretaries during the Clinton 
administration.

"This is nasty stuff," said Alvarez, now a senior scholar at the Washington, 
D.C.-based Institute for Policy Studies.

The waste, leftovers from highly concentrated nuclear fuel for bomb making, 
is considered so hazardous that it should be sent instead to an underground 
repository similar to those used for plutonium-tainted waste, he told The 
Salt Lake Tribune.

Normally the waste would be barred from disposal at Envirocare, but a 
paragraph in the energy bill -- which could be debated by the U.S. House of 
Representatives this week -- would redefine the waste so it is allowed in a 
commercial facility.

Envirocare is not mentioned by name, but the one-paragraph provision would 
make it possible for tailings from the Fernald, Ohio, federal cleanup to be 
transported to Utah after Envirocare updates its U.S. Nuclear Regulatory 
Commission license.

Envirocare is seeking permission from federal regulators to take radium-226 
that is 25 times more concentrated than allowed by its current license so 
that it can be considered for the $14 million Fernald waste contract, the 
Tribune reported in its Sunday editions.

U.S. Rep. Rob Bishop, a Utah Republican who formerly worked as a statehouse 
lobbyist for Envirocare, has called the Envirocare provision a "win-win" for 
the company and the state, although the Fernald waste is only expected to 
generate about $24,000 in radioactive waste taxes for Utah.

Energy department contractor Fluor Fernald and Envirocare dispute Alvarez's 
assessment of the waste, saying it has long been treated like other low-level 
byproduct material from uranium milling.

"To my thinking," said Envirocare's Ken Alkema, "he doesn't know what he is 
talking about."

Since 1999, Fernald has shipped 97 rail loads of bulk waste to the Tooele 
County landfill, and 38 more are expected in the next few years. Ultimately, 
809,461 tons of Fernald's bulk waste is slated to wind up at the Utah 
landfill.

Efforts for Envirocare to receive the "high-activity" silo waste began last 
year, when the energy department told Congress it would finish the cleanup by 
the end of 2006 rather than the 2010 deadline originally built into its 
contract.

Fluor Fernald signed a contract last March that would give it incentives for 
the accelerated cleanup, the Tribune reported. Under that contract, Fluor 
gets paid $215 million if it completes the job by December 2006. If the work 
is done six months earlier, its paycheck will be $288 million dollars.

Fluor Fernald spokesman Jeff Wagner noted Fernald itself will be the burial 
ground for 90 percent of the cleanup waste, even though the site sits above 
an aquifer that serves millions of people in Ohio.

He said this "balanced approach" also calls for sending the remainder to the 
energy department-owned Nevada Test Site dump and Envirocare.

Under state law, the only revenue the state of Utah would realize from the 
silo waste would be from a radioactive waste tax.

Under that, byproduct waste generated by a government agency is taxed at 10 
cents for every cubic foot of waste. The silo waste is 8,900 cubic yards, or 
240,300 cubic feet.

That means the state treasury can expect to receive about $24,030.

"The tragedy of this is," said Claire Geddes of Utah Legislative Watch, "that 
Utah is being sacrificed in the pursuit of corporate profits and will become 
the nation's bargain-basement dumping ground for this highly toxic 
radioactive weapons waste."

This story appeared in The Daily Herald on page D4.

Radioactive waste vessel closes intersection

A north Houston intersection was closed for several hours Thursday when a 
vessel containing radioactive waste fell off a truck, Houston Fire Department 
officials said. 

None of the material leaked, and no injuries were reported from the incident 
at Imperial Valley and Greens just before 1 p.m. 

The public was never endangered, said Houston Fire Department spokesman Jay 
Evans. The intersection was impassable while city and state officials and 
hazardous materials teams investigated.

Baton Rouge The Advocate
Evidence of pipe cracks found at nuclear plant 
Oct 28 2003
http://www.2theadvocate.com/stories/102803/new_entnuk001.shtml

By The Associated Press
NEW ORLEANS -- Workers at Entergy Corp.'s Waterford 3 nuclear power plant 
have found evidence of cracks in piping that circulates radioactive water 
through the reactor, Entergy has told the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.
The pipes are located within the 3.5-thick containment structure that encases 
the power plant's reactor, and leaks resulting from any cracks have posed no 
danger to the public, Entergy Nuclear spokeswoman Diane Park said.

Likewise, monitoring equipment within the concrete-and-steel structure has 
not detected any unsafe levels of radiation, she said. The leaks are believed 
to be tiny, Park said Monday.

The cracks were found at Waterford after the plant was shut down Oct. 19 for 
a regularly scheduled maintenance outage, which occurs every 18 months. The 
leaks are located at two spots where pipes connect to the reactor's 
pressurizer and its coolant pump.

Park said the leaks will be repaired during the maintenance outage, but she 
did not know whether the work would prolong the shutdown. Maintenance outages 
typically last three to five weeks, she said.

The cracks are in a nickel-chromium alloy known as Alloy 600, a material that 
is common in pressurized water reactors. Entergy owns and operates five 
pressurized water reactors: Waterford in Taft, Arkansas Nuclear units one and 
two in Russellville, Ark., and Indian Point Energy Center units one and two 
in Buchanan, N.Y.

The industry has been aware of problems with Alloy 600 for more than a 
decade. But the trouble did not become a major concern in the United States 
until last year after cracks were found in pipes at the Oconee plant in South 
Carolina and a hole was found in the reactor lid at the Davis-Besse plant in 
Ohio.

The NRC this year ordered the operators of the nation's 68 pressurized water 
reactor power stations to conduct special inspections of Alloy 600 material 
in their reactors.

The inspections have turned up cracks at the Summer plant near Columbia, 
S.C., and at the South Texas unit one plant near Houston. Waterford is the 
latest U.S. plant to join the list.

Some industry observers consider the alloy problems to be the most 
significant safety issue to face U.S. nuclear plants since the Three Mile 
Island accident in 1979.

"Clearly, there is a level of concern based on what was found at Davis-Besse, 
or the NRC would not have ordered these types of inspections," Park said.

Evidence of pipe cracks found at nuclear plant
Associated Press

NEW ORLEANS - Workers at Entergy Corp.'s Waterford 3 nuclear power plant have 
found evidence of cracks in piping that circulates radioactive water through

New Orleans Times-Picayune:

Nuclear plant pipes seem cracked 
Boric acid indicates minuscule fracture inside Waterford 3
Tuesday October 28, 2003
By Keith Darc 
Business writer 

Workers at Entergy Corp.'s Waterford 3 nuclear power plant in St. Charles 
Parish have found evidence of cracks in piping that circulates radioactive 
water through the reactor, the New Orleans-based utility reported Monday. 

The pipes are located within the 3.5-foot-thick containment structure that 
encases the power plant's reactor, and leaks resulting from any cracks have 
posed no danger to the public, Entergy Nuclear spokeswoman Diane Park said. 
          
Likewise, monitoring equipment within the concrete-and-steel structure has 
not detected any unsafe levels of radiation, she said. 

The leaks, which are believed to be tiny, were revealed by small amounts of 
boric acid that had collected on pipe nozzles in two different sections of 
the reactor coolant system, Park said. 

Water circulating through the reactor at temperatures ranging from 550 
degrees to 600 degrees contains boron, a chemical that helps control nuclear 
reactions by absorbing neutrons. When the water leaks, it leaves a boric acid 
residue. 

Tiny leaks in a reactor generally do not pose a safety danger, but they can 
become threatening if they become larger. A massive leak could release 
dangerous amounts of radioactive water into the containment building, and it 
could depressurize the reactor and lead to a catastrophic meltdown of the 
reactor core. 

The cracks were found at Waterford after the plant was shut down Oct. 19 for 
a regularly scheduled maintenance outage, which occurs every 18 months. The 
leaks are located at two spots where pipes connect to the reactor's 
pressurizer and its coolant pump. 

Entergy disclosed the discovery Monday in documents filed with the Nuclear 
Regulatory Commission. 

Parks said the leaks will be repaired during the maintenance outage, but she 
didn't know whether the work would prolong the shutdown. Maintenance outages 
typically last three to five weeks, she said. 

The cracks are in a nickel-chromium alloy known as Alloy 600, a material that 
is common in so-called pressurized water reactors. Entergy owns and operates 
five pressurized water reactors: Waterford in Taft, Arkansas Nuclear units 
one and two in Russellville, Ark., and Indian Point Energy Center units one 
and two in Buchanan, N.Y. 

Alloy 600 is mainly used as lining in pipes as they pass through container 
walls and as weld material on pipes. 

The trouble follows a pattern of problems that have surfaced at several other 
similarly designed nuclear power plants across the country in recent years. 

The industry has been aware of problems with Alloy 600 for more than a 
decade, but the trouble didn't become a major concern in the United States 
until last year after cracks were found in pipes at the Oconee plant in South 
Carolina and a hole was found in the reactor lid at the Davis-Besse plant in 
Ohio. 

The NRC this year ordered the operators of the nation's 68 pressurized water 
reactor power stations to conduct special inspections of Alloy 600 material 
in their reactors. 

The inspections have turned up cracks at the Summer plant near Columbia, 
S.C., and at the South Texas unit one plant near Houston. Waterford is the 
latest U.S. plant to join the list. 

Several nuclear power plant operators, including Entergy, have announced 
plans to replace the lids on some of their older reactors. Entergy said in 
May that it will replace the lid on Arkansas unit one, its oldest nuclear 
plant. The project, which will take two years, could cost the company $85 
million. 

Entergy hasn't decided whether to replace lids on the reactors of Arkansas 
unit two and Waterford 3, Park said. 

Though older nuclear plants are believed to be more susceptible to Alloy 600 
leaks, Waterford, which opened in 1985, is a relatively new plant. 

Some industry observers consider the alloy problems to be the most 
significant safety issue to face U.S. nuclear plants since the Three Mile 
Island accident in 1979. 

"Clearly, there is a level of concern based on what was found at Davis-Besse, 
or the NRC would not have ordered these types of inspections," Park said. 

. . . . . . . 

Keith Darc can be reached at kdarce@timespicayune.com or (504) 826-3491.

http://www.harktheherald.com/modules.php?
op=modload&name=News&file=article&sid=5367

Radioactive waste may go elsewhere
Sunday, November 02, 2003 - 12:00 AM 
N.S. Nokkentved THE DAILY HERALD  |  
Most people would rather not have this kind of stuff buried in their 
community.

But a Utah radioactive waste landfill is prepared to compete for a contract 
to dispose of controversial waste from a federal cleanup site in Ohio.

Envirocare of Utah Inc. says it would have to compete with at least three 
other commercial radioactive waste disposal companies.But two may not be able 
to accept it, and the third hasn't decided whether it is interested.

At issue is the disposal of 1.4 million cubic feet of concentrated uranium 
tailings from a federal cleanup site in Fernald, Ohio. But only if federal 
law covering the waste is changed.

Waste Control Specialists in Texas doesn't have a license to dispose of the 
waste. But if the company were interested, officials could apply to state 
regulators in Texas, which has the authority to regulate uranium tailings, 
company vice president Michael Lauer said.

"It's a business decision," he said. The company already has a suitable site 
for disposal, and the state license application is sitting on a shelf in 
company offices.

"It could happen very quickly," Lauer said.

International Uranium in Blanding can't dispose of the entire amount and is 
not pursuing the disposal contract, said Ron Hochstein from the Vancouver, 
British Columbia-based company's Denver office.

The waste may be too radioactive for the Cotter Corp. in southwest Colorado, 
one state official said. Company officials declined to comment.

And Envirocare would have to get its federal license to dispose of uranium 
tailings changed to accept the waste.

But before the waste can be sent to any commercial radioactive waste 
landfill, federal legislation is needed to give the Nuclear Regulatory 
Commission authority to regulate the waste.

"We went to (U.S. Rep. Rob) Bishop and asked him to write a letter," said Tim 
Barney, senior vice president at Envirocare. But it was the federal 
Department of Energy that asked Congress for the legislation.

"This was a DOE-driven initiative," Barney said.

Bishop, R-Utah, a former Envirocare lobbyist, and the federal Energy 
Department requested the legislation that would give the NRC the needed 
authority.

The waste in question now lies inside two crumbling concrete silos at a 
federal Department of Energy site in Fernald, Ohio, which processed uranium 
once used as fuel in nuclear reactors that produce atomic bomb materials.

Once solidified in concrete inside a quarter-inch steel tank, the waste would 
amount to about 1.4 million cubic feet. The element of most concern is the 
radium because it produces radon gas -- considered the second-leading cause 
of lung cancer in the country.

Radium loses its radioactivity slowly. It will take 16,000 years before it 
decays away to insignificant levels. Most of the waste now at Envirocare will 
lose its radioactivity in a few hundred years.

The concentration of radium in the waste is 25 times higher than similar 
waste Envirocare is now licensed to take.

But radium is not the only radioactive element in the waste. It also contains 
thorium, radioactive lead and polonium. A federal document says it contains 
more than 6,100 Curies -- a measure of radioactivity.

The waste includes 31 tons of uranium, 130 tons of barium, 900 tons of lead, 
and almost 3 tons of arsenic. The waste also contains polychlorinated 
biphenyls -- known as PCBs -- but at levels below regulatory concern. 

Cementing the waste would not prevent the release of radon. And the steel 
containers are not expected to last much longer than 150 years.

But disposal at Envirocare assumes the steel canister will corrode and the 
concrete will crumble. The disposal site is designed to contain the material 
to meet Environmental Protection Agency specifications on radon emissions, 
said Envirocare vice president Ken Alkema, who worked three years for the 
cleanup contractor at the Fernald site.

The Energy Department is in the process of cleaning up its facilities at 
Fernald. To complete that process, it needs to find a place for the waste in 
the silos -- too hazardous to be buried at the site.

Unless the federal law is changed, however, the department's only option is 
to send the material to a federal facility in Nevada. That would take longer 
and already has run into local opposition.

One reason for the lapse in regulatory authority may be that the tailings 
were not considered waste until after 1983.

The tailings come from refining uranium ore from the Belgian Congo. The 
Belgian government wanted the radium in the ores for luminescent watch and 
instrument dials, says a case study of the Fernald site by the Institute for 
Energy and Environmental Research based in Takoma Park, Md.

The United States began importing the ore in 1943 for the 40 to 50 percent 
concentration of uranium, much higher than uranium mined in the United 
States, which typically is 2 to 5 percent.

The U.S. government sent recovered radium back to Belgium until 1949, when it 
began sending it to Fernald for storage. Belgium continued to consider the 
radium a resource -- not waste. In 1983, Belgium transferred ownership of the 
material to the Energy Department, the IEER study said.

Though now considered waste, it was never included in any federal waste 
regulatory legislation.

nnokkentved@heraldextra.com

This story appeared in The Daily Herald on page C1.

Is a dirty bomb real threat? 
Tuesday, November 11, 2003
By JOHN SOLOMON 
Associated Press Writer 

WASHINGTON -- Federal investigators have documented 1,300 cases of lost, 
stolen or abandoned radioactive material inside the United States over the 
past five years and have concluded there is a significant risk that 
terrorists could cobble enough together for a dirty bomb. 

Studies by the Energy Department's Los Alamos laboratory and the General 
Accounting Office found significant holes in the nation's security net that 
could take years to close, even after improvements by regulators since Sept. 
11, 2001. 

 
"The world of radiological sources developed prior to recent concerns about 
terrorism, and many of the sources are either unsecured or provided, at best, 
with an industrial level of security," the Los Alamos lab concluded two 
months ago in a report that was reviewed by The Associated Press. 

The report concludes that the threat of a so-called dirty bomb that could 
disperse radiological materials across a wide area "appears to be very 
significant, and there is no shortage of radioactive materials that could be 
used." 

Security improvements under way "are unlikely to significantly alter the 
global risk picture for a few years," it added. 

The FBI repeatedly has warned law enforcement over the past year that al-
Qaida was interested in obtaining radiological materials and creating a 
dispersal bomb, most recently after authorities received an uncorroborated 
report a few weeks ago that al-Qaida might be seeking material from a 
Canadian source. 

Nuclear Regulatory Commission spokeswoman Beth Hayden said the agency 
recognizes the potential dangers of such materials and al-Qaida's interest in 
them -- "there are millions of sources," she said. But she added most of the 
1,300 lost radiological sources were subsequently recovered and the public 
should keep the threat in perspective. 

"The ones that have been lost and not recovered, I'm told, if you put them 
all together, it would not add up to one highly radioactive source," Hayden 
said. "These are low-level sources." 

The top Democrat on the House Homeland Security Committee says the studies 
show security efforts fall short of what is needed. 

"Even though for years we have known of the threat that terrorists would 
use 'dirty bombs' to attack the United States, I am alarmed at the 
government's inadequate response to this very real threat. The economic and 
health costs of such an event would be staggering. It appears we don't even 
know how much material exists that could be used for such weapons or even 
where it is being kept," Rep. Jim Turner, D-Texas, said. 

The Los Alamos analysis specifically cited concerns about the transportation 
of large shipments of radioactive cobalt from industrial sites, as well as 
lax security at hospitals that use radiological devices to treat and diagnose 
patients. 

The GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, detailed how terrorists could 
abuse the legal method for obtaining radiological sources because the NRC 
takes as long as a year to inspect facilities after it mails them a license 
for such materials. 

"Because the process assumes that the applicant is acting in good faith and 
it can take the NRC as along as 12 months before conducting an inspection, it 
is possible that sealed sources can be obtained for malicious intent," the 
GAO told the Senate recently. 

NRC Commissioner Edward McGaffigan Jr. said the GAO concerns were overstated, 
focusing on materials with extremely low level radioactivity. He said his 
agency has been taking steps for months to more securely ship and store high-
risk sources. 

"We honestly think we are doing a very aggressive and excellent job in this 
area, but we have obviously more to do," McGaffigan said in an 
interview. "Our view is we don't want to lose any of them, and we are going 
to have cradle-to-grave controls as soon as we possibly can for high-risk 
sources." 

He said the government was undertaking a first-ever inventory of who 
possesses radioactive materials. 

and how much they possess. 

The GAO questioned whether the NRC has moved fast enough to secure sealed 
sources -- devices that contain small amounts of radiological materials used 
in construction and hospitals. 

"The number of sealed sources in the United States is unknown because NRC and 
states track numbers of licensees instead of sealed sources," the GAO told 
the Senate in a report published in August. 

Two universities told the GAO about security problems with nuclear materials, 
specifically cases in which doors to rooms with the materials had been found 
unlocked or open. 

The congressional investigators found that many of the 114 universities that 
possess, from earlier experiments, the radiological material plutonium-239 
have tried unsuccessfully to return it to the government. The Energy 
Department doesn't have enough secure storage space, the investigators said. 

The congressional investigation for the first time tallied the number of 
times sealed radiological materials have been lost, misplaced or stolen. They 
found more than 1,300 instances inside the United States since 1998. While 
most have been recovered, the report cited a handful of harrowing, unsolved 
losses. 

For instance, in March 1999, an industrial radiography camera containing 
iridium-192 was stolen from a Florida home. The camera has not been recovered 
despite an investigation by the FBI. The NRC believes the material should 
have degraded by now and would no longer be useful for a bomb. 

A North Carolina hospital discovered in March 1998 that 19 sealed sources of 
radiological material, including the highly dispersible cesium-137, were 
missing from a locked safe. They have not been found. 

Security improvements are being made. For instance, the NRC requires tighter 
security by companies that use soil analysis gauges that contain radiological 
materials. There are some 20,000 of them used nationwide by more than 5,100 
licensees. The devices are lost or stolen at a rate of one a week, officials 
said. 

The GAO and Los Alamos security reviews made several recommendations. They 
include keeping licensed sources from getting radiological materials until 
after they are inspected, improving structural security at high-risk 
locations and working with federal, state and international regulators to 
toughen controls. 

"These efforts are unlikely to significantly alter the global risk picture 
for a few years, although the risks regarding certain sources and 
circumstances could change more quickly," the Los Alamos study conceded.

Panel opens door to hotter radioactive waste in Utah
 advertisement
 
Patty Henetz
Associated Press
Nov. 11, 2003 12:05 PM

SALT LAKE CITY - A congressional panel has reclassified uranium mill tailings 
in Fernald, Ohio, the first necessary step for Utah hazardous waste companies 
that want to import and store 30 million pounds of highly concentrated 
radioactive waste.

House and Senate negotiators, working to resolve differences in their 
versions of the 2004 energy and water appropriations bill, agreed to allow 
the waste at the Fernald site and another radioactive storage site to be 
defined as "byproduct material," which officials at the Utah companies 
Envirocare and the White Mesa Mill facility of International Uranium Corp. 
likely will bid on.

The conference committee's action came as a surprise both to Envirocare and 
critics of reclassification, including Rep. Jim Matheson, D-Utah, who said he 
had been focusing on the same issue in a different energy bill.

The conference committee's report on the $27.33 billion appropriations bill, 
however, will go to the House and Senate as early as next week for final 
passage. Conference committee reports can only be adopted or rejected, not 
changed.

Matheson noted that the House version of the energy and water bill didn't 
have the reclassification language, and he was unaware that it had been 
inserted in the Senate bill. Sen. Bob Bennett, R-Utah, said it was inserted 
by another senator at the request of the Bush administration.

Ohio Sen. George Voinovich earlier had proposed adding identical language to 
a Senate energy bill.

Before the reclassification, the waste would be barred from disposal at 
Envirocare, Instead, it would have been shipped to the Nevada Test Site.

Dane Finerfrock, director of the Utah Division of Radiation Control, said the 
congressional committee's action Friday was only a first step. If Envirocare 
were to win the bid to import the waste, it would also have to petition to 
amend its license and to modify its groundwater permit.

Envirocare spokeswoman Betty Arial said Envirocare expects to compete for the 
Fernald waste contract with a federal facility and at least three other 
contractors: Lakewood, Colo.-based Cotter Corp.; Waste Control Specialists of 
Andrews, Texas; and International Uranium Corp. through its White Mesa mill 
in Blanding, Utah.

If all goes well for Envirocare, the "absolute earliest" the company could 
take the Fernald waste would be next October, Arial said.

Amarillo Globe News
Web-posted Tuesday, November 18, 2003 
Hutchison endorses plutonium pitch 
By GREG ROHLOFF
grohloff@amarillonet.com  

In making another pitch for the location of a new plutonium pit facility at 
Pantex, a contingent of Amarillo representatives gained the endorsement of 
U.S. Sen. Kay Bailey Hutchison.
Kevin Schweers, a spokesman for the Texas Republican, said Hutchison agreed 
to write an endorsement letter to Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham advocating 
Pantex as the site for the plant that would make new triggers for nuclear 
weapons.

The DOE wants to name a location for the plant by April and is considering 
Savannah River Site near Aiken, S.C.; Pantex; Nevada Test Site; and sites at 
Los Alamos and Carlsbad in New Mexico.

Schweers said a report to Congress from the Department of Energy is expected 
by Nov. 30.

Mayor Trent Sisemore - accompanied by City Manager John Ward, City 
Commissioner Robert Keys, Amarillo Chamber of Commerce President Gary 
Molberg, John Teague, vice president of governmental affairs for the chamber, 
and Amarillo Globe-News Publisher Les Simpson - said the buzz during the 
visit Thursday and Friday was that the report may include a delay in naming a 
preferred location.

"Whatever decisions are made, it's going to generate some controversy."
U.S. Rep. Mac Thornberry

 
The group met with Linton Brooks, National Nuclear Safety Administration 
administrator; Pete Olson, chief of staff for U.S. Sen. John Cornyn, R-Texas; 
Hutchison's staff; U.S. Rep. Mac Thornberry, R-Clarendon; Dr. Dale Klein of 
the Department of Defense; John Conway, chairman of the Defense Nuclear 
Facilities Safety Board; and Madelyn Creedon of the Senate Armed Services 
Committee staff.

None tipped their hand on preferences for the site, Sisemore said.

"It's the best-kept secret in Washington right now," Sisemore said.

The group reiterated widespread support for the facility in Amarillo, the 
work ethic and record of the Pantex work force, and its expertise in 
manufacturing and the transportation challenges of moving pits from Pantex 
where they are now stored to another location for remanufacturing, Sisemore 
said.

Molberg said Washington officials appreciated the effort made in the trip and 
were complimentary toward BWXT Pantex, the Pantex plant contractor.

Thornberry said he had not heard any indication of which location may win 
out, noting the Savannah River Site is considered a front-runner because it 
will dispose of excess plutonium.

"Whatever decisions are made, it's going to generate some controversy," 
Thornberry said, noting the opposition in some quarters to the building of 
new nuclear weapons.

EPA Plan Would Ease Rules on Nuke Waste 
By NANCY ZUCKERBROD
Associated Press Writer 

WASHINGTON (AP)--The Bush administration is considering allowing low-level 
radioactive waste to be dumped at toxic waste sites and other facilities that 
currently aren't permitted to receive it. 

The Environmental Protection Agency is expected to issue a notice Tuesday 
seeking public comments on the proposal. 

The notice, a copy of which was obtained by The Associated Press, asks the 
public to weigh in on whether certain levels of radioactive waste can be 
stored in landfills or hazardous material disposal sites. 

Nuclear power companies can dispose of low-level radioactive waste at a 
handful of sites around the country, and about 20 sites can dispose of 
hazardous material. 

The EPA notice says a rule change could simplify the process for getting rid 
of hazardous and radioactive waste for nuclear power companies and others 
that generate it. 

"The need to comply with two separate regulatory systems, each of which is 
targeted to a different component of the waste, creates a certain regulatory 
and economic burden on mixed waste generators," the EPA states in its 
notice. 

Companies have stored a lot of waste instead of disposing of it because of 
the burden of getting rid of it properly, the notice says. 

Environmentalists criticized the new proposal. 

"They can save a lot of money if their waste doesn't have to go to a 
facility designed to safely contain it," said Daniel Hirsch, president of 
the Committee to Bridge the Gap, a Los Angeles-based nuclear watchdog group. 

Environmentalists urged new EPA Administrator Mike Leavitt, the former 
governor of Utah, not to make the changes. 

"EPA's proposal, within days of Gov. Leavitt's confirmation as the new EPA 
chief, to deregulate radioactive wastes, is a deeply troubling assault on the 
environment," said Diane D'Arrigo, nuclear waste project director for the 
Washington-based Nuclear Information and Resource Service. 

EPA spokeswoman Cynthia Bergman said the agency will consider public comments 
before taking further action. 

The notice focuses on commercial nuclear waste but asks for input on whether 
the Energy Department should also loosen its rules governing the disposal of 
radioactive waste from weapons plants.

Nov. 18, 2003, 12:11AM
DeLay fund-raiser on eve of trial raises eyebrows 
By R.G. RATCLIFFE 
Copyright 2003 Houston Chronicle Austin Bureau 

AUSTIN -- On the eve of the federal trial that could enhance Republican 
congressional power, U.S. House Majority Leader Tom DeLay plans to scoop up 
re-election cash at an Austin lobby fund-raiser. 

The Dec. 10 luncheon is scheduled the day before a three-judge panel begins a 
trial on the legality of a congressional redistricting map that DeLay, R-
Sugar Land, pushed through the Texas Legislature earlier this year. 

A dozen Austin lobbyists are hosting the event. Their clients include Verizon 
Wireless, Accenture management consultants, Waste Control Specialists, the 
Texas Medical Association and the Texas Association of Realtors. 

Wayne Franke, one of the organizers, said it is pure coincidence that the 
fund-raiser is set for the day before the redistricting trial. And an aide 
for DeLay said the event's date was set before the trial was scheduled. 

"We were going to have it a lot earlier, but the congressional agenda did not 
cooperate," Franke said. 

Franke said Austin lobbyists have hosted a $1,000-per-person luncheon for 
DeLay each of the past six or seven years. He said the most people who 
attended was 30, and he believes there were 18 at last year's event. 

"Some have business up in Washington, and they go up there quite a bit. And 
those are the ones who usually participate here," Franke said. "They handle 
state issues and they handle federal issues. That would be the reason." 

Franke said some knew DeLay when he was a member of the Texas House. DeLay 
was elected to the U.S. House in 1984. 

Suzy Woodford, executive director of Common Cause of Texas, said she believes 
DeLay's appearance in Austin is meant to pressure the federal judges hearing 
the redistricting case. 

"He's not known as `The Hammer' for no reason," Woodford said, referring to 
DeLay's nickname in Washington. "If you have an issue pending that you really 
care about, this is a good way of letting them (the judges) know he's 
watching." 

But DeLay political aide Jim Ellis said there is nothing sinister about the 
timing. 

"You'll have to ask the court if they meant anything by scheduling the 
hearing right after the DeLay fund-raiser because it's been on the books for 
a long time -- long before they chose that date for the court case," Ellis 
said. 

At DeLay's urging, the Legislature passed a congressional redistricting plan 
last month designed to erase the 17-15 majority that Democrats hold in the 
state's congressional delegation and likely replace it with a 22-10 
Republican majority. 

DeLay argued a new map was needed because the current map denied the 
Republicans a majority when they have won every statewide office and a 
legislative majority. 

Democrats and minority groups have gone into federal court to try to block 
the plan, claiming it harms minority voting rights to achieve a GOP majority. 

The court has set a hearing on motions for summary judgment for Dec. 8, with 
the trial to begin Dec. 11 if the court does not grant any of those motions. 

The DeLay fund-raiser will be held at the InterContinental Stephen F Austin 
Hotel. The host committee consists of lobbyists Franke, Tony Bennett, Tom 
Clarke, Bill Clayton, Jenny Fowler, Alfred Gilchrist, Ron Hinkle, Bill 
Messer, Bill Pewitt, N.J. "Buzz" Robnett, Bill Stevens and Bill Stinson. 

Messer and Robnett served in the Texas House with DeLay. Clayton was House 
speaker at that time.
