http://www.fwweekly.com/issues/2003-11-19/metropolis.html

11/19/2003 
Dumping on the Dump
Environmentalists and others think legislative haste led to bad nuclear waste 
law.

By Betty Brink
 
Burnam: 'This is what you get when legislators don't do their homework.'  

On Earth Day, ironically enough, the 78th Texas Legislature finally passed 
what State Rep. Lon Burnam calls "a monopoly corporate welfare bill" -- 
intended to enrich one specific corporation. He's talking about the bill 
allowing development of a multi-state nuclear dump in Texas, and he says it 
was written for the benefit of Waste Control Specialists, a West Texas 
hazardous waste dump owned by Dallas billionaire Harold Simmons. "It will 
allow Texas to become a nuclear waste dumping ground for the nation -- if not 
the world," he said. 
It was a long time coming. Versions of the so-called "low-level" radioactive 
waste disposal measure have been proposed repeatedly for nearly a decade, 
defeated each time by intense lobbying from environmental groups and anti-
nuclear activists. This year they lost. The bill passed both chambers with 
little notice, Burnam said, as most of the media coverage centered on the 
redistricting dance between the two parties. 

This is a "risky experiment," Burnam said. The facility will be "host to 
commercial, federal, and mixed hazardous wastes all at the same site, a 
deadly combination of products that are not compatible." 

Opponents, however, have not given up the battle completely. They will fight 
a rearguard action in Austin on Dec. 17, trying to convince the state 
environmental agency to minimize the bill's damage via licensing and 
operating rules. And they are hoping for help from an unusual quarter -- the 
Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which is nearly always on the opposite side of 
issues from the anti-nuke lobby, but this time may be the groups' best ally. 
The NRC has tossed in a monkey wrench that could shut the dump down 
altogether -- or make it unprofitable for a private company to operate. 

The law as written, the NRC says, is in direct conflict with federal 
statutes. Bottom line, according to NRC spokesperson Dave McIntyre, is that 
unless the law is changed, the NRC will not allow any shipments of federally 
owned radioactive waste to any Texas site. That alone could doom the dreams 
of Simmons. 

But other concerns raised by the law are myriad. Susybelle Gosslee, president 
of the Dallas League of Women Voters, is most worried about the dangers of 
moving radioactive cargoes through the state to reach the dump. She wants the 
regs to require extra funding for "comprehensive first-response teams for 
communities throughout the state ... and adequate security" in transport. 
Burnam, the voters league, and others are also worried that, if the dump is 
located as expected on Simmons' company's land in West Texas, the radioactive 
and other hazardous wastes to be buried there in unlined trenches will 
eventually permeate the underlying red clay and contaminate the aquifer 
below. 

Other dumps located on similar clays have turned into nuclear nightmares, 
Burnam said, with taxpayers ending up footing the bill. Burnam wants the 
regulations tightened to "zero leak tolerance." 

In fact, the new law raises so many concerns and potential conflicts that one 
environmental attorney has suggested that the state agency, the Texas 
Commission on Environmental Quality, will be opening the state up to years of 
litigation if it tries to implement the law in its present form. 

"If there was ever a time for an agency charged with such a monumental task 
to go above and beyond the minimal requirements of the law," Burnam 
said, "the time is now." 

The three-member environmental commission will take testimony on Dec. 17, 
before approving the policies that will govern the planned dump for about the 
next 15 years. Staffer Susan Jablonski said the TCEQ encourages public 
testimony, and that concerns raised at earlier hearings have already 
convinced staff to make some changes to the proposed regulations. She would 
not say what they are. 

The changes that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is seeking are no small 
matter. In a letter to the state agency, NRC official Paul Lohaus pointed out 
that the Texas law conflicts with federal law regarding ownership of the 
land, buildings, and ultimately the waste. 

Federal regulations governing low-level nuclear waste disposal sites are 
stringent about ownership -- and there are no exceptions, said the NRC's 
McIntyre. They require that the land and the buildings be owned by either the 
state or federal government before a license to operate is issued, he said. 
Otherwise, the NRC will not approve any transfer of federal waste to the 
site. 

Under the Texas law, the private owner would not be required to turn over the 
federal waste site to the feds until decommissioning, years into the 
future. "That's not acceptable," McIntyre said. "This ownership issue has to 
be resolved," he said, before any wastes from a federal facility can be 
shipped. 

Government ownership "from the beginning and into perpetuity," is critical, 
McIntyre said, to guarantee that the contaminated site will be maintained and 
monitored for the safety and health of the public long after the license 
holder is gone. "There must be certainty of the stewardship" of a nuclear 
waste site beyond the 15 or 30 years of a license holder, he said. "The Texas 
regs have to be compatible with the NRC's. Right now they are not." 

The issue is one of keen interest to billionaire Simmons. His company already 
owns a hazardous waste disposal facility on about 1,000 acres in Andrews 
County not far from the New Mexico border. He has reportedly spent about $1 
million in the past two years lobbying and contributing to legislator's 
campaigns, in an effort to get the bill passed. One portion of the resulting 
law will, for the first time, allow a nuclear dump to be privately owned and 
operated. The law also will allow the eventual licensee to accept tens of 
millions of cubic feet of radioactive waste, not only from nuclear power 
plants and medical facilities, but from nuclear weapons programs dating to 
1943. Today those federal wastes are "temporarily" stored by the Department 
of Energy at aging and leaking facilities around the country. 

There's little doubt in Austin that Simmons' company will win the 
license. "His lobbyists, 16 of them, helped write the bill," Colin Leyden, an 
aide to Burnam, said. 

Burnam represents the Texas Radioactive Waste Defense Fund, a coalition of 
statewide groups that includes the Sierra Club, Public Citizen, and the 
League of Women Voters. He said the regulations as currently proposed allow a 
tolerance for leaks, which is unacceptable. 

"This dump will be built with an assumption that leaks will occur," he said, 
and that the red clay underneath Andrews County will keep radiation, 
including long-lived isotopes such as plutonium, from migrating into the 
water tables. 

Similar assumptions about the imperviousness of clay doomed a low-level waste 
dump at Maxey Flats in Kentucky, he pointed out in testimony before the TCEQ. 
It was closed in the 1980s after radioactive isotopes migrated to the 
groundwater. The operator walked away, and Maxey Flats is now a Superfund 
clean-up site. Burnam listed five other low-level waste sites around the 
country that had been touted as safe that turned into nuclear hot-spots. 

The years-long effort to open a waste site in the state was driven by Texas' 
commitment to Vermont and Maine under a compact approved in 1988, with 
Congressional approval. In that agreement, Texas committed to building a dump 
for nuclear waste generated within its borders and allowing the two smaller 
states to ship their wastes here for a $25 million fee. (The only exception 
is spent fuel from nuclear reactors. Those hot rods must be shipped to a 
federal high-level waste site that may or may not open someday at Yucca 
Mountain in Nevada.) The compact was supposed to shield Texas from having to 
accept nuclear waste from other states under interstate commerce regulations. 
However, Maine's legislature voted last year to pull out of the compact 
because of the years of delay. Its only reactor has been decommissioned and 
sent to other disposal sites. 

That leaves the radioactive detritus from Texas' two nuclear plants and 
Vermont's one plant, as well as a small amount of medical and research 
wastes. Not enough, Simmons reportedly has said, to make a dump profitable. 
He has lusted after the DOE wastes from the git-go, Burnam said. "That's 
where the money is." The Texas Observer recently estimated that profits from 
such a dump could top $100 billion. 

But that potential for profit could also become a nightmare for the state, 
according to Austin environmental attorney David Fredrick, an opponent of the 
dump. Because there are such "large profits to be made in radioactive waste 
disposal," he warned the commission, "there are a number of corporations, 
individuals, institutions, and even states that would have incentives to 
challenge the entire Texas ... program," if the commission is forced to adopt 
rules that conflict with federal law. That could throw the state into 
litigation that could last for decades, he said. 

"This bill was on the fast track this session," Burnam said. "No one bothered 
to check with the feds. This is what you get when legislators don't do their 
homework." 


You can reach Betty Brink at betty.brink@fwweekly.com.

http://www.oaoa.com/news/nw112103d.htm
Rep. West to seek another House term
By Julie Breaux
Odessa American
Friday November 21, 2003 

State Rep. Buddy West will seek his fourth term in the state House of 
Representatives next year.

The 67-year-old Republican from Odessa announced his plans during his town 
hall meeting Thursday at the Odessa Chamber of Commerce.

ãI will run for re-election because of all the issues on the board now,ä West 
told the gathering of about 50 constituents and business and civic leaders.
West said he feels heâs in a ãposition to move forwardä on issues significant 
to District 81, which includes a majority of Ector, Andrews and Winkler 
counties.

One of those issues is the licensing of a disposal site for low-level 
radioactive waste.

Currently, Waste Control Specialists Inc. has a license to store low-level 
radioactive waste at its 1,600-acre facility in Andrews County. But the 
company doesnât have a license for its disposal.

The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality has just begun whatâs expected 
to be a lengthy process of approving an application for a license to dispose 
of radioactive waste in Texas.

West said with the geology and hydrology of Andrews County, Andrews ãstands 
wellä to be that disposal site.

ãIt will be the economic driver of West Texas,ä he said, referring to the 
jobs a low-level radioactive waste disposal site would generate directly and 
indirectly.

West wrote the bill allowing for the disposal of radioactive waste in Texas 
during the recently adjourned Legislature.

Elected to his House seat in 1993, West is chairman of the House Energy 
Resources Committee and a member of the Environmental Regulations Committee 
and the Committee on Administration.

He also serves as vice-chairman for the Texas Railroad Commissionâs Oil Field 
Cleanup Fund Advisory Committee.

West lives in Odessa with his wife, Shirley. The Wests have one son and two 
daughters.

Rep. West visits Andrews, announces re-election bid
(Sunday, November 23, 2003

State Rep. Buddy West Thursday took time out during a quick stopover at the 
Andrews County Courthouse to announce his intentions in seeking re-election 
for another term in Austin.
Rep. West, touring Odessa, Andrews and Kermit during town hall meeting, said 
he wanted to return to Austin for another term and finish projects that have 
been started, including finding a new funding source for public education.
West, a Republican, represents District 81 in the Texas Legislature and told 
a small gathering of constituents at the courthouse that he felt compelled to 
seek re-election because of so many projects underway now in Austin.

West was elected to his seat in 1993 and is chairman of the House Energy 
Resources Committee and is a member of the Environmental Regulations 
Committee and the Committee on Administration. He also served as vice-
chairman for the Texas Railroad Commissionâs Oilfield Cleanup Fund Advisory 
Committee. 

Several of the issues include finding a new funding source for public 
education, which has gained support since more and more districts are finding 
themselves on the short end of Robin Hood or recapture, which sends money 
from property-rich school districts to poor ones.

West said as it current stands now, he didnât think Gov. Rick Perry would 
call another special session for funding education until he knew some type of 
funding mechanisms were in place. ãCurrently, there just isnât anything on 
the plate,ä he said about possible solutions.

West said a select committee consisting of Senate and House members is 
attempting to reach a consensus on funding methods, but West said thus far it 
didnât appear that the committee had been productive.

ãI doubt the governorâs going to call everyone back for a special session 
unless thereâs a pretty good chance thereâs a solution at hand,ä West said.

Because most of the school districts in Texas are at or near the maximum 
$1.50 tax rate, lawmakers have finally discussed shifting the financial 
burden from property taxes to businesses or by increasing the sales taxes. 
West said a state income tax would probably be fairer to all concerned, but 
itâs probably not going to happen.

Another issue on tap will be the permitting for the stateâs low-level 
radioactive waste disposal, which most likely will involve Waste Control 
Specialists in Andrews County.

The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality is in the process of writing 
and approving an application for a license to dispose of the waste in Texas.
West said all the geology and water issues bode well for WCS in Andrews 
County. West helped write the bill allowing for a private company to be 
licensed for the project.

Local assistant school superintendent David Mitchell asked West to remember 
school children during the next session, Mitchell saying that the 
legislatorsâ efforts on cutting costs had hurt some disadvantaged school kids.
Mitchell was referring to two low-income dental programs geared toward 
certain economically disadvantaged children, who had been hurt by the cuts.

West said he understood Mitchellâs concerns, but said the 78th Legislatureâs 
main task had been finding funds to run the state for another two years. 
West, however, said he saw the need for taking care of students. ãItâs 
probably an issue of Îpay me now, versus pay me later,âä in regards to 
healthy students.

 Bush clears way for mini-nukes
President signs defense bill allocating funds toward major change in weapons 
designs

By STAFF AND WIRE REPORTS

WASHINGTON -- President Bush signed a $401.3 billion defense authorization 
bill Monday, saying members of the U.S. armed forces are facing "a great and 
historic task" in confronting terrorism. 

"The stakes for our country could not be higher," the president said at a 
Pentagon ceremony. "We face enemies that measure their progress by the chaos 
they inflict, the fear they spread and the innocent lives they destroy." 

"America's military is standing between our country and grave danger," he 
proclaimed. 

Though the president focused his comments on the conventional military, the 
defense bill is a first step toward dramatic change in U.S. nuclear weapons 
research. U.S. weapons scientists at Lawrence Livermore, Los Alamos and 
Sandia labs now are encouraged to explore new H-bombs, including low-
yield "mini-nukes," for the first time in nearly a decade.  

Unlike during the Cold War, when nuclear weapons were designed for specific 
threats, the Pentagon's civilian leaders have called for a new "capability-
based" arsenal for uncertain conflicts. 

Bush spoke before leaving for a holiday week at his ranch. On the way to 
Texas, Bush stopped at Fort Carson, Colo., which has lost 28 soldiers in Iraq 
since the president declared an end to major combat on May 1. Four were among 
16 soldiers killed Nov. 2 when a helicopter was shot down in the dangerous 
Sunni Triangle near Fallujah. Fort Carson has sent 12,000 troops to Iraq, its 
largest deployment since World War II. 

The president lunched with soldiers, met privately with families of some who 
have died and spoke about the situation in Iraq, where on Sunday two U.S. 
troops were killed and then pummeled with concrete blocks and a soldier trav 
eling in a convoy was killed by a road-

side bomb. 

Bush said the war in Iraq is making America safer "from terrorists who hate 
what we stand for." He spoke before hundreds of cheering soldiers and family 
members in an aircraft hangar. The soldiers and their families are 
sacrificing for "democracy, tolerance and the rights and dignity of every 
people," Bush said, adding, "The United States of America will not be 
intimidated by a bunch of thugs." 

U.S. policies in Iraq are a major political vulnerability for Bush in the 
2004 election season. 

After months in which more than half of Americans approved of the president's 
handling of Iraq, a recent CNN-USA Today-Gallup poll showed disapproval at 54 
percent and approval at 45 percent. Other polls find the public evenly 
divided on that question. 

Public approval of Bush's handling of the economy, meanwhile, has increased 
recently with positive news on that front. 

Among other things, the defense bill: 

Raises salaries for soldiers by an average of 4.15 percent, and extends 
increases in combat and family separation pay. 

Calls for the Air Force to lease 20 Boeing 767 planes as in-flight refueling 
tankers and to buy 80 more. 

Partially overturns rules preventing disabled veterans from receiving some 
retirement pay as well as disability compensation. 

Grants Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld increased control over 700,000 
civilian employees. Pentagon officials said restrictions on hiring, firing 
and promoting employees forced them to use military personnel for jobs better 
suited for civilians. Democrats said the bill goes too far in stripping 
overtime guarantees and job protection rules. 

Exempts the military to provisions of the Endangered Species Act and the 
Marine Mammal Protection Act. The Pentagon claimed environmental laws 
restrict training exercises; environmentalists said the laws have had little 
effect on training and that the exemptions go too far. 

Lifts a decade-old ban on research into low-yield nuclear weapons and 
authorizes $15 million for continued research into a powerful nuclear weapon 
for threatening deep underground bunkers. 

Weapons scientists are studying making two high-yield nuclear bombs -- the 
B63 designed by Livermore and the B61 designed by Los Alamos -- into tougher, 
more rigid and harder designs so they can survive a plunge through a few 
dozen feet of rock or concrete and detonate. The resulting bomb, known as the 
Robust Nuclear Earth Penetrator, is intended to be used on deeply buried 
bunkers and mountain tunnels, where the Bush administration argues that 
military leaders might feel safe to launch a biological or nuclear strike on 
the United States or its allies. 

In a separate spending bill, however, Republican lawmakers joined Democrats 
in cutting in half the funds for the nuclear penetrator. Congress also made 
sizeable cuts in White House requests for building a new plutonium bomb 
factory and reducing delays for a resumption of nuclear testing, if the 
president requests it. 

"Fortunately, they did not get everything they wanted," said Jon Wolfsthal, 
deputy director of the nonproliferation project for the Carnegie Endowment 
for International Peace. "In a world where they're breaking open every piggy 
bank and can't print money fast enough, they're still hesitant to fund this 
initiative fully."

Headline: Rebuilding nuclear arsenal -- Detail Story
 
      
S. Iqtidar Husain 

The policies of the United States in the nuclear field have recently 
undergone a major shift, and this has serious implications internationally. 
At the end of the cold war both the United States and the former Soviet Union 
decided to scale down their nuclear arsenal reducing the number of warheads 
by sixty per cent by the year 2012. 

This was in terms of the Moscow Treaty, ratified by the US Senate in March 
2003. Production of all other nuclear components and materials was also 
halted. An embargo was placed on all nuclear weapons-testing in the US in 
1992 and the site for such testing at Nevada closed down. All this is now 
changing. 

The first indicator came during the Clinton administration, when the Senate 
refused to ratify in 1998 the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (CTBT), of which 
the US itself was the sponsor. Before the decision in the US Congress, an 
intense debate took place in the American print and electronic media on the 
merits of the CTBT. 

For full four days one watched on various TV channels in the US analyses and 
commentaries by experts on the different clauses of this treaty and its 
implications. all the serious newspapers, the New York Times, Wall Street 
Journal etc. were full of editorials and op-eds on the subject. 

Interestingly what was quite revealing was that in all these writings and 
discussions, barring one college student, a girl of Indian origin, who 
objected to nuclear weapons per se being inherently immoral and devastating, 
no one raised this issue as particularly relevant. Instead, the entire focus 
was on how America would be disadvantaged by acceding to this treaty, in not 
being able to modernize its nuclear arsenal and carry out further research in 
this field; this despite the US possessing the largest and most comprehensive 
stockpile of nuclear weapons in the world. Predictably, the treaty was not 
ratified. 

The Bush administration plunged head-long into the nuclear revival programme, 
with its emphasis on a more assertive nuclear strategy. The first signs of 
the administration's new nuclear policy came last January in its Nuclear 
Posture Review. 

The Policy Paper, produced by the Pentagon, said that the United States 
should not just maintain the capability to launch large nuclear counter-
strikes as a deterrent to nuclear powers, "but should consider possibly 
striking pre-emptively at those countries developing nuclear, chemical or 
biological weapons." 

The doctrine proposed the manufacture of a new generation of nuclear weapons 
called "bunker-busters" to destroy caches of weapons buried deep underground. 
The doctrine also stipulated the creation of low-yield (5 kilo tons) nuclear 
warheads which had been banned in the US under a decade old law. It was also 
recommended that the ban on nuclear weapons testing be lifted. 

The bad news is that the above doctrine is being implemented quite rapidly. 
After much deliberation by the Senate Armed Services Committee, and despite 
some reservations from the Democrats, the Committee cleared proposals in the 
defence budget 2004 to revive America's nuclear arms industry. These 
proposals have been approved by the lower house of the Congress this month 
(November) and would soon be cleared by the Senate. 

The defence spending bill for 2004 provides six million dollars to explore 
new nuclear bomb designs and fifteen million dollars to study modifying 
existing high-powered nuclear weapons so that they can destroy buried 
bunkers. These bombs would be called the "Robust Nuclear Earth Penetrators" 
and would be a modification of existing hydrogen bombs. This proposed device 
would be able to burrow deep into the earth, and to create shock waves 300 
meters below the surface which would be six times more powerful than the 
Hiroshima bomb, experts say. 

The figures given above are just a minor indicator of the overall nuclear re-
vamping programme that is proposed and which runs into billions of dollars. 
According to the San Francisco Chronicle, proposals in President Bush's 
budget would refurbish virtually every facet of the nuclear weapon complex, 
re-building the country's nuclear weapons industry, and resume the production 
of nuclear components and materials, halted after the end of the cold war. 

According to the same paper, the proposals include $ 320 million to build new 
plutonium cores-known as "pits", for nuclear war heads, $ 40 million of which 
would be used to design a plant capable of producing 500 such "pits" a year. 
An additional $ 135 million would go to restart production of tritium, which 
has not been produced by the government for more than a decade. Tritium is a 
gas which dramatically increases the force of thermo nuclear explosions. 

In the words of Robert Civiak, a scientist and analyst on nuclear weapons 
spending, the fastest growing programme in the budget of National Nuclear 
Security Administration, which oversees all nuclear weapons, is refurbishment 
of all the industrial machinery of nuclear warhead production. "People don't 
realize that we are getting back into the nuclear bomb business in a big way, 
and it is a very expensive business" said Joseph Cirinicione, director of the 
non-proliferation project at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. 

The figures for America's stockpile of nuclear materials are mind-boggling, 
though these are classified. Some statistics are available in the US media. 
The Energy Department, in 1999, indicated that there were 12,000 plutonium 
pits in storage in Amarillo, Texas., in addition there are nearly 200 tons of 
highly enriched uranium at the Oak Ridge Reservation in Tennessee, according 
to the Bulletin of Atomic Scientist US officials maintain "we want a nuclear 
arsenal that would last forever." 

Compare the above to the alleged production by Iran and North Korea! The 
charge is that nuclear weapons in the hands of "rogue" states are dangerous, 
but there were many hot-heads in America, including in the administration, 
during the Afghan and Iraq wars who openly advocated the use of nuclear bombs 
in these theatres. 

Disarmament experts state "we are moving away from five decades of efforts to 
delegitimize the use of nuclear weapons." The question is, "does the United 
States need the additional nuclear weapons", especially given its growing 
conventional capabilities in precision guided munitions? 

Remember four different aircraft simultaneously dropping 10,000 lb bombs each 
with precision hitting time on target, while aiming for Saddam Hussain's 
hideout in Baghdad. This was an improvement on the daisy cutter used in the 
caves of Tora Bora. 

The impact of these four bombs together was greater than any conventional 
strike in the past. The irony is they still didn't hit Saddam Husain. And now 
the latest is MOAB (Mother of All Bombs), a 10,000 kg monster that would 
smother the target area with a flammable mist creating a powerful blast. 

There is widespread anxiety about the latest turn in American nuclear plans. 
To quote one American activist from Berkley California "I don't know how 
President Bush and his administration imagine the future, but it can't be one 
dedicated to securing a peaceful co-existence in a prosperous international 
community, intent on maintaining a healthy well educated population. That 
future requires thoughtful approaches to allies and foes alike, to economies 
not solely governed by profits at the expense of subordinate population, to 
environments that support flourishing ecosystem, clean air water and land. 

The Bush administration supports renewed nuclear studies and weapons testing 
and is in favour of a repeal on the ban on smaller more usable nuclear 
warheads. This support and the policy of military pre-emption is an extremely 
dangerous position to foster and perils all life. These are policies which 
must be challenged and defeated, if we, the general citizens of the world, 
are not to be held hostage to the narrower and most restrictive ideas of how 
the world is to be shaped and governed. 

The redesigning of nuclear weapons especially the production of low yield 
ones is going to definitively change the character of nuclear warfare. It 
implies a movement from pure deterrence, the philosophy of MAD (Mutually 
Assured Destruction), to one of actual use - from the strategic to the 
tactical. 

There could be great temptation to actual use of bombs like the bunker-
busters in certain situations, especially where there may not be any 
possibility of nuclear retaliation. The obvious targets for the low - yield 
nuclear weapons and the bunker busters would be errant Third World Countries. 
This could set, off a chain reaction, encouraging others to do the same. 

The threshold between conventional and nuclear warfare is becoming less 
distinct. This does not augur well for the future.

DOE nuclear waste transportation policies questioned 
By Steven Friederich - Journal Writer

POCATELLO - Spent nuclear fuel might have traveled down Interstate 15 last 
month, within hundreds of yards of residential homes, and the public wasn't 
notified.

Nuclear watchdog groups are now calling for a renewed look at DOE's nuclear 
waste transportation policies. And earlier this year, the National Academy of 
Sciences - which provides scientific advice to Congressional officials - 
convened a committee to look at the issue. 
  

The Department of Energy announced last month it would send an unspecified 
number of spent nuclear reactor fuel rods to the Idaho National Engineering 
and Environmental Laboratory from its Oak Ridge National Laboratory in 
Tennessee.

Neither DOE nor Bechtel Jacobs, the company that operates the Oak Ridge site 
for DOE, would disclose the timing or the route for the five planned 
shipments. 

Dennis Hill, spokesman for Bechtel Jacobs, did say the fuel would be 
traveling sometime in November by large trucks using giant protective 
canisters to hold the spent nuclear fuel.

If the fuel did travel by truck, and there's no way to confirm it did because 
DOE spokesman Joe Davis and Hill both cited national security concerns for 
not releasing additional details, the shipment's most direct route would have 
taken it almost 2,000 miles through seven states - Tennessee, Illinois, 
Missouri, Kansas, Nebraska, Wyoming, Utah and Idaho. 

An online travel calculator estimated the trip would take about 30 hours.

"We think people along the routes should be told it's coming through," said 
Pocatello Regional Director Beatrice Brailsford, of the local nuclear 
watchdog group Snake River Alliance. "The government has always treated these 
shipments with a good deal of secrecy. They think if we're ignorant, we're 
safe." 

Chuck Broscious, of the local Environmental Defense Institute, also openly 
objects to not informing the public when nuclear waste travels through 
communities.

Mayor Roger Chase and City Council members Harry Neuhardt and Richard 
Stallings said they haven't been notified a shipment took place. Local police 
officials also recently stated they were unaware of any spent nuclear fuel 
shipments.  
 

A federal contract requires all Oak Ridge spent fuel to be removed from its 
Milton Valley site by 2006, Hill said. INEEL received 40 percent of Oak 
Ridge's total spent nuclear fuel rods and the rest went to a receiving basin 
at DOE's Savannah River site in Georgia, Hill said.

The account of the Oak Ridge fuel follows a similar example from earlier this 
year when local leaders weren't notified. 

According to news reports, a seven-car train carrying spent nuclear fuel rods 
departed Ashford, New York - about 45 miles south of Buffalo - shortly after 
midnight on July 13 and arrived at INEEL four days later. The train carried 
125 irradiated bundles of fuel rods and was shipped 2,360 miles by rail 
without informing local officials, emergency first responders or the public 
along the route.

"At least tell the fire chief," Bill King, town supervisor of Ashford told 
the news media at the time. "These volunteer firefighters are the ones who 
come running any time of day or night to respond to emergencies. If they're 
not prepared and on notice, it threatens them and it threatens the 
community."  
 

Both shipments are authorized by the state's court-enforced 1995 nuclear 
waste cleanup agreement. The government is allowed to send 13 truck shipments 
of high-level waste a year to INEEL through 2012, which is down from 20 
truckloads a year before 2003.

Even so, the 1995 agreement doesn't allow anymore than 497 truck shipments 
before all of the waste has to be removed in 2035. 

According to DOE, there have been more than 3,000 shipments of spent nuclear 
fuel and there has never been a release of radioactive material harmful to 
the public or the environment. Spent nuclear fuel also cannot explode and is 
not a bomb. In fact, through the protective transportation containers, it 
emits very little radiation.

In March of this year, the National Academy of Sciences created the 
Transportation of Radioactive Waste Committee with 15 university professors 
and scientists from some of the most prestigious universities in the country. 
Their goal will be to draft a formal recommendation to Congress by March 2005 
on what to do about nuclear waste transportation.

The committee has met three times, according to the Academy, though key 
members refuse to comment on the committee's activities like Julian Agyeman, 
an associate professor at Tufts University in Massachusetts and professor 
Hank Jenkins-Smith of Texas A&M University. Both are studying the public 
perception of the nuclear industry.

In August, Public Citizen - a government watchdog group founded by former 
presidential candidate Ralph Nader - sent a letter to the National Academy of 
Sciences questioning DOE's procedures in the Ashland shipment.

"We are deeply troubled that the DOE secretly moved this shipment under the 
cover of darkness early on a Sunday morning without notifying the public," 
wrote Lisa Gue, Public Citizen's senior energy analyst in the Aug. 11 dated 
letter.

"While we do not dispute the need to address the national security 
implications of nuclear waste transportation, we are not convinced that this 
level of secrecy is justified, or that it meaningfully reduced risks," she 
said. "On the contrary, such secrecy fundamentally conflicts with the 
principles of government transparency and accountability essential to 
protecting the public interest."

Brendan Hoffman, a Public Citizen energy specialist, said the recent truck 
shipment through Pocatello adds to the controversy because local leaders 
continue not to be notified.

"The whole national security argument is ridiculous," he said. "If you want 
to find the shipment, you'll find it."

Hoffman said the public should be notified at least a week in advance because 
though the likelihood of an accident is small, "For anyone who wants to get 
out of town, they should have the option."

Stallings, a four-term U.S. representative and a former nuclear waste 
negotiator for the Clinton administration, said I-15 has seen tons of spent 
fuel and other nuclear materials cross its pavement, but has never had a 
major accident.

"I'd be more scared of what's going over our railroads than the nuclear 
material on our highways," he said.

In an interview with PBS's Frontline, Stallings said transporting nuclear 
waste emotionally scares people beyond belief - even in an area like 
Pocatello, which has had hundreds of its citizens work at INEEL.

"When we raised the issue that people would be carrying spent fuel through 
the railroad yards in Pocatello, or that trucks would be bringing it through 
I-15 É and does that make you nervous, the numbers just go off the scale," he 
said. "There's tremendous fear that's somehow there's going to be an accident 
and their kids are going to be affected for their life. It's unreal. It's not 
likely to happen. And yet it's hard to convince people otherwise."

Steven Friederich covers the Idaho National Engineering and Environmental 
Laboratory along with federal and local political issues for the Journal. He 
can be reached at (208) 239-6001 or by e-mail at sfriederich@journalnet.com.

Pantex officials update neighbors on environmental issues 
12/02/2003 
Associated Press 

Environmental monitoring is continuing at the Pantex plant, say officials who 
are also updating cleanup plans at the nuclear weapons facility. 

Panhandle residents were briefed Monday on well monitoring and environmental 
remediation plans in a quarterly update. Pantex is the nation's primary 
assembly and disassembly plant for nuclear warheads. 

Plant officials are analyzing data and writing reports, said Dennis 
Huddleston, manager of environmental remediation for BWXT Pantex. Huddleston 
presented information on the risk-based end state vision, a plan to 
standardize cleanups across all sites. 

"It will bring consistency and a common-sense approach to cleanup," he told 
the Amarillo Globe-News in Tuesday's online edition. 

Included in the plan are corrective measures to reduce risk at all sites 
beginning by May 2005. 

Information on an airborne geophysics progress report was presented by Jeff 
Paine, an investigator for Pantex from the economic geology division of 
University of Texas at Austin. The report measures conductivity on sites 
around the plant to detect changes in the sediment type and water saturation. 

Jeri Osborne, a Pantex neighbor, said information on an airborne 
electromagnetic survey was of interest because those planes fly directly over 
her home. 

"I try to get enough information to ask the right questions," she said, 
adding there was no alarming information in Monday's presentations.

Posted on Tue, Dec. 02, 2003   
http://www.bayarea.com/mld/cctimes/news/7393327.htm
Commission advocates lab competition
By Andrea Widener
CONTRA COSTA TIMES

A long-anticipated report has found that managers of federal research labs 
should regularly compete to continue running the science facilities, a 
judgment that could have a major impact on the University of California.

Among its most controversial conclusions is that Lawrence Livermore and Los 
Alamos labs contracts should be bid separately, which would likely make 
competition easier for an outsider and harder for UC. The university has run 
the two weapons labs uninterrupted for more than half a century.

The report by the so-called Blue Ribbon Commission found that competition 
would benefit the labs and recommended a process to better link lab 
performance to the competition decision. At the same time, it recognized 
problems with the Department of Energy's lab oversight, which often gave labs 
high marks even when there were major management failures.

"The principles arguing for free and open competition and (the) benefits to 
be gained through competition could address the management problems perceived 
in the current operation of the laboratories," the report states.

The commission has been controversial since its beginning, when several 
people complained the group was weighted toward favoring competition and that 
it included a Defense Department official on leave from the University of 
Texas -- a potential UC competitor to run the weapons labs.

A skeptic of the commission's makeup, Rep. Ellen Tauscher said she was not 
surprised with the findings that competition is necessary and that UC's labs 
should be bid separately.

"I do not think that they have any significant reasoning behind their 
decision not to have" Los Alamos and Livermore competed together, said 
Tauscher, D-Alamo, who represents the area that includes Lawrence Livermore 
and Sandia/California. "They were meant to answer the hard questions. What 
they have done is kick a hard question down the street."

Commission member Jacques Gansler said the group met with people of every 
point of view, and he thought it was an open and fair process. He said the 
group was not swayed by arguments that the weapons labs should be run by the 
same manager.

"We were truly independent," said Gansler, interim dean and professor at the 
University of Maryland's school of public affairs. "... We weren't convinced 
that (joint management) was the overriding consideration."

The report was spurred by a DOE decision this spring to make the university 
compete to continue running Los Alamos after 60 years as its sole manager -- 
a move spurred by business and management problems at the New Mexico lab. A 
recent Congressional decision forced competition for all contracts older than 
50 years, including UC's other labs, Lawrence Livermore and Lawrence 
Berkeley, a multidisciplinary science lab.

The commission examined management of Energy Department labs nationwide. Its 
conclusions are not binding on the DOE, which oversees 18 major contractor-
operated labs, but they are sure to be influential on future searches for new 
lab managers.

Competition has been the agency's stated policy for years. But it only bid 
contracts when something has gone wrong, so competition is seen as punitive, 
Gansler said.

"In a sense, you've got to start over now (with this report). It is a new set 
of rules," he said.

Scott Sudduth, who oversees governmental relations at UC, said the commission 
recognizes that there have been problems with previous reviews.

"The public perception is that UC has had its hand slapped by having the labs 
competed, and no one -- absolutely no one -- has questioned the university's 
stewardship of the fundamental mission of the labs," Sudduth said. "I think 
the commission is recognizing that the process is partly to blame for that."

The report sets out a new process that allows excellent managers to have 
their contract extended for up to 20 years, but it could be competed as 
regularly as every five years. They also sets up a new, more rigorous 
evaluation procedure that brings in outside panels and high-level DOE 
management to decide how lab managers are performing.

In competition itself, the group recognized that nonprofits may be at a 
disadvantage in an open competition that could cost $3 million to $5 million, 
so it recommended a grant of up to $2 million.

Tauscher said only giving nonprofits half the necessary amount was 
ridiculous. "It is a big problem, and we're going to give you half a 
solution," she said.

UC was glad to see the commission recognized the special problems for 
nonprofits, Sudduth said, but contends competition could cost $10 million or 
more.

Despite the commission's findings, Sudduth said UC continues to believe the 
Los Alamos and Livermore contracts should be competed together. "We will 
continue to make the case, and we think there are others that will make the 
case, that you don't want to rock the apple cart when it comes to the 
nation's nuclear deterrent."

The report will be reviewed at a Dec. 10 meeting. A full copy of the report, 
and more information, is available at www.seab.doe.gov/news.htm.

Approx. Tues Dec 2 2003
No Utah site will take 'hot' waste from Ohio, N.Y. 
By Judy Fahys 
The Salt Lake Tribune 

    A southeastern Utah uranium recycler is not in the running as a possible 
burial ground for highly concentrated radioactive waste from two 
controversial government cleanups. 

  Officials at the International Uranium Corp. White Mesa uranium mill have 
confirmed the company never planned to bid for waste from Ohio and New York. 

  With the decision last week by Envirocare of Utah to drop its federal 
application to receive the waste -- and International Uranium out of the 
picture -- there are no commercial facilities in Utah eligible to accept the 
13,000 cubic yards of radioactive material from government cleanups in 
Fernald, Ohio, and Niagara Falls, N.Y. 

  International Uranium President Ron Hochstein noted that his company is 
not licensed for "direct disposal" of the K-65 waste, like the stuff stored 
in two silos at Fernald. Even though the mill has recycled mildly 
contaminated tailings from similar uranium ore in the past, his company would 
not seek the license change needed for White Mesa to be considered, he said. 

  "Silos 1 and 2 are too hot for us to handle," said Hochstein, whose 
company is one of San Juan County's biggest employers. 

  In fact, none of the nation's commercial storage sites -- including the 
two in Utah -- has the government approvals needed to accept the waste. 

  Congress helped clear the way for commercial disposal of the K-65 sludge 
with passage last week of the Energy and Water Appropriations Bill. The bill 
reclassified the unusually concentrated radium waste so that it could be 
buried in a surface landfill rather than in a government-owned underground 
disposal site as originally proposed. 

  "We are going to continue to pursue all the options we can," said Jeff 
Wagner, a spokesman for Fluor Fernald, the contractor for the Fernald 
cleanup. 

  "Our interest is to make sure we find a safe home for this waste and can 
do it in an efficient and cost-effective manner," he added, "and [we] can do 
it on our closure schedule of 2006." 

  Fluor Fernald had been looking for years for a way to send the K-65 waste 
to Envirocare's privately owned radioactive and hazardous waste landfill in 
Tooele County, rather than sending it to the government-owned Nevada Test 
Site. The contractor, the U.S. Energy Department's choice for the $1.4 
billion cleanup, described Envirocare as the safest and cheapest option for 
disposing of the waste, which, untreated and undiluted, is roughly 125 times 
more concentrated than currently allowed in Utah. 

  Radium emits penetrating gamma rays, as well as alpha radiation, a known 
carcinogen. It is considered a hazard to human health and the environment 
forever. 

  Envirocare had asked the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission to increase 
its license for uranium byproduct waste from its current 4,000 picocuries 
radium per gram of waste to 100,000 picocuries radium per gram. But the 
company promised U.S. Rep. Rob Bishop, R-Utah, and state legislators that it 
would not pursue the license change until Utah takes over the byproduct 
regulation program from the NRC -- a switch that is not expected to be 
complete until next spring. 

  Envirocare also faced mounting public concern about the plans, which 
clash with the state's current policy of only taking mildly tainted 
radioactive waste. 

  The company's withdrawal dashed the Energy Department's plans to use the 
Utah site. It also jeopardizes Fluor Fernald's hopes of getting a $215 
million performance bonus for getting the job done by a December 2006 
deadline. 

  By dropping its license-change request, Envirocare will lose out on the 
$14 million Ohio contract -- a contract the company claimed in an Oct. 21 
advertisement that would also be sought by "competitors in Colorado and 
Texas." 

  Commercial facilities in Washington and South Carolina are not licensed 
by the NRC to accept uranium byproduct waste. Low-level facilities in Idaho, 
Texas, Colorado and White Mesa also do not have the proper government 
licenses. 

  Said Myron Fliegel, who was reviewing Envirocare's license amendment for 
the NRC: "I don't know that there's a viable [uranium byproduct] facility 
that could take it." 

  Although Fluor Fernald is looking for other options, it appears 
Envirocare was its best and only hope for commercial disposal. 

  Fluor Fernald, the contractor cleaning up the uranium mill site in Ohio, 
now is proceeding with its plans to haul the waste cross-country to a 
government-owned disposal facility at the Nevada Test Site. The company would 
not disclose whether the waste would travel through Utah on its way to Nevada 
for fear of sharing sensitive information with would-be terrorists. 

  fahys@sltrib.com

EPA completes cleanup of polluted land six months early
12/3/2003 10:44 PM
By: Estacion, Mary

    
 Work to clean up the former Tex Tin plant.   
It's been quite a few years since Abel Garza worked at the old Tex Tin 
facility in Texas City.

"We didn't even use gas masks," Garza says. "You had to put your own 
handkerchief, whatever you had in your pocket, to put over your face."

But that was then, this is now. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency led 
an effort to clean up the 170-acre site, with workers covered in protective 
gear.

"It had enormous amounts of hazards, chemicals, acids pits, radioactive 
material," Myron Knudson says.

Fifteen tons of that radioactive material was disposed of, along with 50 tons 
of the byproduct used in the tin smelting process -- a Superfund site cleaned 
up six months ahead of schedule and $10 million under budget.

"This is a model for EPA, as I've been told by the Region 6 administrator," 
Mayor Carlos Garza says.

Land that was once filled with hazardous material could now be used as a 
major port in Texas City. Mary Estacion explains.

As city officials consider the future of Tex Tin, Mayor Garza says he hopes 
to make the newly available land a big part of the city's plan to build a 
megaport.

"We have a tentative commitment from Stevedoring Services of America. SSA 
plans on using half of it for an intermodal yard, where they will spur into 
the railroad tracks to bring in containers
as well as load new containers onto it for ships throughout the United States 
region," Mayor Garza says.

But there's still work left to do. Swan Lake, contaminated by some waste 
products from the Tex Tin plant, borders Galveston Bay. So jetties are being 
built to minimize any environmental impact. 

EPA officials say only one Superfund site in the Houston-Galveston area 
remains on their priority list.

Malone Services, a former hazardous waste storage facility in Texas City, was 
put on the list two years ago.

Its cleanup is still in the planning stages.

Dec 4 2003
SF Chronicle
UC faculty stunned by Berkeley lab bid plan 
Out-of-state school would win contract 

Keay Davidson, Chronicle Science Writer   Thursday, December 4, 2003 
  
UC Berkeley faculty shuddered Wednesday at the prospects that the Lawrence 
Berkeley National Laboratory, their longtime neighbor and a veritable factory 
for Nobel Prizes, could be run by an out-of-state university or even a for-
profit corporation. 

"This would be a major disaster, a really major disaster on top of everything 
else we have to deal with now" in the financially strapped UC system and 
state of California, said Randy Schekman, a professor of cell and 
developmental biology. 

Loss of the University of California's half-century-old job as lab manager 
would be a blow to the state's pride and hurt efforts to attract -- or 
retain -- top students, faculty and investors, shocked faculty said. The 
present contract to run Lawrence Berkeley runs out on Jan. 31. 

The reaction came one day after revelations that President Bush signed 
legislation requiring competition for contracts to manage six national 
laboratories financed by the U.S. Energy Department. Three of those labs are 
run by the University of California: Lawrence Berkeley, in the hills 
overlooking the UC Berkeley campus, the Lawrence Livermore and Los Alamos, 
N.M. , nuclear weapons labs. 

The other national labs affected by the legislation are in Illinois, Iowa and 
Idaho. 

Following recent financial, managerial and security scandals at Los Alamos, 
embarrassed UC officials had fully expected their punishment -- a forced 
competition for the next five-year contract to run Los Alamos. UC has run 
that lab, where the first atomic bombs were built, since World War II. 

The provision requiring the competitions -- which affects national labs that 
have enjoyed no-bid contracts for 50 years -- was tucked into the $27.3 
billion spending bill by an Ohio Republican, Rep. David Hobson. 

"The idea of having to compete for LBNL is certainly catching us by 
surprise," said Robert G. Jacobsen, vice chair of the physics 
department. "That's not something that we, as individual faculty members, had 
been concerned about." 

Jacobsen fears that in months ahead, uncertainty over who will end up running 
Lawrence Berkeley could adversely affect proposed collaborations among UC 
Berkeley faculty, Lawrence Berkeley lab staffers and outside collaborators. 

Faculty also worry that a new manager -- especially a nonuniversity manager --
 might bureaucratize ties between the main campus and Lawrence Berkeley. That 
might make it harder for faculty to arrange everything from travel to 
conferences and equipment purchases. 

Also, they warn, if an outside owner takes over, it might be tougher for UC 
to attract top faculty. That's partly because campus officials could no 
longer guarantee certain perks to a coveted candidate -- perks such as a 
Lawrence Berkeley job for the candidate's spouse or quick access to Lawrence 
Berkeley's veritable toy store of supercomputers and supergadgets. 

Possible competitors for running any of the contested labs range from outside 
universities, such as the huge University of Texas system, to for- profit 
corporations such as Lockheed Martin, which already runs Sandia National 
Laboratories, to nonprofit research institutions such as Battelle, which runs 
other labs including Pacific Northwest National Laboratory in Washington 
state. 

"It would create a civil war (at UC Berkeley) if (Lawrence Berkeley) were 
managed by some other university -- it would be an intolerable 
circumstance, " Schekman said. "Can you imagine that? The University of Texas 
running LBNL? It would be intolerable. 

"And it (leaves) us facing the most vulnerable position, with further budget 
cuts (statewide). We're in a completely untenable situation. We can't print 
money -- and it might cost millions of dollars just to compete." 

A change in owners for Lawrence Berkeley "could potentially be calamitous, " 
said integrativebiology professor Thomas M. "Zack" Powell, chair of UC 
Berkeley's Energy and Resources Group. "The level of expertise up there (at 
Lawrence Berkeley Lab) is extraordinary -- it's one of those places where you 
walk down the hall and in an office is the world's expert on something or 
other. 

"Some of those people are going to leave (if management changes). They're 
just going to throw up their hands and say, 'I don't want to be managed by a 
corporate entity or a university a half-country away.' " Powell added. "Some 
of those people -- and not just the high-end scientists and technicians -- 
will have no trouble finding a position elsewhere in the Bay Area right 
away .. . and they'll probably get substantially more money." 

Many employees at the Livermore lab "would prefer to retain the UC 
connection," said lab spokesperson Linda Seaver. "Everybody here has sort of 
a wait-and-see attitude." The lab, founded in 1952, has more than 8,000 
employees. 

Asked if officials at the University of Chicago, which manages the Argonne 
National Laboratory in Illinois and its sister lab in Idaho, are upset for 
being sucked into a federal shakeup triggered by UC's alleged mismanagement 
of the Los Alamos lab, University of Chicago spokesperson Larry Arbeiter 
laughed and said: "That's a very good question and I won't answer that on the 
record." 

E-mail the writer at kdavidson@sfchronicle.com.

Thursday, December 4, 2003 4:49PM EST

Study finds N.C. power plants emit most toxic chemicals in country 

By EMERY P. DALESIO, , Associated Press Writer

RALEIGH, N.C. (AP) - Power plants in North Carolina pumped more toxic 
chemicals into the atmosphere than those run by electric utilities in any 
other state, a national study by a liberal watchdog group reported Thursday.
The Public Interest Research Group, analyzing 2001 data collected by the 
Environmental Protection Agency, found North Carolina's coal-fired power 
plants belched more than 78 million pounds of toxic chemicals into the air in 
2001, the last year for which figures were available. The state's two major 
utilities are Raleigh-based Progress Energy and Charlotte-based Duke Power.
The report found that electric utilities were the biggest air polluters, 
while metal mining accounted for half the pollution of the water and land. 
Nearly 75 percent of the pollution rising from utilities was hydrochloric 
acid and another 16 percent was sulfuric acid.

"We've known for years that these are some of the biggest sources," said 
Martha Keating of Efland, who co-authored the PIRG report. "I guess what's 
new is that we're running up against a political and legal juncture."

The report was released as the Bush administration considers regulations that 
would allow power plant owners to postpone for up to a decade requirements 
that they install specific technology designed to reduce mercury pollution.

"Utilities will be further reducing mercury emissions in the next few years," 
said Dan Riedinger, a spokesman for the Edison Electric Institute, a trade 
group for the country's utilities.

The PIRG report found that electric utilities in Texas - President Bush's 
home state - were the largest emitters of mercury into the air and water. 
Texas power plants were responsible for about 10 percent of the mercury 
released into the air, the report found.

Ohio, Pennsylvania, Indiana and West Virginia utilities were the next largest 
mercury polluters, combining for 38 percent of the total nationwide.

Mercury is a persistent substance that affects the nervous system and is 
especially dangerous for pregnant women and children. Mercury concentrations 
in fish have prompted at least 43 states to issue fish consumption 
advisories. Forty percent of mercury emissions come from the smokestacks of 
coal-burning power plants, but the emissions have never been regulated as a 
pollutant.

Coal-burning electric generating plants were responsible for 17 percent of 
toxic pollutants nationwide in 2001. That was slightly more than 1 billion 
pounds, down from 1.2 billion pounds in 2000.

North Carolina's power plants were blamed for 11 percent of the national 
total for all toxic chemical releases into the air, the report said.

Duke Power spokesman Tom Williams said while half the company's generating 
capacity comes from coal-burning power plants, the remaining half comes from 
nuclear power.

"We're very proud of our coal plants. They're among the most efficient in the 
nation," Williams said. "All I can say is that our plants have gotten cleaner 
and cleaner."

Sulfur dioxide scrubbers the state's utilities are installing in coming years 
also will remove some mercury emissions, he said.

A spokesman for Raleigh-based Progress Energy did not immediately return 
calls for comment Thursday.

Ohio, Pennsylvania, Florida, West Virginia and Georgia rounded out the 
dirtiest half-dozen states on PIRG's ranking of power plant pollution. The 
top six states accounted for half the nation's airborne toxic chemical 
releases in 2001, the report said.

On Thursday, the EPA proposed capping emissions of sulfur dioxide and smog-
causing nitrogen oxide from factories and power plants in 30 states, most of 
them east of the Mississippi River. Smog and fine soot, much of it from power 
plants, are blamed for respiratory problems, especially among children and 
the elderly.

Neither sulfur dioxide nor nitrogen oxide is among the toxic chemicals that 
must be reported to the EPA.

Dec. 5, 2003, 10:19PM

Reliant likely to skip buying plant stake
By LAURA GOLDBERG
Copyright 2003 Houston Chronicle
Reliant Resources said Friday it's not likely to exercise its option to buy a 
majority stake in the Texas power plant subsidiary of CenterPoint Energy. 

Houston-based CenterPoint Energy holds 81 percent of Texas Genco Holdings, 
with the rest owned by public shareholders. Reliant Resources, which sells 
power on a retail level to consumers under the Reliant Energy brand in 
Houston and elsewhere in Texas, has an option exercisable between Jan. 10 and 
Jan. 24 to purchase CenterPoint's Texas Genco stake. 

Texas Genco has power plants in the Houston area, along with a 30.8 percent 
stake in a nuclear plant in Matagorda County and a plant in Limestone County. 

CenterPoint spokeswoman Leticia Lowe said Friday the company's strategy is to 
sell its Texas Genco stake, whether to Reliant or another buyer. 

A financial adviser has already been hired to help the company explore 
alternatives should Reliant not exercise its option. 

CenterPoint, which plans to use proceeds from a sale to pay down debt, can't 
begin marketing Texas Genco until Reliant's option expires. 

Shares in all three companies closed down Friday. CenterPoint ended down 40 
cents at $9.52, while Reliant closed down 23 cents at $6.16. Shares in Texas 
Genco took the biggest hit, sliding $2.35 to $29.60. 

In a written statement Friday, Joel Staff, Reliant's chairman and chief 
executive, said as the company makes a decision, it is weighing its power 
supply needs for its Texas retail electric business, the cost of the deal and 
impact on earnings. 

Staff said that because Texas Genco's earnings are affected by prices of 
natural gas, buying the stake "would likely add substantial volatility to 
Reliant's earnings." 

He also noted that Reliant already has power supplies under contract to meet 
about two-thirds of next year's projected needs for its retail business and 
to meet a significant portion of 2005's needs. 

Over time, he said, Reliant is likely to buy individual generating assets to 
supplement the power it buys from others.

www.lubbockonline.com

The Lubbock Avalanche-Journal
Story last updated at 12:41 a.m. Monday, December 8, 2003 
Company promises to deal with nuclear waste
LOUISIANA ENERGY Services says it will remove waste from proposed plant in 
a 'timely manner.' 


SANTA FE (AP) ÷ The company that wants to build a nuclear fuel plant in New 
Mexico has made a written commitment to remove the plant's nuclear waste in 
a "timely manner."

Louisiana Energy Services promised in a letter Saturday to Gov. Bill 
Richardson to store the waste at its proposed site only temporarily.

LES president Jim Ferland wrote "there will be no disposal or long-term 
storage (beyond the life of the plant) of uranium byproduct cylinders in the 
state of New Mexico."

LES plans to use uranium enriched at the plant, which would be built near 
Hobbs, to fuel nuclear power plants around the world.

Opponents are concerned the plant's radioactive waste could end up stored on 
the plant site indefinitely because there is no place to get rid of it.

The waste requires processing before it can be shipped to a low-level nuclear 
waste dump, but there is not a U.S. waste facility capable of doing that.

Ferland committed to work with a private company outside of New Mexico to get 
rid of the waste. In addition, LES plans to post a bond worth $27 million 
each year the plant operates to ensure that there will be enough money 
available to get rid of the waste.

Ferland's letter is an attempt to clear up a controversy created over a 
provision added to the failed energy bill by Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., who 
is chairman of the Senate Energy Committee.

The provision would have forced the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to act 
within two years on an application by LES, which has been trying to build the 
plant since the late 1980s.

It also provided a method for the federal government to take responsibility 
for the waste. Richardson's office feared that provision would mean the waste 
would end up sitting at the New Mexico facility because the federal 
government has no way to deal with the waste.

LES officials said Saturday they do not intend to use the provision in 
Domenici's proposed legislation.

"It's been LES's intention all along to find an appropriate disposal path, 
and that in our minds has always been a private facility," company spokesman 
Doug Turner said.

It is unclear what the government would do with LES waste.

Secrecy doesn't help waste issue
Monday, December 08, 2003 - 12:00 AM 
The Daily Herald 
  
Want to know why Utahns are distrustful of the government's original plan to 
bring radioactive waste from Fernald, Ohio, to Utah?

It might have to do with the Department of Energy's unwillingness to respond 
to questions in a timely manner.

The Daily Herald has tried since October to contact DOE officials about the 
Fernald cleanup.It's now two months later, and we're still waiting for 
answers to several questions, including:

 --   Why didn't DOE try to get regular legislation introduced to reclassify 
Fernald's uranium tailings rather than use last-minute amendments tacked on 
after the bills had been debated? Does it prefer secrecy?

 --   Why did the DOE change its mind about disposing of the material at the 
Nevada Test Site and push for Envirocare of Utah instead?

 --   Why did the department conduct public hearings on the Fernald cleanup in 
New Mexico, Nevada, Tennessee, Missouri, California, Washington, D.C., Texas 
and South Carolina -- but not in Utah -- when it changed plans and decided to 
send the waste to Envirocare's facility in Tooele County? Shouldn't the 
people of Utah have had a chance to speak on this subject before the waste 
showed up at their doorstep?

 --   If Nevada won't take the stuff, and Envirocare can't take it, what 
happens? It obviously can't stay in Ohio.

These are all fair questions, the answers to which would enhance public 
understanding of this issue. The DOE's reluctance to answer fuels the 
suspicion, reasonable or not, that something foul is afoot.

The unresponsiveness further fuels the mistrust Utahns understandably have of 
the government on radioactive matters. Government officials said that the 
above-ground atomic tests in Nevada posed no threat, and many Utahns paid the 
ultimate price for that.

If the Department of Energy is seeking a receptive audience in Utah, it needs 
to be willing to answer questions and allow residents to make informed 
decisions. If it can't, then it has only itself to blame when public opinion 
is based on an incomplete set of facts.

This story appeared in The Daily Herald on page A5.

CALIFORNIA TO SOUTH CAROLINA
Nuclear reactor set for journey
By Bruce Henderson
Knight Ridder

CHARLOTTE, N.C. - Few retirees could ever have gone to such lengths to 
relocate in rural Barnwell as a decommissioned nuclear reactor waiting to be 
shipped from San Onofre, Calif.

Barnwell's low-level nuclear waste site is the only port in an awfully long 
storm for the 770-ton reactor vessel. It has been shunned by railroads, 
Panama Canal authorities and a West Coast dump.

So Southern California Edison will do what it must: barge its radioactive 
cargo 11,000 miles by way of Cape Horn, at the tip of South America. The 
voyage will take three months.

Taking the scenic route to Barnwell illustrates a larger problem: what to do 
with America's retired nuclear plant parts.

Barnwell is the only site open to waste from throughout the United States. 
But that will change in 2008, when it will close to all states except South 
Carolina, Connecticut and New Jersey.

Seventeen reactors are being decommissioned, said the Nuclear Energy 
Institute, an industry group. Fifty-one of the nation's 103 operating 
reactors have had licenses renewed, are under review or are expected to ask 
for extensions.

"This is a real question: Where are these things going to go? What's going to 
happen to them in the future?" said Tom Clements of Greenpeace International.

Many shut-down reactors will simply stay put, an option environmental groups 
favor.

But industry experts acknowledge there's no final solution to low-level 
waste, the mildly radioactive debris includes dirty rags and reactor 
components.

A 1980 federal law meant to establish regional disposal sites hasn't overcome 
political resistance to them. North Carolina is being sued by other 
Southeastern states for failing to open a replacement site for Barnwell.

A private site in Utah is licensed to accept only the most lightly 
contaminated low-level waste. Another in Richland, Wash., is open only to 
Northwestern and Rocky Mountain states. Texas is moving toward opening a low-
level site, but it, too, would limit access.

Duke Power sends its low-level wastes to Barnwell and to Utah.

Barnwell, meanwhile, stands at a crossroad. It earns South Carolina millions 
but also symbolizes the state's unwanted reputation as a nuclear dumping 
ground.

Gov. Mark Sanford has been briefed on the coming reactor, spokesman Will 
Folks said.

"The governor has said all along that we need to strike a balance between the 
economic development of our nuclear facilities, like Barnwell and the 
Savannah River Site, and the need to protect our environment," Folks said. 
Barnwell's future beyond 2008, he said, "is a long way down the road."

Four reactor vessels already have been entombed at Barnwell, most recently 
one from Michigan's Big Rock Point plant in October. Other than San Onofre, 
one more reactor is scheduled to be buried there in July 2004 from the 
Connecticut Yankee Nuclear Plant, said Chem-Nuclear Systems, the company that 
runs Barnwell.

"As far as we're concerned, a reactor pressure vessel is the same waste as we 
take in through the gate everyday," spokesman Deborah Ogilvie said. "It's 
just in a bigger package."

Southern California Edison last week got a key government permit for the 
reactor's trip, which will begin with its being rolled 15 miles down a beach.

Decommissioning the San Onofre reactor, which operated from 1968 to 1992, 
will take eight years and $600 million. Two other reactors are still 
operating at the plant.

Now filled with concrete, the retired reactor vessel emits relatively little 
radiation. Standing beside it for an hour would equal half a chest X-ray, 
officials say.

Even so, Greenpeace says shipping such parts needlessly exposes the public to 
radiation and the risk of accidents.

No departure date is set.

Once in Charleston, the reactor will ride the 120 miles to Barnwell on a rail 
car.

Dec. 17, 2003, 5:24PM

State moves ahead with radioactive waste process
Associated Press
BC-TX--Radioactive Waste, Bjt,0530 

State moves ahead with radioactive waste process 

snglf 

By NATALIE GOTT Associated Press Writer 

AUSTIN (AP) -- State regulators approved rules Wednesday that companies are 
to follow when they apply to run a planned low-level radioactive waste site 
in West Texas. 

"It's a big step," said Susan Jablonski of the Texas Commission on 
Environmental Quality. "Having the rules out there allows everybody to know 
what the rules of this commission (are) going to be." 

Lawmakers in the spring approved a bill that allows for the creation of two 
privately-run waste disposal facilities licensed by the state. 

One would handle waste under a compact between Texas, Vermont and Maine, 
although Maine has since dropped out of the compact. A separate but adjacent 
facility would take U.S. Department of Energy waste. 

The rules adopted by the TCEQ lay out what the application has to include, 
such as financial security and the technical requirements. The rules also 
list the criteria for evaluating multiple applications, Jablonski said. 

"If they are going to apply, you want them to put their best foot forward," 
Jablonski said. "We want applications that have all the information that we 
need in order to evaluate them." 

Jablonski said it will be at least the end of 2007 before a license is 
awarded. 

Rep. Lon Burnam, a Democrat from Fort Worth who fought against the bill in 
the Legislature, said the commissioners passed "pretty good rules." 

"While I think the law is a horrible anti-public interest bill that should 
have never passed in the first place, the commission has done more good than 
I thought they may have been able to pull off," Burnam said. 

He applauded the commissioners' decision that the applications be posted on 
the Internet and said the commissioners expressed a willingness to consider 
creating a citizen oversight panel, something he supports. 

Jablonski said the commissioners are open to a citizen advisory committee but 
want to talk further about how it would be constructed. She said such a 
committee did not have to be set up now. 

Michael Woodward, an attorney who represents Dallas-based Waste Control 
Specialists, said the company was excited that the rules have been adopted so 
it can move forward with the application process. He said the company will 
seek the license to operate the waste site. 

"Any facility licensed under these rules, which provide very strict criteria, 
will be protective of health and the environment," Woodward said. 

The TCEQ also approved a rule change on how it treats pollution released by a 
company either by accident, during routine maintenance or when a facility 
shuts down or starts up. Under the new rule, the emission releases either 
have to be permitted for or they would be considered a violation if the 
company couldn't prove the releases were unavoidable. 

The TCEQ was under pressure from the Environmental Protection Agency to 
change the rule.

Pennsylvania News
Council concerned about waste 
Resident wants landfill policy re-examined. 
Thursday, December 18, 2003
By JEFF SCHOGOL 
The Express-Times 

PLAINFIELD TWP. -- Grand Central Sanitary Landfill accepts low-level 
radioactive waste, landfill operations manager Bruce Fahs said Wednesday. 

Fahs testified during a public hearing on Waste Management Inc.'s application 
to expand Grand Central by about 43 acres. 
   
     
Wednesday marked the ninth hearing on the matter since Sept. 11. 

Fahs said if the landfill's radiation detectors go off when a truck drives 
by, the truck is inspected. 

In some situations, Waste Management must call the state Department of 
Environmental Protection which decides if the truck can dump its load or not, 
Fahs said. 

Fahs said the DEP has allowed trucks to dump low-level radioactive waste at 
the landfill but only if it has determined the waste does not pose a health 
risk. 

Fahs noted that radiation is a naturally occurring phenomenon. One source of 
low level radioactive waste is iodine, which is used in medical procedures, 
he said. 

Another source of low-level radiation is discarded wrist watches, said Waste 
Management spokesman Harry Smith. 

Waste Management attorney Anthony Martino said the landfill accepts 
a "minuscule" amount of low-level radioactive waste. 

But Pen Argyl is concerned about the low-level radioactive waste, so much so 
that it monitors landfill leachate treated at the borough's sewage treatment 
plant for radiation, said borough Councilman David De Palma. 

Washington Township resident Sherry Darr asked why Waste Management needs 
radiation detectors to know if a truck is carrying low-level radioactive 
waste. 

Darr said Waste Management should know which trucks have low-level 
radioactive waste beforehand. Those trucks should be tested before they reach 
the landfill and clearly identified if they contain low-level radioactive 
waste, she said. 

She said she did not think any radioactive waste should be allowed in the 
landfill at all. 

She also said she is not confident in the DEP's ability to investigate 
radioactive incidents based on their poor track record investigating odor 
complaints. 

Darr said she wants to know if there are public records detailing how much 
low-level radioactive waste is being disposed of at the landfill and where it 
comes from. 

Township supervisors Chairman Randy Lieberman said he was unaware that low-
level radioactive waste was being dumped at the landfill. 

Lieberman said the board of supervisors would be concerned about the waste. 

Processed infectious waste was another topic at Wednesday's hearing. 

Martino submitted a letter from the DEP stating the landfill accepts only 
processed infectious waste. 

Supervisors were concerned when they learned in October that the landfill 
accepted processed infectious waste. But the landfill can only accept 
infectious waste that has been disinfected, according to a letter from 
William Tomayko of the DEP. 

Even so, the supervisors must determine if the township zoning ordinance 
allows the landfill to accept any infectious waste, processed or otherwise, 
said township Solicitor David Backenstoe. 

Supervisors also must determine if the zoning ordinance's provision for 
infectious waste is preempted by state regulations, Backenstoe said. 

Also Wednesday, landfill engineer Jan Hutwelker presented supervisors with 
more information about the health risk assessment commissioned by Waste 
Management. 

The health risk assessment concluded that the landfill poses no health risk 
to the public. 

Hutwelker gave supervisors information about where dust samples were taken as 
well as descriptions of weather conditions when the samples were taken. 

Pen Argyl solicitor Peter Layman noted that the data on wind direction taken 
at the landfill's meteorological station was different from data taken at 
dust sampling points. 

Hutwelker acknowledged the conflicting data and said it is difficult to 
determine the direction of the wind when it is calm. 

Layman said the disparity could mean the data is flawed or it could mean that 
wind swirls at the landfill, making it difficult to stop litter and dust from 
blowing off the site. 

The landfill expansion hearing scheduled for today was canceled because Waste 
Management did not have a witness ready, Backenstoe said. 

Reporter Jeff Schogol can be reached at 610-863-4025 or by e-mail at 
jschogol@express-times.com.

FWStar-Telegram
 Posted on Thu, Dec. 18, 2003   
 

Nuclear plant operators want extension on repair

The Associated Press

BAY CITY - Operators of a Southeast Texas nuclear plant have asked the U.S. 
Nuclear Regulatory Commission to extend until February the time it has to 
repair a failed emergency diesel generator, a spokesman for the plant said 
Wednesday.

Workers at the South Texas Project in Bay City believe a rod in one of six 
diesel generators used in emergencies was flawed and had microcracks, 
resulting in the generator's failure during a test Dec. 9, project spokesman 
Ed Conaway said.

The generators would be used if the plant's off-site power failed.

The commission has given the plant until Tuesday to make the repairs, or the 
reactor connected to the emergency generator might have to be shut down. The 
commission requires three emergency diesel generators for each nuclear 
reactor.

Conaway said workers plan to inspect rods in the other five generators as 
well.

Only one emergency generator is needed to keep each of the plant's two 
reactors operational in case of a power failure, he said
